text:
Acting is the art of creating a character in the film medium. The person who fulfills this aspect of film production is the actor. The actor and the film character are separate; in performance, however, the two merge and are perceived by the viewer as one.

The performance of actors is judged by their ability to effectively portray a given character. Thus, good actors make the audience believe in the characters they portray through the creative use of voice, facial and body movements, gestures, and the manner in which they relate to other characters. Acting requires both instinct and intelligence. Instinct is important for the actor to give a unique interpretation to what is demanded by the role. More important is the intelligence to be able to understand and bring humanity to the character he is portraying.

 

 

The actor is generally dependent on the director for guidance. Although film has many techniques for masking incompetence or errors in acting, or enhancing the performance (such as editing, camera movement, composition, and others), acting ability, nonetheless, is essential if the actor wishes to be truly successful. In musicals and action films, singing talent and skills in martial arts, respectively, may also be necessary.

According to generally acceptable standards, there are four factors to a screen actor’s performance. The physical dynamics of a character refers to the actor’s physique, movements, physical features, and personality traits that can be used to help the actor delineate a character. The inner spirit of the character refers to the actor’s ability to reveal subtle emotions and shadings of a character. The cinematic control of the character refers to the proper use of the film medium or the actor’s ability to create a character without resorting to overplaying or underplaying. The truth of the character refers to the effective revelation of character. Filipino actors, it is widely believed, are intuitive and sensitive performers. Though seriously handicapped by the lack of professional training, these actors often rely on their own skills to enable them to project ideas and emotions effectively, demonstrating a wide range of talent in the process. A remarkable number of able performers from every generation of screen professionals have achieved eminence through their own skills and talents, and through exposure to different roles given to them by producers and directors.

There was a time in the history of Philippine cinema when the aesthetics of film acting was limited to the portrayal of traditional roles as found in the sarsuwela and the drama. Actors who had performed on stage first necessarily brought with them into the cinema such conventions of stage acting as larger-than-life facial and body movements, stereotyped reactions, and conventional gestures. Also retained in the process was the one-dimensional characterization of traditional dramas. This simplistic characterization was perpetuated in film, forcing many performers to do typecast roles of heroes or villains.

This type of acting was further enhanced with the rise of radio soap operas from the 1940s to the 1960s where voice acting and highly emotional rendition of memorable lines defined good drama and therefore a credible performance. The popularity of the melodrama as Filipino entertainment was evident in the tearjerkers that showcased the talents of the most popular actors and actresses from the 1950s to the 1960s. These included the likes of Carmen Rosales, Rosa del Rosario, Anita Linda, Tita Duran, Pancho Magalona, Leopoldo Salcedo, Carlos Padilla, and Armando Goyena, followed by the generation of Rita Gomez, Marlene Dauden, Lolita Rodriguez, Charito Solis, Eddie Rodriguez, Dante Rivero, Vic Silayan, Robert Arevalo, and Eddie Garcia. For the longest time, typecasting prevented actors from developing their acting talents in the realistic mode. But it is to the credit of many of these actors that they were versatile enough to develop internalized acting when the newer directors called for it.

The development of stars into actors was attempted by a number of big studios during the 1950s. At Sampaguita, for instance, the acting coach of female stars was Rosa Mia, while Van de Leon and Lucas Paredes guided actors in the delivery and interpretation of their roles. Those who were being built up as major talents were given additional courses in social graces and grooming and were exposed to many social functions outside the studio. At LVN, the major stars were under the personal tutelage of the grand matriarch Doña Sisang. The same setup was implemented at Premiere and Lebran.

In the 1970s, another generation of actors emerged. These actors were shaped by a new batch of university-trained and independent-minded directors. Lino Brocka, who trained in theater, and Ishmael Bernal, who studied filmmaking abroad, were at the forefront of the emerging cinema. Displaying maturity and sensitivity to their material, they insisted on sincerity and truthfulness of characterization. Brocka discovered and developed new talents like Hilda Koronel, Christopher de Leon, Jay llagan, and Bembol Roco. Bernal, on the other hand, transformed Vilma Santos and Nora Aunor into the country’s best thespians. Later, Brocka would add to his list of discoveries such names as Phillip Salvador, Gina Alajar, and Mona Lisa, whose careers were successfully revived by their mentor. However, the 1970s also saw more television dramas gaining popularity and therefore defining what constitutes good acting in the eyes of the masa (masses). Like traditional acting before it, the standard of such acting was exemplified by Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), starring Marianne de la Riva and Ronald Corveau, with the young Romnick Sarmenta; Flordeluna, starring Laurice Guillen, Dindo Fernando, Herbert Bautista, and the young Janice de Belen; and Anna Liza, starring Julie Vega.

Armed with a theater background, Laurice Guillen became part of the efforts to professionalize acting in local cinema. Guillen and husband actor Johnny Delgado were instrumental in the training of fellow actors in the 1980s through the Actors’ Workshop, which they founded. Although the Actors’ Workshop is not a formal acting school, it succeeded in putting method into the largely untrained raw potential of screen thespians. Using the “Being Method” developed from Stanislavsky by American acting coach Eric Morris, the workshop, at one point, became the only “formal” training ground for local actors. The Actors Guild—also known as the Kapisanan ng mga Artistang Pilipino sa Pelikula at Telebisyon—and the Film Academy of the Philippines both endeavored to enhance the growth and development of the acting profession.

Other directors, such as Marilou Diaz-Abaya, were known to put their actors in a workshop before production in order to orient them. Cases like these are rare, however, and most directors today still rely on the raw talent of their stars to portray roles that have been identified with their screen image. A good number of the country’s better actors, like Gina Alajar, Bembol Roco, Jaclyn Jose, and Michael de Mesa, for that matter, became relegated to doing supporting roles and making occasional appearances that do little justice to their enormous talent.

But the rise of the independent filmmaking scene has opened new possibilities for these artists to flex their acting muscles. Certified actors who have been able to still show what it really means to be an actor with small indie movies that showcase their talents include the likes of Anita Linda, Eddie Garcia, Gina Pareño, Jaclyn Jose, Gina Alajar, Michael de Mesa, Judy Ann Santos, Joel Torre, Ricky Davao, Cherry Pie Pichache, Cherie Gil, Isabel Lopez, Julio Diaz, Ronnie Lazaro, and Mylene Dizon. To this day, icons like Nora Aunor and Vilma Santos continue to reap accolades not only for themselves but for the country.

There is also a new generation of performers, many of them from theater, who stood out from the independent movie scene to show that they are there for the art and not merely for the prize that comes with the celebrity status. Examples of these actors are Coco Martin, Alessandra de Rossi, Sid Lucero, Angel Aquino, Irma Adlawan, Eugene Domingo, Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino, Nonie Buencamino, John Arcilla, Lou Veloso, Pen Medina, Soliman Cruz, Hazel Orencio, Angelica Panganiban, Mercedes Cabral, Joem Bascon, Sue Prado, Joey Paras, Ina Feleo, Mara Lopez, Ping Medina, Alex Medina, Karl Medina, Victor Medina, and Angeli Bayani.

Acting as an art and a craft evolves and matures as it responds to the changes happening not only in local cinema but all over the world. The Filipino actor is right there—ready to match his foreign counterpart with as much talent as well as unwavering passion.  Written by Joel David and Justino Dormiendo, with notes from  Pio de Castro III, Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Jose Javier Reyes, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
The film archives is a place where film records are kept and systematically preserved. It serves as a repository for documents of historical value. The person having charge of the archives is called the film archivist. The main functions of the film archivist are selection, retrieval, and acquisition of important film records; preservation, restoration, and storage; cataloguing and documentation; and diffusion of the film culture or giving the public access to the film collection. In many parts of the world, film archivists are tasked to preserve not only the film medium but also magnetic recordings in video and audio formats and pertinent documents like photographs, correspondence, news items, posters, brochures, screenplays, and the like.

Among the developing countries in Asia, the Philippines has the longest film history, dating back to as early as 1897, when it was still a colony of Spain. The moving pictures that were exhibited during this period were made of such fragile organic, celluloid material that in time they easily deteriorated and are now forever lost. The coming of the Americans to the Philippines at the turn of the century was recorded in films, which were transferred on paper (a more stable medium) by the Edison Company so it could copyright its works. It is this “paper film” that has survived and was later recopied into celluloid once again.

 

 

From 1912, when the first Filipino feature film, La Vida de Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal), was produced in the country by Dr Edward Meyer Gross, to the present (2018), the Philippines has suffered an incalculable loss in its film heritage due to the lack of a permanent national film archives. It is ironic that a 1940 newsreel about the funeral of one of the country’s more popular cinema figures, the actor Rudy Concepcion, is preserved and stored in the Japanese film archives in Tokyo but no copy is available in the Philippines. Film owners have generally been unsuccessful in keeping their master negatives and other film properties intact, although studios like LVN Pictures and Sampaguita Pictures have exerted considerable efforts to preserve their films. Studio fires resulting from poor storage of nitrate films and the bombing and shelling of Manila during World War II wiped out productions prior to 1946 save for a handful of titles.

When the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) was established in 1981, one of its five modules was known as the Film Archives of the Philippines. The other four were Alternative Cinema, Film Fund, Film Ratings Board, and Manila International Film Festival. The ECP was short-lived, and it was replaced in 1984 by the Film Foundation of the Philippines (FFP), which in turn was dissolved in 1986 following the EDSA Revolt. Prior to the dissolution of the ECP and FFP, the film archives were transferred to the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). From 1986 to 1992, the film archives under the MTRCB have functioned as a storage facility or repository of old films alongside censored films or movies that have been withdrawn from exhibition.

The University of the Philippines Film Center (UPFC), established in 1976, put up its own film archives with the acquisition of master negatives and film records from Bancom Audiovision Corporation. The services offered by the UPFC then were cleaning and repair of films, temporary restoration to reduce the brittle inflexibility of old films, and transfer of 16 mm print to video. Technical evaluation reports were given to film owners so that they understood the condition of their films when they decided to reissue or deposit in the archives. The archives have since been turned over to the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP).

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) had its own archival collection. This includes the turn-of-the-century films acquired from the United States Library of Congress; the Lino Brocka collection; some Gerardo de Leon films; and productions of Sampaguita Pictures, Lea Productions, Tamaraw Films, and AM (Amalia Muhlach) Productions.

A major archival treasure, which was turned over to the Philippine government by the Federal Republic of Germany in 1990, is the newly restored version of Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961. This was made possible through the joint efforts of the Goethe Institut Manila, the German Embassy in Manila, the Federal Archive in Bonn, the Federal Archive in Koblenz, and Lufthansa. Chief restorer Harold Brandes used a special copying machine that produced a new duplicate negative after repairing all perforation damage on the only surviving but severely deteriorated 35 mm film copy. Afterward, the sound was copied on an intermediate film, from which a new sound negative was made. The new theater copy made from the 35 mm picture and sound negative was shown at a special screening at the Manila Film Center on 22 May 1990, during the commemoration of “Gerardo de Leon Year.” In 1992, the CCP invited Philippe Brunetaud to lecture at a Film Conservation Workshop.

In the area of film documentation, a few vital works that are comprehensive in scope have been accomplished by film researchers and librarians: “Philippine Motion Pictures, 1908-1958: A Checklist of the First Fifty Years,” 1979, by Carmencita Momblanco; “Filmography of Philippine Film 1959-1989,” 1995, by Arnulfo Junio; “Union Catalog on Philippine Culture: Film,” 1990, by the CCP Library Staff then headed by Carol Afan; and the filmography sections of all four Urian anthologies, edited by Nicanor Tiongson. The Momblanco work is a master’s thesis presented to the UP Institute of Library Science containing 1,379 bibliographic entries that document the movie industry’s film releases from 1908 to 1958. The Junio work continues the Momblanco filmography to three decades after. The Afan catalog consists of 3,642 bibliographic entries of printed materials, published and unpublished, written by Filipinos or foreign authors dealing solely or mainly with Philippine film. The Tiongson anthologies provide production data on the films exhibited in the Philippines for four decades, from 1970 to 2009.

Starting in the 1990s, there were two associations actively involved in matters concerning the state of film archives in the Philippines: the National Committee on Archives under the Sub-Commission on Cultural Heritage of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film (SOFIA). In 1993, SOFIA was established through the cooperation of professionals who believed in the value of film preservation and film restoration. SOFIA organized several seminars and workshops that focused on the collection, preservation, and archiving of important films. Through the years, SOFIA has exerted a tremendous amount of effort in initiating the preservation of several Filipino classic films through their cooperation with several organizations, such as the CCP, NCCA, the Goethe-Institut, and others. Most of SOFIA’s promotion and restoration projects are carried out through financial assistance that comes from the NCCA.

A few private institutions are actively involved in film archiving. The ABS-CBN Film Archives, the biggest of these institutions, currently holds over three thousand film prints from several companies like Sampaguita Pictures, LVN Pictures, Regal Films, Seiko Films, and OctoArts Films. In 2011, the network also established the ABS-CBN Film Restoration Project together with Central Digital Lab, aiming to restore classic Filipino films. Himala (Miracle), 1982, by Ishmael Bernal was the first film to be restored. The newly restored version of the film was shown in the 69th Venice International Film Festival. Several films have been restored since then, including Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; and Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976.

Other private archives include the Mowelfund Audiovisual Archive, which houses a collection of short films and documentaries, and the FPJ film archive, which holds a collection of Fernando Poe Jr’s films.

In 2011, after a long clamor for a national film archive, the National Film Archives of the Philippines (NFAP) was established through the initiative of the FDCP. The NFAP spearheads projects that aim to protect and restore the films that give shape to our national identity. So far, the NFAP has initiated the restoration of classic films like Genghis Khan, 1950, Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, and Insiang, 1976. Maynila and Insiang were restored in cooperation with Martin Scorsese’s Film Foundation through its World Cinema Project.  Written by Anella Mendoza and Lena S. Pareja, u pdated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
The Filipino movie audience falls into three categories based on household income: classes A, B, C, D, and E. Class A is composed of the upper class. This consists of the top and senior business executives, large-scale entrepreneurs, landlords, and licensed professionals (such as doctors, lawyers, engineers, and architects). Class B is the upper middle class. This includes mid-level executives (such as business managers and assistant managers), medium-scale entrepreneurs, and medium-size landowners. Class C, the middle class, is made up of junior business executives, mid-level professionals, small entrepreneurs, small farm owners, senior white-collar workers, and skilled workers. Group D, the lower class, consists of semiskilled workers and blue-collar workers. Group E, the extreme lower class, includes the unskilled workers, vendors, and the unemployed.

The first audiences for the Filipino film belonged to the lower class who delighted in the komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama in the first three decades of the 20th century, and the bodabil in the decade before the Pacific War. Raised on these theater forms, these urban audiences looked for the same themes, stories, characters, settings, and even stars in the first Filipino films. The taste of this audience for popular stage fare was reinforced when stage artists and technicians who went into film brought with them the content and conventions of traditional theater. After the war, it was still this audience who flocked to see local films as these had a language and culture to which they could relate. Film director Lamberto Avellana coined the term “bakya crowd” (after the cheap wooden clogs they usually wore) for this audience who seemed unable to appreciate “artistic” movies, preferring to be entertained by romantic melodramas, action, comedy, fantasy, and horror films. Until the 1960s, local movies were generally labeled bakya in contrast to English movies shown in classy English movie houses.

 

 

But this changed beginning in 1966, when Manila Mayor Antonio Villegas founded the Manila Film Festival (MFF) where Tagalog films were showcased for 12 days in leading commercial theaters previously dedicated to foreign films. Foreign films were not shown in these theaters during the festival. In 1975, the MFF became the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), which also required all cinemas in Metro Manila to exhibit only Filipino films during the Christmas season. Through the years, the audience of the MMFF increased. In 2015, the box-office earnings of the MMFF official film entries reached more than a billion pesos. The movie audiences were composed of families, adults, teenagers, and children who could afford to pay the movie ticket ranging from 200 pesos to 250 pesos. The 2015 box-office results showed that this movie audience preferred comedy (Beauty and the Bestie), romance-comedy (My Bebe Love and Walang Forever [No Forever]), and horror (Haunted Mansion).

The rise of the middle class who could still afford to spend for movies gave way to the emergence of multiplexes in the malls. SM Cinemas, Ayala Mall Cinemas, and Robinsons Movieworld are the leading theater chains in the country. SM Cinemas do not show movies with R18 classification (only viewers who are eighteen years old and above can be admitted into an R18 film) as part of their corporate policy to offer family-oriented entertainment.

 

 

Finally, the introduction in the 1970s of film and communication courses in the college curriculum developed a more educated and critical generation of film audiences. They would expect films with better production values, both in content and form. At the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, which is designed to discover and honor the cinematic works of young Filipino filmmakers, majority of its audience who flocked to the Cultural Center of the Philippines is composed of students and film enthusiasts. From its initial audience count of 11,607 in 2005, it rose to 96,639 in 2013 with simultaneous screenings in Ayala Malls Cinemas. These young viewers are the audience of the new Philippine cinema (Szymanski 2015, 176).

The continuously evolving demographic of Filipino film audiences is further concretized by a survey conducted by the Social Weather Stations and commissioned by the Film Development Council of the Philippines in 2006. The results of the survey state that 67 percent of audiences who watch in the cinema come from the class D, most of them from the National Capital Region. Of this population, 49 percent either finished high school or have a bit of college education. Meanwhile, 56 percent of film audiences who watch movies either at home or in the movie houses belong to the ABC classes. What these statistics state is that our films are beginning to cater to the more affluent and educated sections of the movie-watching population. The various effects that these changes have caused on the quality of our films and their projected quality and diversity of audiences are still taking shape amidst the complex milieu of our cinematic history.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, Justino Dormiendo, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, with notes from Pio de Castro III and Bienvenido Lumbera , updated by Elvin Valerio, Rica Leticia Arevalo, and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
Film awards are a form of recognition, honorific or monetary, given to artistic or technical achievement in film in a particular year or period. The annual awards rites conducted by the various groups and organizations in the country confer honors on movie people as a measure of recognition for their efforts and achievements in the film industry. Film grants are special subsidies given to deserving filmmakers in order to help them in their craft and ensure realization of a proposed project. This may come in the form of travel grants, scholarships, and subsidies.

Movie industry awards were first conferred by the Manila Times Publishing Company: the Maria Clara Awards in recognition of the best films and performances of 1950 and 1951. When the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) was established on 31 May 1953 to honor the best film achievements for 1952, the Maria Clara Awards bowed out of existence. Patterned after the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Hollywood, FAMAS originally counted as members people from the movie industry itself. Among the original members were directors, actors, cinematographers, scriptwriters, musical directors, sound directors, and film editors. In addition, members from the movie press, who had no direct involvement in the work of movie people, were invited to counteract possible biases expected from so-called loyalty votes of industry colleagues.

 

 

The FAMAS criteria emphasized that “a picture should be judged in its totality as it strikes the perceptual senses” and “a motion picture should possess more than mere realism.” The concern of the FAMAS was on formal aspects of filmmaking, such as scriptwriting, direction, acting, cinematography, editing, sound, and music.

On 1 May 1976, the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) was organized by academicians and journalists “to stimulate dialogue between the moviegoers and the film industry, to explore directions for the improvement of films, and to develop awareness of the responsibility of film as a medium of expression and communication, given the conditions of contemporary filmmaking in the Philippines.” The MPP considers both content and form in its evaluation of a film. In the MPP criteria, “the content of the film is considered superior if it is a truthful portrayal of the human condition as perceived by the Filipino, and if it deals with the Filipino experience to which the greater number of moviegoers can relate.” Form is artistic if the filmmakers are able “to use and integrate creatively the various elements of cinema direction, screenplay, acting, cinematography, production design, editing, music, and sound.” The MPP emphasizes the need to integrate the various elements that contribute to the totality of a film.

 

 

In 1978, two years after the institution of the MPP, the Archdiocese of Manila, headed by Jaime Cardinal Sin, established the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). It was organized with the sole purpose of rewarding film and other media products “which transmit genuine human values to their audience through the competent and professional use of the appropriate mass media techniques.” The CMMA’s foremost concern was the “role of mass media in creating a humane society.” CMMA standards and criteria stress the significance of the moral, social, and spiritual values that film and other mass media impart to their audience. The CMMA jurors represent a cross section of media, business, trade, academic, and socio-civic groups.

On 5 Jan 1981, leaders of the film industry established the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) as the official awards body of the industry tasked to confer its own annual awards that reflect the opinion of industry technicians and artists. In its criteria, the FAP stressed the value of team effort, to which individual merit must be subordinated. “It is the cohesive, intermingling effort of the group that must come into play, from director, actor, script, editing, cinematography, music, sound, and production design put together.” A film, to be adjudged excellent, has to achieve a high degree of credibility and realism. The FAP defines realism in the context of a film’s ability to portray its message believably, “whether it is a true-to-life story or a science-fiction fantasy.”

 

 

In 1984, the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) established its own “Star Awards” to honor outstanding members of the film industry for their achievements in various aspects of film. A great majority of its members come from the print media. In 2003, several members of the PMPC formed a group called the Entertainment Press Society and they established the Golden Screen Awards a year later.

There were also film festivals that gave out awards for Filipino films: the Manila Film Festival (MFF), founded by Mayor Antonio Villegas in 1966, which always coincided with the Araw ng Maynila (Manila Day) celebration in June (1966-74); the defunct Manila International Film Festival (1982-83); the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) Short Film Festival (1982-85); and the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), held in December. Established in 1975 and formerly called the Metropolitan Film Festival, MMFF is considered to be a continuation of the MFF.

 

 

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) has, since 1987, conducted the annual Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video to honor young and promising filmmakers. Also, from 1989 to the present, the CCP has also been paying tribute to local artists, including filmmakers, through the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. The CCP has sponsored a Film Grants Program for new talented filmmakers, offering funding and a guaranteed venue for video features, documentaries, experimental films, and animation. In line with the CCP’s vision to develop a truly Filipino national culture that evolves from the grassroots, film, radio, and video production workshops have also been conducted in various regions of the country.

In 1999, the first Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF) opened. CIFF invited Filipino and foreign filmmakers annually to submit entries for competition. The first batch of CIFF winners included Leaf on a Pillow by Garin Nugroho of Indonesia for the grand prize Lino Brocka Award; The Terrorist by Santosh Sivan of India for the Grand Jury Prize; Ricky Davao of the Philippines, Best Actor for Saranggola (The Kite); Ana Capri of the Philippines, Best Actress for Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water); Birth of a Butterfly by Mojtaba Rael of Iran for the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award; Father’s Toys by Carol Miu-Suiet of Hong Kong for Best Short Film; and The Port of Last Resort by Paul Rosdy and Joan Grossman of Austria/USA for Best Documentary. Fruto Corre’s documentary Mountain of Waters received Special Citation.

In 2006, the awards in Cinemanila’s first Digital Lokal competition were given to Manoro (The Teacher) by Brillante Mendoza, Grand Prize; Squatterpunk by Khavn de la Cruz, Jury Prize; Brillante Mendoza, Manoro, Best Director; Maricel Soriano, Numbalikdiwa (Reversion of the Soul), Best Actress; Archie Adamos, Raket ni Nanay (Mother’s Sideline), Best Actor; and Numbalikdiwa by Bobby Bonifacio Jr and Anino ng Setyembre (September’s Shadow) by Briccio Santos, Audience Favorite Awards.

At the turn of the millennium and the spread of inexpensive digital video technology, more film festivals and competitions with corresponding awards were established in celebration of independent films, which no longer depended on commercial film producers and were free to follow the filmmakers’ artistic visions. In 2005, the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival was established in order to encourage and celebrate the creation of new and original cinematic works “that boldly articulate and freely interpret the Filipino experience with fresh insight and artistic integrity.” This festival was originally sponsored by the CCP, the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP), the UP College of Mass Communication, Tonyboy Cojuangco, and the Cinemalaya Foundation Inc, a nonprofit, nongovernment foundation that aims to promote the Filipino independent film through grants and prizes. After Cinemalaya, the Cinema One cable television network launched the Cinema One Originals in 2005, an annual film festival held in selected cinema outlets that showcases the diversity of themes, talents, and voices in the independent film industry.

In 2008, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), through the National Committee on Cinema (NCC), launched Cinema Rehiyon, an annual film festival that celebrates and promotes the production of independent films from the various regions of the country. Through Cinema Rehiyon, the NCCA also features the yearly winners of the several regional film festivals that it funds—namely, the Pasale: A Film Concourse and Advocacy in Bicol, the Cinemagis: Northern Mindanao Digital Short Film Festival in Cagayan de Oro City, the Pelikultura: CALABARZON Film Festival in the CALABARZON region, the Lilas Binisaya Film Festival in Cebu City, the Nabunturan Independent Film Exhibition in Compostela Valley, the Mindanao Film Festival in Davao City, the Lutas Film Festival in Dumaguete City, the Lantawan-SOCSKSARGEN Film Festival in General Santos City, the Cinekasimanwa: The Panay Island Film Festival in Iloilo City, the CineAnimo: Misamis Occidental-Zamboanga Digital Short Film Festival in Ozamis City, and the Cine Kabalen Film Festival in Pampanga.

In 2011, the FDCP launched its flagship film competition, Sineng Pambansa, an irregularly held event which is a good venue for young filmmakers to further hone their talents and showcase their works. The festival’s mission is “to revitalize the Filipino film industry by encouraging and supporting the production of high-quality films, and by promoting the works of Filipino filmmakers to a wider public through national and international film festivals.” Occasionally, the Sineng Pambansa has an All-Masters edition, which gives grants to the major local filmmakers so they can make art films.

In 2013, the first Quezon City International Film Festival (QCinema) was held by the Quezon City Film Development Commission (QCFDC) in order to encourage and inspire filmmakers from Quezon City to create films that are imbued with love for country, gender sensitivity, and excellence. After selecting the best scripts submitted to the commission, the filmmakers are given monetary grants and a full year to realize their scripts as full-length films. The festival is now held annually. Established in 2006, the QCFDC is the first and only commission of its kind in the country. Known for its adherence to sensitivity toward issues involving gender and sexuality, the QCFDC also held the largest Asian LGBT film festival in 2014, the Quezon City International Pink Festival.

Also in 2013, the CineFilipino Film Festival was launched by Unitel Productions Inc, which “aims to support and develop new cinematic, audience-friendly works of artistic merit by up-and-coming and established filmmakers to help define the human experience through a Filipino perspective.” The festival holds competitions for a variety of film formats that include short films, feature-length films, documentaries, and digitally formatted TV series.

In 2015, the Singkuwento International Film Festival was inaugurated. The festival aims to gather Filipino filmmakers from the Philippines and abroad for the continued promotion and nourishment of Philippine film. The festival holds annual screenings and competitions that involve multi-formatted film entries, such as short films and documentaries.

Filipino filmmakers have won awards not only in local festivals and competitions but also in international festivals. Among these filmmakers are Raymond Red, who won the Palme d’Or at Cannes Film Festival in 2000 for his short film Anino (Shadow); Lav Diaz, who won the Special Jury Prize at Fribourg International Film Festival in 2006 for Heremias, and the Orizzonti Grand Prize at the Venice International Film Festival in 2008 for Melancholia; and Brillante Mendoza who won Best Director in the Cannes Film Festival in 2009 for his film Kinatay (The Execution of P.). Other Filipino filmmakers have won awards in prestigious film festivals in Venice, Berlin, Locarno, Brussels, Rotterdam, Cairo, New York, Toronto,Vancouver,Tokyo,Busan, Singapore, Bangkok, among others.  Written by Lena S. Pareja and Justino Dormiendo, with notes from  Pio de Castro III, Bienvenido Lumbera, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
Censorship refers to the official act of examining motion pictures before they are screened publicly to prevent the exhibition of films that are deemed “immoral, indecent, contrary to law and/or good customs or injurious to the prestige of the Republic of the Philippines and its people” (Republic Act 3060, 1961).

 

Following the declaration of martial law by then president Ferdinand Marcos on 21 Sep 1972, the prohibitions as exercised by the government office concerned were expanded to include films that “tend to incite subversion, insurrection, or rebellion against the State; tend to undermine the faith and confidence of the people in their government and/or duly constituted authorities; glorify criminals or condone crimes; serve no other purpose but to satisfy the market for violence or pornography; offend any race or religion; tend to abet the traffic in and use of prohibited drugs; are contrary to law, public order, morals, good customs, established policies, lawful orders, decrees or edicts; and any or all films which in the judgment of the Board are similarly objectionable and contrary to the letter and spirit of Proclamation No. 1­081” (Letter of Instruction 13, 1972).

 

 

In the Philippines, film censorship and classification have been implemented by a board known at various times as Board of Censors, Board of Censors for Motion Pictures (BCMP), Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television (BRMPT), and Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB ). Cinema first came to the Philippines during the last days of Spanish colonial rule when there was no film censorship. During the first two decades of American rule, films imported from Europe and the United States (US) enjoyed unlimited freedom of exhibition. It was only when Filipinos started producing their own movies that some sectors of the community saw the need for measures to control moviemaking activities. This was presumably the result of a protest lodged by the Spanish community that resented the showing of a film by JulianManansala titled Patria Amore (Beloved Country), which, opened at the Palace Theater on 23 Jul 1929. What Manansala intended as a nationalist work was perceived by the Spaniards as a movie with “anti-Spanish sentiments.” The protesters filed a court injunction to stop the exhibition of the movie. An American-dominated board, however, denied the plea for an injunction. Nevertheless, the authorities had been alerted. Four months later, on 27 Nov 1929, the Philippine Legislature established the first censors body by approving “An Act to Create a Board of Censorship for Motion Pictures and Define Its Functions.”

 

One of the early Filipino movies that provoked the censors’ ire was Filippine Films’ Batang Tulisan (Young Bandit), 1937. The film was found objectionable not only for its title, which the censors feared would infect the youth with “certain subversive ideas,” but also for the presentation of a priest in a villainous role; the use of a hypodermic, poison-laden injection as a murder weapon; and the courtship scenes between a boy and a girl who were both 10 years of age. Interestingly, these same scenes were depicted in Gregorio Coching’s Liwayway magazine serial that ran for several weeks before the screenplay based on the novel was completed. No objections were raised at the time the magazine serial came out. But the producers had no choice; they had to re-edit the film and change its title to Binatang Parang (Barrio Swain) so that it could be shown some six months later.

 

 

The prewar years were relatively peaceful and without controversy for the board. Filipino movie fare favored sarsuwela cum Hollywood-style musicals in the Philippine setting, like Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star) 1937, Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), Arimunding-Munding, 1938, Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut) 1938, and Leron-Leron Sinta (Leron-Leron Beloved), 1939.

 

During the Japanese occupation period from 1942 to 1943, film censorship was handled by the Bureau of Information and Public Security under the Commission of the Interior. In 1944, the function was absorbed by the Board of Information (Hodobu), also known as the Propaganda Corps. The following were considered censorable and subject to confiscation: anti-Japanese propaganda, advocacy of democracy, attempts to alienate the Axis powers from one another, repudiation of the war, opposition to the fundamental principles of the educational renovations in the Philippines, and exposure of alleged improper conduct of the military administration. These restrictions were applied not only to film but also to radio, stage shows, and printed media. It was the role of the Hodobu to control, direct, supervise, and coordinate all the information and publicity activities of the Philippine Republic. Only two feature films were made during this period, the war epic Dawn of Freedom, 1944, and a drama advocating the return to country living, Tatlong Maria (Three Marys), 1944. Both films were produced and distributed by the Bureau of Southern Areas of the Movie Distribution Compan y (Eiga Haikyusha).

 

 

Immediately after the war, film producers resumed work and a new Board of Review for Moving Pictures was established by Pres Manuel A. Roxas in 1946. The first film to come under fire in the postwar period was Premiere Productions’ Ako Raw Ay Huk (They Call Me Rebel), 1946, a film that explored the life of a member of the peasant guerrilla organization known as Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa mga Hapon (Hukbalahap). Government representatives on the board found the material objectionable. Because of this film, officials of the Philippine Constabulary (PC) considered the idea of requiring future scripts to be approved by the PC before they were filmed. Some journalists on the board, including Teodoro A. Valencia (who later was to become board chair), refused to abide by the principle of prior censorship. Ako Raw Ay Huk was finally approved under a new title, Labi ng Digmaan (Survivor of War), 1946.

 

In the late 1950s and early 1960s, crime and violence became the big issues. This trend would continue up to the 1970s and even the 1980s, when the censors would run into the same problem. As early as 1962, Maliw alu was banned because of its portrayal of excessive violence, but the board’s decision was overruled by an Appeals Committee (composed of the undersecretaries of defense, justice, and education) that later allowed its showing after the controversial portions were deleted. In 1963, the board was again in the center of controversy when the permit for the movie Ang Manananggol ni Ruben (The Lawyer of Ruben) was withdrawn after four days of exhibition. The notoriety of Ruben Ablaza, who was convicted in the real-life sensational rape case involving Annabelle Higgins, was cited by the board as its main reason for revoking the permit. When the movie was finally approved and shown, the controversial Ablaza sequence had been deleted and its title shortened to Ang Manananggol (The Lawyer).

 

Two other films censored in the 1960s had nothing to do with either crime or violence. Politics and freedom of expression became the issues in Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), 1965, purportedly about the life of then presidential candidate Ferdinand Marcos, while religious discrimination was the charge against Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1969. The Iginuhit controversy was finally settled by a Supreme Court decision in favor of the producers who invoked freedom of expression in cinema. In the case of Perlas ng Silangan, the provincial board of Sulu Province protested that the movie “misrepresented Muslim customs and defamed Islam.” Again, the film was eventually shown in a watered-down version.

 

In Jul 1970, film producer/director Ruben Abalos opened the floodgates for the bomba with his Uhaw (Thirsty) starring sultry Merle Fernandez. This was followed by Celso Ad. Castillo’s Nympha (Nymph) and other bomba films like Luray (Ravaged), Hidhid (Sex-Starved), Daing (Moan), Busog (Sated), Haliparot (Flirt), Patigasan (The Harder One Wins), Ang Bukid ay Basa (The Field Is Wet), Saging ni Pacing (Pacing’s Banana), Batuta ni Drakula (Dracula’s Nightstick), Ako sa Itaas, Ikaw sa Ibaba (Me on Top, You Under), 1971; mainstream cinema, in the words of then censors’ chief Guillermo de Vega, “went wayward and floundered in a stream of gross sensationalism and bad taste.” The continued proliferation of bomba films in the 1970s led to the forced resignation of the censors’ board members. The public indignation over the showing of Mga Uhaw na Bulaklak (Thirsty Flowers), 1976, ultimately resulted in the dissolution of the entire board and the creation of a new and stricter group.

 

Ironically, this was one of the finest periods in mainstream Philippine cinema, which saw the emergence of a new breed of filmmakers. Subsequently, Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, Mike de Leon, Behn Cervantes, Celso Ad. Castillo, and Marilou Diaz-Abaya would also at various times in this period be embroiled in issues of censorship with the censors’ chief, Maria Kalaw Katigbak, and later, Manuel Morato.

 

The case of Behn Cervantes’s Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, was equally controversial. The film, which was critical of the landlords in Negros province, attracted the attention of the military who confiscated the prints of the film. Though it was shown on a limited run, its permit was subsequently revoked and all its prints confiscated by military agents. In a city in Negros, landlords reportedly bought the booking rights two weeks in advance so that the moviegoers there, many of them sakada, would not get to see it.

 

In the 1980s, sex movies enjoyed an unprecedented degree of freedom mainly in the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) venue at the Manila Film Center, especially during the Manila International Film Festival. This prompted the Catholic Women’s League to stage its biggest rally against both the ECP and the Manila Film Center, which showcased “explicit” films by renowned filmmakers such as Nagisa Oshima’s In the Realm of the Senses, 1976, and Bernardo Bertolluci’s 1900, 1976, as well as Filipino sex-oriented films like Snake Sisters, 1984, Isla (Island), 1985, Scorpio Nights, 1985, and Boatman, 1985.

 

In 1985, the board was renamed Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB), but the same guidelines continued. Although the board claims that its work is mainly classification, some artists continue to raise issues of censorship against the MTRCB as well as questions regarding the composition and qualification of its members.

 

Manuel L. Morato wielded the scissors from 1986 to 1992 as chair of the MTRCB under Pres Corazon C. Aquino’s administration. Morato banned Martin Scorsese’s The Last Temptation of Christ, 1988, an adaptation of Nikos Kazantzakis’s novel.The Morato board also banned the Filipino documentary Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan), 1989, for its anti-US bases position in Clark Air Base and Subic Naval Base. Lino Brocka’s Orapronobis, 1989, was not spared censorship because it attacks human rights violations—specifically, the vigilantes—under the Cory regime.

 

Then, Pres Fidel V. Ramos appointed Atty Henrietta S. Mendez MTRCB chair from 1992 to 1995. The Mendez board created an uproar for banning Steven Spielberg’s Schindler’s List, 1993, for sex and nudity; Jane Campion’s The Piano, 1993, for sex and adultery; and Clint Eastwood’s The Bridges of Madison County, 1995, for the brief scene showing the pubic hair of Meryl Streep. An Appeals Committee was formed, which could overturn an MTRCB decision on a film rated X twice.

 

Former presidential press secretary and journalist Jesus “Jess” S. Sison followed Etta Mendez as MTRCB chief from 1995 to 1998. Sison introduced the policy of allowing only television programs rated General Patronage (GP) to be aired from 6:00 am to 7:00 pm. All other shows rated Parental Guidance (PG) could be shown only from 8:00 pm to 6:00 am. Sison paid close attention to titles. Basa, for instance, was changed to Basa sa Dagat (Sea-Drenched), 1995, Tikim to Patikim ng Pinya (Let Me Taste the Pineapple), 1996, and Daigdig ng mga Toro (World of Bulls) to Halimuyak ng Babae (Scent of a Woman), 1996.

 

Producer-actor Armida Siguion-Reyna was the MTRCB chair under Pres Joseph Estrada from 1998 to 2001. Her board now had more members from the movie and television industries than the preceding boards, and more than half of the members came from the industry, which had never happened before. As insiders or practicing artists, the board was comparatively more lenient than the past boards. Perhaps the most controversial films approved during Siguion-Reyna’s time were Live Show (aka Toro), 2001, and Sutla (Silk), 1999. Laging Sariwa (Always Fresh), 1999, Dugo ng Birhen (Virgin’s Blood), 1999, and Monay (Bread Roll) got an X because, opined the review committees, the sex scenes were not necessary to the story. Live Show, though approved on second review, did not get screened in theaters during Siguion-Reyna’s time.

 

Despite their liberalism, however, it can be said that this board was just as strict as the boards before them. Jose F. Lacaba, former vice-chair of Siguion-Reyna, stated that “from July 1998 to October 1999, the Siguion-Reyna board gave an X rating … to a total of 37 films—of which 12, despite a degree of pruning in some cases, went on to get another X on second review…. In the first year and three months of the Board’s existence, we closed down 52 theaters, primarily for allowing minors into Adults Only movies. Compare that with records of the past boards: three years of the Sison board, 45 theaters closed; three years of the Etta Mendez board, 32 theaters closed; six years of the Morato board, no record on file.”

 

Film critic and educator Nicanor G. Tiongson became the MTRCB chair from 2 Feb 2001 to 21 Mar 2001 after Erap resigned as president. Since the permit to exhibit the critically acclaimed Live Show was still valid, it was finally screened in Philippine theaters. It elicited the ire of the Catholic Church, and Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, pressured by the Church, ordered the public screening of the said film stopped. After only less than three weeks as chair, Tiongson resigned in protest against what he considered an illegal banning of the film.

 

Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo then picked writer Alejandro (Anding) R. Roces to replace Tiongson. Not a lot of fireworks happened during Roces’s term between 4 Apr 2001 and 21 Jun 2002 that would send showbiz reporters agog with “newsworthy” tidbits.

 

Marilen Y. Dinglasan followed Anding Roces, and served as MTRCB chief from 22 Jun 2002 to 7 Nov 2002. It was during Dinglasan’s time when a new law turned over to MTRCB the responsibility of reviewing and classifying DVD, VHS, and other optical media materials. This task used to be performed by the Optical Media Board, then headed by actor Edu Manzano. Atty Dennis G. Manicad took over after Dinglasan as officer-in-charge from 8 Nov 2002 to 26 Feb 2003. Again, it was a relatively quiet period as the board members of MTRCB conscientiously did their job, with nothing much of a change from the policies of the past boards. Erring theaters would be closed, producers and filmmakers would be penalized, all according to law and the internal rules and regulations of the MTRCB.

 

Consoliza P. Laguardia was MTRCB chair from 27 Feb 2003 until 22 Oct 2010. A movie fan, Laguardia would readily be available as reviewer, especially if a committee lacked a reviewer. She watched quite a number of local and foreign movies, and was in her element, so to speak, when movie stars and starlets would visit the office. She was much aware of issues of violations committed by television personalities, such as Rufa Mae Quinto, Lolit Solis, Willie Revillame, and Joey de Leon. She also ordered the closure of some theaters, but played safe when it came to political films. An episode of the broadcast documentary Reporter’s Notebook that featured an indigenous tradition of giant wooden phalluses was axed for airing on GMA 7. Furthermore, a short film regarding the oil spill in Guimaras in Panay Gulf was not given a permit for public exhibition perhaps so as not to highlight government negligence. Then, a biopic in the format of a documentary on ex-president Joseph Estrada was rated X on first and second reviews. The movie The Da Vinci Code, 2006, an adaptation of Dan Brown’s novel of the same title, directed by Ron Howard, was approved for public screening in 2006, in spite of protests by the Roman Catholic Church.

 

Pres Benigno Aquino III handpicked Mary Grace Poe Llamanzares as MTRCB chair. It was Grace Poe’s first government position. From the start of 23 Oct 2010, Llamanzares took to heart her new job until she resigned on 1 Oct 2012, in preparation for her candidacy as senator. One of Grace Poe’s first moves as chief of MTRCB was to meet with all the MTRCB employees, study all the past records of MTRCB, and dialogue with film producers and television heads, as well as with representatives of movie and television shows, the better to understand problems and to seek solutions. Under Poe’s leadership, less punishments or penalties were meted out. Immediate punitive action was prevented because violators were first warned, and more informal and sympathetic dialogue between MTRCB and violating parties were held. She introduced the classification rating of R-16 for the movies, and Strong Parental Guidance (SPG) for television. She supported independent filmmakers and advocated the protection of children.

 

Following in the footsteps of Grace Poe is Atty Eugenio H. Villareal. He replaced Poe on 28 Nov 2012. Aside from dialogue, the best practices that minimize penalties and punishments expanded to the creation of committees in order to strengthen advocacies. Seminars with the theme “Matalinong Panonood ng Pamilya at Lipunan nina Juan at Juana,” or MP, was conducted all over Metro Manila and the regions. Media literacy and MPs are meant to heighten the awareness of people about the ratings and classifications of MTRCB as well as the tasks or functions of the agency. Tie-ups and memoranda of agreement are signed between MTRCB and both government and nongovernment entities. In 2015, board members are busy with various committees, like committees on persons with disabilities, on family and children’s rights, on gender sensitivity, and on senior citizens. Film showings for the board and staff are conducted, and the filmmakers are invited. Self-regulation is encouraged by letting the TV stations decide on their own if their show merits a G, a PG, or an SPG. Because of the additional programs and projects and the new character of the MTRCB, it has now been considered not just a review and classification agency but also a developmental institution.

 

Naturally, not everyone can be pleased. Some still fight for more freedom of expression and complete self-regulation, or abolition of the MTRCB; others opt for censorship of the old school. In the end, there are laws, and until the laws themselves are changed, citizens have to abide by them. This is not to say that there is no room for liberal interpretations and applications. For instance, the MTRCB still has, under Presidential Decree 1986, the authority to “approve or disapprove, delete objectionable portions from and/or prohibit the showing of TV shows and movies.” This censorship function is circumvented by letting the filmmakers themselves decide what scenes to retain or to cut in order to merit a certain desired rating. MTRCB values, ultimately, age appropriateness or the protection of children.  Written by Lena S. Pareja and Justino Dormiendo, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Marra PL. Lanot

Lacaba, former vice-chair of Siguion-Reyna, stated that “from July 1998 to October 1999, the Siguion-Reyna board gave an X rating … to a total of 37 films—of which 12, despite a degree of pruning in some cases, went on to get another X on second review…. In the first year and three months of the Board’s existence, we closed down 52 theaters, primarily for allowing minors into Adults Only movies. Compare that with records of the past boards: three years of the Sison board, 45 theaters closed; three years of the Etta Mendez board, 32 theaters closed; six years of the Morato board, no record on file.”

Film critic and educator Nicanor G. Tiongson became the MTRCB chair from 2 Feb 2001 to 21 Mar 2001 after Erap resigned as president. Since the permit to exhibit the critically acclaimed Live Show was still valid, it was finally screened in Philippine theaters. It elicited the ire of the Catholic Church, and Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, pressured by the Church, ordered the public screening of the said film stopped. After only less than three weeks as chair, Tiongson resigned in protest against what he considered an illegal banning of the film.

Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo then picked writer Alejandro (Anding) R. Roces to replace Tiongson. Not a lot of fireworks happened during Roces’s term between 4 Apr 2001 and 21 Jun 2002 that would send showbiz reporters agog with “newsworthy” tidbits.

Marilen Y. Dinglasan followed Anding Roces, and served as MTRCB chief from 22 Jun 2002 to 7 Nov 2002. It was during Dinglasan’s time when a new law turned over to MTRCB the responsibility of reviewing and classifying DVD, VHS, and other optical media materials. This task used to be performed by the Optical Media Board, then headed by actor Edu Manzano. Atty Dennis G. Manicad took over after Dinglasan as officer-in-charge from 8 Nov 2002 to 26 Feb 2003. Again, it was a relatively quiet period as the board members of MTRCB conscientiously did their job, with nothing much of a change from the policies of the past boards. Erring theaters would be closed, producers and filmmakers would be penalized, all according to law and the internal rules and regulations of the MTRCB.

Consoliza P. Laguardia was MTRCB chair from 27 Feb 2003 until 22 Oct 2010. A movie fan, Laguardia would readily be available as reviewer, especially if a committee lacked a reviewer. She watched quite a number of local and foreign movies, and was in her element, so to speak, when movie stars and starlets would visit the office. She was much aware of issues of violations committed by television personalities, such as Rufa Mae Quinto, Lolit Solis, Willie Revillame, and Joey de Leon. She also ordered the closure of some theaters, but played safe when it came to political films. An episode of the broadcast documentary Reporter’s Notebook that featured an indigenous tradition of giant wooden phalluses was axed for airing on GMA 7. Furthermore, a short film regarding the oil spill in Guimaras in Panay Gulf was not given a permit for public exhibition perhaps so as not to highlight government negligence. Then, a biopic in the format of a documentary on ex-president Joseph Estrada was rated X on first and second reviews. The movie The Da Vinci Code, 2006, an adaptation of Dan Brown’s novel of the same title, directed by Ron Howard, was approved for public screening in 2006, in spite of protests by the Roman Catholic Church.

Pres Benigno Aquino III handpicked Mary Grace Poe Llamanzares as MTRCB chair. It was Grace Poe’s first government position. From the start of 23 Oct 2010, Llamanzares took to heart her new job until she resigned on 1 Oct 2012, in preparation for her candidacy as senator. One of Grace Poe’s first moves as chief of MTRCB was to meet with all the MTRCB employees, study all the past records of MTRCB, and dialogue with film producers and television heads, as well as with representatives of movie and television shows, the better to understand problems and to seek solutions. Under Poe’s leadership, less punishments or penalties were meted out. Immediate punitive action was prevented because violators were first warned, and more informal and sympathetic dialogue between MTRCB and violating parties were held. She introduced the classification rating of R-16 for the movies, and Strong Parental Guidance (SPG) for television. She supported independent filmmakers and advocated the protection of children.

Following in the footsteps of Grace Poe is Atty Eugenio H. Villareal. He replaced Poe on 28 Nov 2012. Aside from dialogue, the best practices that minimize penalties and punishments expanded to the creation of committees in order to strengthen advocacies. Seminars with the theme “Matalinong Panonood ng Pamilya at Lipunan nina Juan at Juana,” or MP, was conducted all over Metro Manila and the regions. Media literacy and MPs are meant to heighten the awareness of people about the ratings and classifications of MTRCB as well as the tasks or functions of the agency. Tie-ups and memoranda of agreement are signed between MTRCB and both government and nongovernment entities. In 2015, board members are busy with various committees, like committees on persons with disabilities, on family and children’s rights, on gender sensitivity, and on senior citizens. Film showings for the board and staff are conducted, and the filmmakers are invited. Self-regulation is encouraged by letting the TV stations decide on their own if their show merits a G, a PG, or an SPG. Because of the additional programs and projects and the new character of the MTRCB, it has now been considered not just a review and classification agency but also a developmental institution.

Naturally, not everyone can be pleased. Some still fight for more freedom of expression and complete self-regulation, or abolition of the MTRCB; others opt for censorship of the old school. In the end, there are laws, and until the laws themselves are changed, citizens have to abide by them. This is not to say that there is no room for liberal interpretations and applications. For instance, the MTRCB still has, under Presidential Decree 1986, the authority to “approve or disapprove, delete objectionable portions from and/or prohibit the showing of TV shows and movies.” This censorship function is circumvented by letting the filmmakers themselves decide what scenes to retain or to cut in order to merit a certain desired rating. MTRCB values, ultimately, age appropriateness or the protection of children.

text:
Cinematography involves the use of lighting and composition to create the images that will bring out the significance of a scene as visualized by the film director. The elements of cinematography are lighting, which helps create drama, mystery, suspense, and humor; composition or the arrangement of people and objects within the frame; and movement, which includes the mobility of the camera to change a vantage point.

 

The cinematographer, also called the director of photography (DOP), works directly with the production crew or shooting unit in the setup of a particular scene. The DOP scrutinizes the set together with the director and instructs the camera operator where to position the camera. He or she tells the gaffer where to place the lights and how to adjust the lighting, runs an exposure meter over the faces of the actors, and peers through the contrast filter to check the relationship between light and shadow. When everything is set up, the DOP advises the director who then steps up to the camera to approve its setup. On the director’s signal or call for “Roll camera … action!” the camera starts grinding, the actors perform until the director yells “Cut!”

 

 

The early Filipino director-producers like Jose Nepomuceno and Jose Domingo Badilla were first of all highly competent professional photographers. Lighting then was basic illumination, merely to allow the camera to record images on film. But these pioneer filmmakers knew that cinematography was more than that. They knew the magic of the camera and lighting devices and followed their products to the laboratory, nursing the movie up to the projection room where it told its story on screen. Later, they learned to improvise to find solutions to problems of illumination and lack of proper lighting equipment. They made use of available lighting, using sun reflections and even automobile headlights in place of kleig lights. It became increasingly necessary to compensate for the adverse effects of strong lights, which could melt a hairpin on a star’s coiffure.

 

In the absence of a school for cinematography in the country at the time, most practitioners learned their craft through training and experience. They started out with the camera crew, worked their way up as electricians and gaffers, finally found themselves promoted as assistant or full-fledged camera operators.

 

 

Higino Fallorina, Maria Clara award winner for Baguio Cadets, 1950, and Roberta, 1951, started at Filippine Films in 1935 as a stills photographer. A year later he became assistant cameraman and, in 1937, a full-fledged cameraman with Gamu-gamong Naging Lawin (Moth That Became a Hawk).

 

Tommy Marcelino first worked in the photo department of the Philippines Free Press before becoming an assistant cameraman to his father, Ricardo Marcelino, at Premiere Productions. Both father and son are Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awardees, the elder Ricardo for the Gerardo de Leon film Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960, and the younger Tommy for Paltik (Homemade Gun), 1955.

 

 

Remigio Young, FAMAS awardee for Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, started in the movies as a camera crew member for Jose Nepomuceno. After he became cameraman, he worked with various studios and established his own company for technical services in 1940. He is credited with the camera tricks in the fantasy film Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, and for Rosa del Rosario’s flight over the Bureau of Posts as the wonder woman Darna in the 1951 film Darna by Fernando Poe Sr’s Royal Productions.

 

For years, particularly during the transitional 1950s and 1960s, it was assumed that no artistic film could be made in color. Monochrome was the medium of the “art film,” of neorealism, of the New Wave and film masters from Bergman to Kurosawa. Black and white was the medium of unities and contrasts: the intensity of shadows, patterns of light and darkness, and the varying rough textures of a brightly illuminated or dimly lit scene. Color was used only in dream sequences and big production numbers in musicals where it added to the spectacle.

 

The first attempts of the major studios to shift to color in full-length films are seen in LVN’s Batalyon Trece (13th Battalion), 1949; Premiere’s Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949; and Sampaguita’s The Big Broadcast, 1962. The shift to color called for drastic changes in filming, and cinematographers had to subject themselves to a different orientation. During the early years of color production, the costume movie became very popular. The choice of material increased the cost of production, and emphasized costume and set design. LVN played a leading role in the production of such films as Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950; Rodrigo de Villa, 1952; Dagohoy, 1953; Hawayana (Hawaiian Girl), 1953; Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954; Medalyong Perlas (Pearl Medallion), 1956; and Casa Grande (Mansion), 1958.

 

From the 1930s to the 1950s, when the studio system was in vogue, most cinematographers were part of the regular studio personnel assigned to particular film units. Then, with the studio system broken, cinematographers parceled out their services to film producers and directors with whom they felt artistically compatible. Mike Accion worked with Lamberto V. Avellana in A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, and Gerardo de Leon in Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965. One of de Leon’s early favorites was Emmanuel Rojas, first FAMAS Best Cinematography awardee for his work in Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952. Conrado Baltazar, Lino Brocka’s favorite cinematographer, was awarded the Gawad Urian three years in succession for his work in Brocka’s Gumising Ka… Maruja (Wake Up… Maruja), 1978; Jaguar (Guard), 1979; and Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One), 1980. Baltazar’s creative association with Brocka ended with the cinematographer’s fatal heart attack in 1988, while another latter-day Brocka cinematographer, Pedro Manding Jr, who worked on Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985, and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990, was murdered in 1990.

 

Some cinematographers have created a distinctive style, like Felipe Sacdalan in Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; Ricardo Remias in Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967; Loreto Isleta in Igorot a (Mountain Maiden), 1968; Justo Paulino in Lilet, 1971; Nonong Rasca in Nardong Putik, 1972; Mike de Leon who did Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, before he became a prizewinning director; Romy Vitug, the acknowledged master of controlled brightness and bold color combinations, who did Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins); Fredy Conde in Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Slippers, Neneng), 1977; Sergio Lobo in Ang Lihim ng Guadalupe (The Secret of Guadalupe), 1979; Ver Reyes in Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981; Rody Lacap, who exhibits his originality without contradicting a film’s directorial intentions as seen in Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981; and Batch ’81, 1982; Manolo Abaya, whose intense personalism has become his own trademark as seen in Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Ely Cruz, who has shown considerable mettle in his craft, particularly in the polish and expressiveness of his camerawork as seen in Scorpio Nights, 1985; Johnny Araojo and Romulo Araojo in Bagong Hari (New King), 1986; Ricardo Jacinto in Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988; and Eduardo Jacinto in Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989. Also notable were Philippine cinema’s forays into underwater cinematography as exhibited in Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1935, Dyesebel , 1990, and Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999.

 

Since the advent of cinema, cinematography has continually been refined by its practitioners and has evolved steadily as an art form. Profound technological changes in the craft have occurred since the 1990s with the introduction of digital technology. This new digital cinematography is even credited as one of the main catalysts for the surge of independent or “indie” films in the country, which began in the late 1990s.

 

As early as the mid-1980s, the Japanese electronics giant Sony began introducing high-definition cameras but it was met with little enthusiasm by consumers. However, in 1997, with the introduction of the Sony HDCAM (high-definition camera) recorders and professional video cameras based on CCD (charge-coupled device) technology, the idea, now re-branded as “digital cinematography,” began to attract the attention of filmmakers and cinematographers. Digital cinematography is the process of capturing movement as digital video images, as opposed to the traditional use of film stock. This form of digital capture may occur on video tape, hard disks, flash memory, or other media that can record digital data through the use of a digital video/film camera. Most recently, even mobile phones and tablet PCs (personal computers) equipped with high-definition video cameras are being used to shoot moving images. The images in these high-definition cameras are so sharp that their overall quality already approximates that of celluloid film. Furthermore, digital video cameras are cheaper and therefore more accessible compared to film. The same applies with the ancillary tools that are compatible with digital video, such as nonlinear editing, digital sound design and mixing, and a host of other tools used for filmmaking and animation. Thus, with digital video, the cost of production became significantly lower compared to that of celluloid film.

 

Two of the pioneers of digital film in the Philippines are independent filmmakers Jon Red and Khavn de la Cruz. When digital video was introduced in the mid-1990s, Red was among the first to use digital video for a full-length feature film. Still Lives, 1999, stars indie favorites Joel Torre, Nonie Buencamino, Alan Paule, and Ynez Veneracion. It screened as an official selection in the 2000 Singapore International Film Festival. He followed this up with ASTIGmatism, 2004, featuring a more mainstream cast of actors led by action superstar Robin Padilla, Albert Martinez, Francis Magalona, Jeffrey Quizon, and Alessandra de Rossi. It won the Silver DV (Digital Video) Award at the 28th Hong Kong International Film Festival.

 

On the other hand, de la Cruz, an experimental filmmaker and poet, began making films using a video camera and has never used celluloid film at all. With the arrival of the digital film, he wrote a manifesto titled “Digital Dekalogo: A Manifesto for a Filmless Philippines,” and posted it in his own website. Part of it reads: “Digital film, with its qualities of mobility, flexibility, intimacy, and accessibility, is the apt medium for a Third World country like the Philippines … [T]he digital revolution has reduced the emphasis on technology and has reasserted the centrality of the filmmaker, the importance of the human condition over visual junk food” (de la Cruz 2014).

 

A few pre-digital cinematographers have successfully crossed over to digital filmmaking. Among these award-winning directors of photography is Rody Lacap, well-known for his work with Mike de Leon, Lino Brocka, and Marilou Diaz-Abaya. He used DV technology for digital films like Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011, and Felix Manalo, 2015.

 

Lee Briones-Meily is a director of photography who did Crying Ladies, 2003, and Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000. Neil Daza worked on a number of mainstream movies like Dekada ’70 (The 1970s) and indie films like Bwaya (Crocodile), 2014.

 

With the accessibility of digital cameras, many cinematographers of different generations have come to the fore. Among these cinematographers and their works are Nap Jamir, who worked on Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005; Boy Yñiguez, who worked on Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006; Raymond Red, who worked on Himpapawid (Manila Skies), 2009; Christian Linaban, who worked on Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria (The Dream of Eleuteria), 2010; Arvin Viola, who worked on Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa (The Dance of Two Left Feet), 2011; Lauro Rene Manda, who worked on Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, the End of History), 2013; Pong Ignacio who is known for his work in Tandem and Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015; Odyssey Flores, who is known for Magnifico, 2003, and Serbis (Service), 2008; Carlo Mendoza, who worked on Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story , 2011, and Bwakaw , 2012; and many others.

 

With the advent of the portable camera, new neorealist cinematic styles have emerged and affected the aesthetic delivery of many local films. In “capturing the moment” with a raw flavor, the technique of the “meandering camera” is a staple in many independent films such as Kubrador, Serbis, and Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009.

 

The local cinematographers’ guild, the Filipino Society of Cinematographers, is represented in the Film Academy of the Philippines.  Written by Nick Cruz and Joel David, with notes from Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Elvin Valerio and Clodualdo del Mundo Jr
