text:
Film criticism refers to writings on film that study the products of the Philippine film industry as creative works. These works are analyzed for qualities that validate them as art or for implications on the history and culture of the Filipino people as these are represented in cinema by producers, directors, and/or scriptwriters. On the other hand, film scholarship—a larger term—refers to writings that study various aspects of and matters related to film, including theory, poetics, history and tradition, production, film industry, economics, spectatorship, preservation, and technology. Types of scholarship include film criticism, historical studies, genre studies, representations, biographical studies and portraits, and annotated bibliographies.

 

Film Criticism

Film criticism did not formally manifest itself until the 1960s, or about 40 years after the film industry was born. Previously, what appeared in popular magazines were occasional articles about the state of the industry and the creative personages who inhabited the world of Philippine cinema. A series of articles on Filipino directors by Delfin F. Gamboa appeared monthly, from Dec 1949 to Mar 1952, in the Literary Song-Movie Magazine (LSM). Gamboa wrote on some 16 film directors, delving into their personal backgrounds, shedding light on the preparation for film work of each of his subjects. In the process, attention was focused on the talent and artistry of such directors as Gerardo de Leon, Gregorio Fernandez, Ramon Estella, Lamberto V. Avellana, Manuel Conde, Manuel Silos, and Eddie Romero. In effect, the articles were able to draw for film researchers an early profile of the creative side of the film industry in the decade that was to see the first masterworks of Filipino filmmaking. In the same cast was Vicente R. Generoso’s four-part piece titled “Movies and Public Interest” (LSM, Jan-Apr 1951), which castigated producers whose conservatism had prevented the full realization of the intellectual and artistic potential of Filipino filmmakers. T. D. Agcaoili wrote articles in the same progressive vein.

 

 

The early 1960s marked the appearance for the first time in a learned journal, Philippine Studies (PS), of an article on Philippine movies. Bienvenido Lumbera’s “The Tagalog Film and the Logic of Irony” (PS, Jan 1962) was a survey of a number of films produced in 1960 and 1961, intended to explain why many Tagalog films fail to project a sense of the complexity of their subject matter and theme. As an article published in a university-based journal, Lumbera’s piece reached only a limited circle. It was in the second half of the decade that film criticism was to reach a broad audience when The Manila Chronicle began printing the reviews of Nestor U. Torre, Behn Cervantes, and Ishmael Bernal. A student of Torre, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr was to claim the distinction of being the first reviewer to reach out to the masses when he became a reviewer for the komiks magazine Pilipino Reporter in the early 1970s.

 

The proscription of writing that might be construed as hinting at protest or discontent over martial rule made available in 1972 and later newspaper space that used to be taken up by political news and commentary. Suddenly, film reviews were welcome in the culture section of leading Manila dailies. Critics who made their opinions matter through poised and well-informed views on current film outputs and on problems and prospects of the industry were Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Pio de Castro III, Justino N. Dormiendo, Mario A. Hernando, Manuel S. Pichel, and Nicanor G. Tiongson. With Torre, Cervantes, Lumbera, and del Mundo, they were to serve as the original nucleus of the society of critics that was to call itself Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) in 1976.

 

 

Filipino film criticism may be said to have started out on the back of a tradition best designated as “humanist/literary.” This tradition dominated local film criticism from the postwar years up to the 1970s, with critics schooled in the theories and concepts of literature and theater. Cinema was assessed mainly for its narrative value. Praise was reserved for movies that observed a sense of unity in plot, possessed credible characters, and maintained concern for logic and motivation. Critics sought out films that had themes that spoke the truth about social realities and commented on the human condition.

 

Given the strict criteria of the humanist/literary critics, it was not surprising that only a handful of Filipino films—the best of Gerardo de Leon, Lamberto V. Avellana, Gregorio Fernandez, Manuel Conde, and Manuel Silos—would be acclaimed. In the classic works of these great filmmakers, the critics saw the repudiation of mainstream cinema’s fixation for illogical plots and improbable stories. Ironically, however, the films that they disliked represented the majority of Filipino movies. And despite the disapproving reviews, these movies were the ones patronized by the public, thus signaling that literature as a frame of reference could not account for the aesthetic appeal of mainstream filmmaking.

 

 

Notions of unity and logic are characteristically Western concepts that doubtless cannot be expected in an industry accustomed to shooting films without scripts. Scenes are constantly being improvised so that narrative unity is all but impossible to achieve. Despite the realities in the industry, most critics tended to ignore the pertinence of these matters in assessing a film’s worth or significance. In brief, films were usually judged as finished products rather than as results of a problematic process.

 

The emergence in Europe in the late 1960s of art cinema as opposed to commercial filmmaking left a profound impression on a generation of Filipino students, some of whom went abroad to pursue graduate studies in film. At this time, critics in Europe and the United States had begun to refer to other areas of knowledge in seeking to explain a whole new generation of films that shunned traditional narrative structure in favor of more experimental approaches. The liberating influence of the French New Wave toward the late 1950s had opened new intellectual directions for both filmmakers and critics. Filmmaking was now seen as a vehicle for personal expression, with critics acknowledging directors as authors of their films. Linguistic and art theory began to assume the position of literary criticism as a point of departure for analysis that seeks to explain the aesthetics of film viewing.

 

A neoformalist tradition of reviewing also emerged in the 1990s. Some young critics prescinded from concern with art and relevance toward re-evaluating the notion of form and meaning in cinema. This renewed interest in form allowed mainstream Filipino cinema to be appreciated for its accomplishment in visualization and montage, which had been overlooked for years due to the critical preoccupation with narrative.

 

Cinema studies has become a recognized area in academe. In this area, film theory tries to account for a number of cinematic tendencies by referring to disciplines with parallels in cinematic art. Thus, by the early 1990s, Russian formalism, Freudian psychoanalysis, Marxist criticism, semiology, structuralism, post-structuralism, and feminism had become part of Filipino critical discourse; queer theory followed in the mid-1990s. Two important developments in academe have also changed the landscape of Philippine film studies: postcolonial theory and cultural studies. Postcolonial theory investigates the workings of colonialism and its effects on colonized cultures; thus, it examines the relationship between the colonizing and the colonized cultures, a violent relationship marked by “stories of contestation and … complicity” (Gandhi 1998, 4-5). Cultural studies deals with “literary and non-literary cultural productions and processes, all being counted as ‘texts’ to be decoded,” and treats “cultural productions” like film and advertisement as a signifying practice whose creation, interpretation, and dissemination as “texts” take part in a complex network of power relations and ideological/discursive contestations (Baldick 2008, 76).

 

In this way have Filipino critics of the last decades begun to account for the enduring popularity of komiks-based melodramas, formula action films, and clichéd film farces among the mass audience. Critics nowadays highlight the fact that movies are not isolated phenomena; regardless of their form or quality, they can function as either representation or subversion, or both, of the dominant ideology in Philippine society.

 

Several books and publications gathered a wealth of critical film reviews and considerably augmented the amount of information on Filipino films and filmmakers in the 1980s. The Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson, assembled a selection of the more important essays and reviews by members of the MPP. Readings in Philippine Cinema, 1983, edited by Rafael Ma. Guerrero, is an anthology of 26 articles by film reviewers and feature writers timed to come out during the Manila International Film Festival. Critic Isagani Cruz compiled his reviews and articles in the book Movie Times, 1987, the first ever collection of critical writings by a Filipino film critic. Notes on Philippine Cinema by Emmanuel A. Reyes, 1989, consists of reviews and studies by the young critic who has grappled with the Filipino film as popular culture. In 1983, the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines instituted the Film Ratings Board (FRB), which awarded tax rebates of 50 percent and 25 percent to applicant film productions. The printed organ of the FRB, Filipino Film Review, contains the ratings of the board and views and comments by its members from the time the FRB began to function in January 1983 to the time it folded up in 1987 when the Marcos regime was dismantled.

 

Like the other fields of film scholarship discussed above, film criticism developed further in the 1990s. Critic Joel David published three books in this decade. In The National Pastime: Contemporary Philippine Cinema, 1990, he has put together over 50 reviews that make this collection a comprehensive guide to the films of the 1980s. Fields of Vision: Critical Applications in Recent Philippine Cinema, 1995, complements National Pastime, for its reviews of Filipino films of the 1980s until 1990, but also goes beyond it in its preoccupation with theory and its applicability to local cinema. Wages of Cinema: Film in Philippine Perspective, 1998, the most theoretical among the three, contains extensive discussion of various theories and concepts like structuralism and post-structuralism, auteur criticism, Foucaldian historiography, feminism, psychoanalysis, and postcolonial theory. Emmanuel Reyes’s second book, Malikhaing Pelikula: Mga Sanaysay tungkol sa Pelikulang Pilipino (Creative Film: Essays on Philippine Cinema), 1996, contains essays on art film, an interview with Mike Accion, and Reyes’s own screenplays for Dreaming Filipinos, 1992, and Suwapings, 1994.

 

Rolando B. Tolentino’s two related books deserve mention: National/Transnational: Subject Formations and Media in and on the Philippines, 2001, and Contestable Nation-Space: Cinema, Cultural Politics, and Transnationalism in the Marcos-Brocka Philippines, 2014. While the former is more theoretical (subject formation vis-à-vis transnationalism) and broader in scope (covering more topics like mail-order catalogues and Southeast Asian cinema), the latter sheds light on the complex relationship between cinema and nationhood through Brocka’s films and how they critically engage with Marcosian politics. Jessica Zafra came out with a collection of her film reviews, Twisted Flicks, in 2003. Noel Vera collected his film reviews, essays, and interviews from 1994 to 2004 in Critic after Dark: A Review of Philippine Cinema, 2005. The book contains commentaries on the works of acclaimed directors like Mario O’Hara, Mike de Leon, Tikoy Aguiluz, and Carlos Siguion-Reyna. Another important work on Philippine film criticism is Bienvenido Lumbera’s Re-Viewing Filipino Cinema, 2011. The book gathers together Lumbera’s essays from the 1970s up to the early 21st century on film history and the various aspects of film study (film as commodity, as art, and as social commentary) as well as insightful reviews of now classic Filipino movies.

 

Indeed, from the 1970s onward, film criticism has grown in terms of quality and output. The country can now boast of generations of film critics. In the 1970s, the critics who at one point became members of MPP included Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Pio de Castro III, Justino N. Dormiendo, Mario A. Hernando, Manuel S. Pichel, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Nestor U. Torre, Behn Cervantes, Bienvenido Lumbera, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Isagani R. Cruz, Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo, Agustin L. Sotto, Ricardo Lee, Mario E. Bautista, and Jun Cruz Reyes. In the 1980s, Joel David, Butch Francisco, Tezza O. Parel, Emmanuel A. Reyes, Mauro Feria Tumbocon Jr (also known as Mike Feria), Christian Ma. Guerrero, Alfred A. Yuson, and Alice G. Guillermo joined MPP. In the 1990s, Grace Javier Alfonso, Miguel Q. Rapatan, Rolando B. Tolentino, Paul Daza, Joselito B. Zulueta, and Ellen Paglinauan joined MPP. In the first decade of the 21st century, Benilda S. Santos and Tito Genova Valiente joined MPP.

 

The formation of the MPP was a major step toward the promotion of true artistry in Filipino filmmaking, coming at a time when quality Filipino films were emerging on the scene in the second half of the 1970s. The MPP’s annual Gawad Urian recognized outstanding films, performances, and technical achievements within a given year. It was to become a much-prized award in the industry because it was reputed to be the result of careful deliberation by the members of the group, free from any form of industry pressure or influence.

 

The Film Desk of the Young Critics Circle (YCC) included Patrick Flores, Mike Feria, Ariel Valera, Flaudette May Datuin, Nonoy L. Lauzon, Jerry C. Respeto, Noel Vera, Mozart Pastrano, Melissa Contreras, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Noel D. Ferrer, Eulalio R. Guieb III, Gerard Lico, Neil Martial R. Santillan, Ariel N. Valerio, Galileo S. Zafra, James Raneses, and Clare Salaveria. Later, Jason Pilapil Jacobo, Eloisa May P. Hernandez, and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez became members of YCC. From 2010 to the present, the new YCC members include Jaime Oscar Salazar, Skilty C. Labastilla, JPaul S. Manzanilla, Aristotle J. Atienza, Emerald O. Flaviano, Tessa Maria Guazon, Lisa Ito, and Jema Pamintuan.

 

Manny Espinola started writing film reviews for The Manila Chronicle in the late 1980s. Other critics doing film studies or reviews in the 1990s and 2000s include Anne Frances N. Sangil, J. Neil C. Garcia, Shirley O. Lua, Amor Olaguer-Aljibe, Eileen Meneses, Rito P. Asilo, Philbert Ortiz Dy, and the late Alexis Tioseco (died 2009). Joining the list of critics and film bloggers in this decade are Richard Bolisay, Manuel Pangaruy, Macky Macarayan, Nel Costales, Noli Manaig, Francis Joseph “Oggs” Cruz, Renelson Morelos, Stephanie Mayo, Dodo Dayao, John Tawasil, and Fred Hawson.

 

The rapid growth of multimedia technology, specifically the Internet, has had an impact on film studies in the country and will continue to do so in the years to come. Film buffs can publish their short comments on or reviews of films in their blog, Facebook account, or other social media sites. Filipino moviegoers can visit Pinoy Rebyu: Pinoy Films through Pinoy Lenses—the local equivalent of Rotten Tomatoes—to access reviews of Philippine movies by film enthusiasts and bona fide critics. At present, the websites of MPP and YCC complement their anthologies and contain insightful reviews of Filipino films, thereby promoting the intelligent appreciation of movies in the country. Magazines that have published film reviews and articles include Movement of Mowelfund, Pelikula of the UP College of Mass Communication, and Sinekultura of the University of San Carlos.

 

Film Scholarship

Film studies has continued to grow from the 1990s onward. For film history, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) released a series of monographs on Philippine cinema called Pelikula, which was accompanied by videos on various art forms as part of the series Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art). These included Bienvenido Lumbera’s overview monograph Pelikula: An Essay on Philippine Film, 1989; Agustin L. Sotto’s An Essay on the Philippine Film, 1897-1960, 1992; Lumbera’s An Essay on the Philippine Film, 1961-1992, 1992; and Nestor U. Torre’s An Essay on Philippine Film: Touchstones of Excellence, 1994. Later, these essays formed part of the film volume of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994, which also included entries on forms and types of Philippine cinema, aspects of film production, major works of the Philippine cinema, and biographies of important film artists, technicians, and organizations.

 

One pioneering work in film history and criticism is Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Native Resistance: Philippine Cinema and Colonialism, 1898-1941, 1998, which asserts that “it is possible to see early Filipino cinema not merely as an extension of Hollywood, but as an emergent cultural form and practice that was in itself a critical response to colonialism” (26). Nick Deocampo’s two books may be seen as an extension of or heir to the work of del Mundo. Cine: Spanish Influences on Early Cinema in the Philippines, 2003, is a historical analysis of the origins of cinema in the Philippines and zeroes in on the Spanish influences as gleaned from “a matrix of forces—language, material culture, aesthetics, reception and ideology” (n.p.). His other book, Film: American Influences on Philippine Cinema, 2011, a sequel to Cine, is an examination of how cinema functions as “site in the struggle for a Filipino identity amidst the hegemonic cultural domination of Hispanic and American influences” (n.p.). Jose B. Capino’s Dream Factories of a Former Colony: American Fantasies, Philippine Cinema, 2010, studies “American fantasies and particular workings of decolonization and globalization in a variety of Filipino movies” from 1946 onward (xxxi). All these aforementioned works are grounded in postcolonial theory. Eloisa May P. Hernandez’s Digital Cinema in the Philippines, 1999-2009, 2014, chronicles the history of digital cinema in the country, discusses its production as well as distribution and exhibition, and provides notes on its “aesthetic tendencies” (xiii). Nick Deocampo’s Films from a “Lost” Cinema presents a history of the Cebuano films, using previous studies by Resil Mojares and Erlinda Alburo.

 

The most extensive work on individual canonical directors so far is Nicanor G. Tiongson’s The Cinema of Manuel Conde, 2008, which discusses the life of the filmmaker alongside his works, including the Juan Tamad series and Genghis Khan, 1950, and in light of the development of Philippine cinema and his contributions to its flowering. The book also discusses the director’s last two decades, which were marked by his stint on television and his entry into politics. CCP also published a book in honor of Lino Brocka for his contributions to Philippine cinema, Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times, 1993, edited by Mario A. Hernando. It contains reviews/studies of Brocka’s films as well as essays on the different facets of his life as director for film and for television, as thespian, as writer, and as political advocate. Works on Jose Nepomuceno include Don Jose and the Early Philippine Cinema, 1983, volume 1 of Jose A. Quirino’s Trilogy: A History of Philippine Cinema, and “Jose Nepomuceno: ‘The Father of Philippine Movies,’” 1979, an interview with his son Luis Nepomuceno by Lino Ofero C. Manalo, Alberto Ramos, and Ivan Yaptangco.

 

Other biographical writings on canonical artists include Julianito “Boy” Villasanta’s Tio Ticong: Pelikula at Pulitika ( Vicente Salumbides ), 2002, a collection of essays on the life, works, politics, and contributions of Vicente Salumbides to Philippine cinema; and Daisy Hontiveros Avellana’s The Drama of It: A Life on Film and Theater, 2009, a nonfiction work on the Avellanas, which doubles as Daisy’s memoirs and as Lamberto’s biography. Avellana’s work also features a chronology, filmography, family tree, and pictures. Bibsy M. Carballo’s Filipino Directors Up Close: The Golden Ages of Philippine Cinema 1950-2010, 2010, is a collection of features and biographical sketches on the National Artists for Film Manuel Conde, Lamberto Avellana, Gerardo de Leon, Eddie Romero, Lino Brocka, and Ishmael Bernal as well as notable directors like Mike de Leon, Mario O’Hara, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Raymond Red, Lav Diaz, and Brillante Mendoza. With support from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the Cultural Center of the Philippines and Anvil Publishing jointly produced two volumes of The National Artists of the Philippines, 1998 and 2003, which provide biographical notes, brief but insightful commentaries on the works of the artists, and list of their selected works. Volume 1 (1972-97) features Lamberto V. Avellana, Gerardo de Leon, and Lino Brocka; volume 2 (1998-2003), Ishmael Bernal and Eddie Romero.

 

Short biographical anthologies also emerged in the last 10 years. Khavn de la Cruz, together with Dodo Dayao and Mabie Alagbate, edited the anthology Philippine New Wave: This Is Not a Film Movement, 2010, a collection of interviews and short biographical notes on the independent filmmakers (Philippine New Wave) from Kidlat Tahimik and Adolfo Alix Jr to Lav Diaz and Jeffrey Jeturian to Auraeus Solito and John Torres. 44 Cineastes Filipinos = Filipino Filmmakers = Mga Sineastang Pilipino, 2011, a collaboration between the photographer Oscar Fernandez Orengo and writer Shirley Lua, contains portraits of noted and upcoming Filipino filmmakers by Orengo alongside their short biographies with filmography by Lua. This book was produced by the Instituto Cervantes de Manila.

 

Important biographies of film personalities include the pioneering Doña Sisa ng and Filipino Movies, 1977, edited by Monina A. Mercado; Dolphy , 2009; Mona Lisa : A Portrait, 2013, by Celine Beatrice Fabie; Celso Ad. Castillo : An Autobiography and His Craft, 2013; and Nelson Navarro’s Armida, 2015.

 

An example of a work on film audiences is Alfonso B. Deza’s Mythopoeic Poe: Understanding the Masa as Audience through the Films of Fernando Poe, Jr., 2006. It is a study of spectatorship (the fans of Poe) combined with ample reading of FPJ’s films. It explores “the popularity of FPJ films among the masa” (19) and analyzes his films to shed light on this phenomenon (21).

 

An early study of the short film is Short Film: Emergence of a New Philippine Cinema by Nick Deocampo, 1985. It is an introduction and guide to the appreciation of an alternative to mainstream cinema by an articulate and passionate short-film director and advocate. In terms of genre studies, one highly theoretical book is Bliss Cua Lim’s Translating Time, Cinema, the Fantastic, and Temporal Critique, 2009. Using Bergsonian philosophy and postcolonial theory, this book “argues that fantastic cinema depicts the coexistence of other modes of being alongside and within the modern present, disclosing multiple ‘immiscible temporalities’ that strain against the modern concept of homogeneous time” (n.p.). It includes analysis of local films like Haplos (Caress), 1982; Itim (The Rites of May), 1976, and Aswang, 1992.

 

Full-fledged studies of film icons are pursued in Rolando B. Tolentino’s Richard Gomez at ang Mito ng Pagkalalake, Sharon Cuneta at ang Perpetwal na Birhen at Iba Pang Sanaysay ukol sa Bida sa Pelikula bilang Kultural na Texto (Richard Gomez and the Myth of Maleness, Sharon Cuneta and the Perpetual Virgin and Other Essays on Lead Actors in the Movies as Cultural Texts), 2000, and Cesar Orsal’s Movie Queen: Pagbuo ng Mito ay Kapangyarihang Kultural ng Babae sa Lipunan (Movie Queen: The Creation of Myth and the Cultural Power of Women in Society), 2007. Tolentino’s book studies actors like Richard Gomez, Robin Padilla, and Manilyn Reynes as “cultural texts” and how each represents or embodies aspects of Philippine culture. Orsal’s book explores the myth of the movie queen in Philippine cinema from Susan Roces to Nora Aunor to Judy Ann Santos, and asserts how movie queens help “usher in changes in the representation of women in society” (167, translation by Ronald Baytan). The works of Johven Velasco (Jovenal D. Velasco) were collated by Joel David and posthumously published as Huwaran/Hulmahan Atbp.: The Film Writings of Johven Velasco (Model/Mold, Etc.), 2009. The book contains studies of film actors like Gardo Versoza and Coco Martin, insights on images of men and women in movies, reviews, and commentaries on the state of contemporary Philippine cinema.

 

Two important anthologies that appeared this century are Geopolitics of the Visible: Essays on Philippine Film Cultures, 2000, edited by Rolando B. Tolentino; and A Reader in Philippine Film: History and Criticism (Essays in Honor of Nicanor G. Tiongson), 2014, edited by Jonathan Chua, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, and Rolando B. Tolentino. One of the questions Geopolitics asks is, “How has the visible image been constructed such that it implicates issues of colonial, imperial, and nationalist representations and discourses?” (n.p.). The book includes essays on Nora Aunor (Neferti Tadiar and Patrick D. Flores), Chineseness (Caroline S. Hau), and Ishmael Bernal’s Nunal sa Tubig, 1976 (Eulalio R. Guieb III). A Reader contains new articles on the various aspects of and approaches in contemporary Philippine film studies: adaptation, technical aspects of filmmaking, postcolonial theory, horror films, Derridean hauntology, and independent cinema.

 

Still on anthologies, Kino-Sine: Philippine-German Cinema Relations, 2007, edited by Tilman Baumgärtel and published by Goethe-Institut, explores the fruitful interaction and collaboration between German and Filipino filmmakers from the 1970s onward. Contributors include Kidlat Tahimik, Lav Diaz, Mark Meily, Christoph Janetzko, and Jürgen Brüning. Spirituality and the Filipino Film, 2010, edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, is a collection of essays on Philippine films with faith as the focal point. It contains studies of works of canonical directors like Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Mike de Leon. An anthology on a significant film festival, Making Waves: 10 Years of Cinemalaya, 2014, edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, includes essays examining the various aspects of the festival—its origins, notable films, achievements, audience, and significance in Philippine cinema—together with the list of winners, detailed filmography, audience report, short bio-notes of filmmakers, international awards received by Cinemalaya entries, and full-color plates of the posters of the annual festival and the entries.

 

The MPP’s first anthology was followed by three more volumes, all edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson: The Urian Anthology, 1980-1989: Film Essays and Reviews by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino with a Filmography of Philippine Movies, 1980-1989, 2001; The Urian Anthology, 1990-1999: Articles, Reviews, and Interviews by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino on the Filipino Cinema, 1990-1999, 2010; and The Urian Anthology 2000-2009: The Rise of the Philippine New Wave Indie Film, 2013. To date, the Urian anthologies—four volumes so far—are the most extensive resource material on Philippine movies. Each volume contains essays on different aspects of Philippine cinema, historical essays, critical essays on films representing various genres, and features and interviews on important figures in cinema. It also contains valuable data on Filipino films (e.g., date of release, production details). In effect, the series is an insightful chronicle of Philippine cinema from the Second Golden Age in the 1970s to its drop in the 1990s and to its revival via independent cinema in the new millennium.

 

Another group of critics, Young Critics Circle, has also helped boost film studies and criticism in the country. Like MPP, the Film Desk of the YCC “has committed itself to the discussion of film in the various arenas of academe and media, with the hope of fostering an alternative and emergent articulation of film critical practice …” (YCC 2015). Since its founding in 1990, YCC has produced two anthologies: Sampung Taong Sine (Ten Years of Film), 2002, which contains essays on various aspects of, themes, and achievements in Philippine cinema in the 1990s; a list of winners of the YCC annual awards for film throughout the decade; and reviews of selected films; and Sining ng Sineng Filipino (Art of Filipino Films), 2009, a critical/theoretical book about the nature, form, and aspects of the Filipino film. It also includes reviews of 10 significant Filipino films from 1939 to 2000.

 

For critical notes on film studies in the Philippines, scholars can consult Eileen Ang’s “What Is Philippine Cinema? An Annotated Bibliography of Writings on Film in the Philippines, 1980-2005,” 2005, which summarizes and evaluates the 65 books and other texts included in the study. To date, this is the most extensive bibliographic work on Philippine cinema.

 

It must also be noted that the founding of multidisciplinary journals like Kritika Kultura, Ideya, and Plaridel has helped promote film scholarship in the country. Plaridel of the University of the Philippines Diliman, as of this writing, is one of the few peer-reviewed journals that regularly publish articles on film studies. Ideya: Journal of the Humanities of De La Salle University, now defunct, published a special issue on contemporary Philippine cinema edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr in 2005. The online journal Kritika Kultura of Ateneo de Manila University published a special issue on Ishmael Bernal’s Manila by Night edited by Joel David in 2012.

 

The government is also doing its share in promoting film appreciation and criticism in the country. The National Commission for Culture and the Arts published Sanghaya: Philippine Arts + Culture Yearbook from 2001 to 2005. The CHED (Commission on Higher Education) Memorandum Order (CMO) Number 20, Series 2013, requires an elective in the arts and humanities in the new general education curriculum. One of the government’s projects through the Cultural Center of the Philippines is Cinemalaya Campus, a workshop for students on how to read film and how to use various approaches in the study of films. This activity is held alongside the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

 

Still on pedagogy and film appreciation, Nick Deocampo published Sine Gabay: A Film Study Guide, 2008, which contains valuable data and modules (including objectives, film synopsis, and guide questions) on 100 Filipino films.

 

Many other aspects of Philippine film have yet to be studied and the current milieu of film criticism and scholarship is faced with such challenging task.  Written by Bienvenido Lumbera and Emmanuel A. Reyes,  with notes from Pio de Castro III and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Ronald Baytan

article.value: Film criticism refers to writings on film that study the products of the Philippine film industry as creative works. These works are analyzed for qualities that validate them as art or for implications on the history and culture of the Filipino people as these are represented in cinema by producers, directors, and/or scriptwriters. On the other hand, film scholarship—a larger term—refers to writings that study various aspects of and matters related to film, including theory, poetics, history and tradition, production, film industry, economics, spectatorship, preservation, and technology. Types of scholarship include film criticism, historical studies, genre studies, representations, biographical studies and portraits, and annotated bibliographies.
Film Criticism

Film criticism did not formally manifest itself until the 1960s, or about 40 years after the film industry was born. Previously, what appeared in popular magazines were occasional articles about the state of the industry and the creative personages who inhabited the world of Philippine cinema. A series of articles on Filipino directors by Delfin F. Gamboa appeared monthly, from Dec 1949 to Mar 1952, in the Literary Song-Movie Magazine (LSM). Gamboa wrote on some 16 film directors, delving into their personal backgrounds, shedding light on the preparation for film work of each of his subjects. In the process, attention was focused on the talent and artistry of such directors as Gerardo de Leon, Gregorio Fernandez, Ramon Estella, Lamberto V. Avellana, Manuel Conde, Manuel Silos, and Eddie Romero. In effect, the articles were able to draw for film researchers an early profile of the creative side of the film industry in the decade that was to see the first masterworks of Filipino filmmaking. In the same cast was Vicente R. Generoso’s four-part piece titled “Movies and Public Interest” (LSM, Jan-Apr 1951), which castigated producers whose conservatism had prevented the full realization of the intellectual and artistic potential of Filipino filmmakers. T. D. Agcaoili wrote articles in the same progressive vein.

The early 1960s marked the appearance for the first time in a learned journal, Philippine Studies (PS), of an article on Philippine movies. Bienvenido Lumbera’s “The Tagalog Film and the Logic of Irony” (PS, Jan 1962) was a survey of a number of films produced in 1960 and 1961, intended to explain why many Tagalog films fail to project a sense of the complexity of their subject matter and theme. As an article published in a university-based journal, Lumbera’s piece reached only a limited circle. It was in the second half of the decade that film criticism was to reach a broad audience when The Manila Chronicle began printing the reviews of Nestor U. Torre, Behn Cervantes, and Ishmael Bernal. A student of Torre, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr was to claim the distinction of being the first reviewer to reach out to the masses when he became a reviewer for the komiks magazine Pilipino Reporter in the early 1970s.

The proscription of writing that might be construed as hinting at protest or discontent over martial rule made available in 1972 and later newspaper space that used to be taken up by political news and commentary. Suddenly, film reviews were welcome in the culture section of leading Manila dailies. Critics who made their opinions matter through poised and well-informed views on current film outputs and on problems and prospects of the industry were Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Pio de Castro III, Justino N. Dormiendo, Mario A. Hernando, Manuel S. Pichel, and Nicanor G. Tiongson. With Torre, Cervantes, Lumbera, and del Mundo, they were to serve as the original nucleus of the society of critics that was to call itself Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) in 1976.

Filipino film criticism may be said to have started out on the back of a tradition best designated as “humanist/literary.” This tradition dominated local film criticism from the postwar years up to the 1970s, with critics schooled in the theories and concepts of literature and theater. Cinema was assessed mainly for its narrative value. Praise was reserved for movies that observed a sense of unity in plot, possessed credible characters, and maintained concern for logic and motivation. Critics sought out films that had themes that spoke the truth about social realities and commented on the human condition.

Given the strict criteria of the humanist/literary critics, it was not surprising that only a handful of Filipino films—the best of Gerardo de Leon, Lamberto V. Avellana, Gregorio Fernandez, Manuel Conde, and Manuel Silos—would be acclaimed. In the classic works of these great filmmakers, the critics saw the repudiation of mainstream cinema’s fixation for illogical plots and improbable stories. Ironically, however, the films that they disliked represented the majority of Filipino movies. And despite the disapproving reviews, these movies were the ones patronized by the public, thus signaling that literature as a frame of reference could not account for the aesthetic appeal of mainstream filmmaking.

Notions of unity and logic are characteristically Western concepts that doubtless cannot be expected in an industry accustomed to shooting films without scripts. Scenes are constantly being improvised so that narrative unity is all but impossible to achieve. Despite the realities in the industry, most critics tended to ignore the pertinence of these matters in assessing a film’s worth or significance. In brief, films were usually judged as finished products rather than as results of a problematic process.

The emergence in Europe in the late 1960s of art cinema as opposed to commercial filmmaking left a profound impression on a generation of Filipino students, some of whom went abroad to pursue graduate studies in film. At this time, critics in Europe and the United States had begun to refer to other areas of knowledge in seeking to explain a whole new generation of films that shunned traditional narrative structure in favor of more experimental approaches. The liberating influence of the French New Wave toward the late 1950s had opened new intellectual directions for both filmmakers and critics. Filmmaking was now seen as a vehicle for personal expression, with critics acknowledging directors as authors of their films. Linguistic and art theory began to assume the position of literary criticism as a point of departure for analysis that seeks to explain the aesthetics of film viewing.

A neoformalist tradition of reviewing also emerged in the 1990s. Some young critics prescinded from concern with art and relevance toward re-evaluating the notion of form and meaning in cinema. This renewed interest in form allowed mainstream Filipino cinema to be appreciated for its accomplishment in visualization and montage, which had been overlooked for years due to the critical preoccupation with narrative.

Cinema studies has become a recognized area in academe. In this area, film theory tries to account for a number of cinematic tendencies by referring to disciplines with parallels in cinematic art. Thus, by the early 1990s, Russian formalism, Freudian psychoanalysis, Marxist criticism, semiology, structuralism, post-structuralism, and feminism had become part of Filipino critical discourse; queer theory followed in the mid-1990s. Two important developments in academe have also changed the landscape of Philippine film studies: postcolonial theory and cultural studies. Postcolonial theory investigates the workings of colonialism and its effects on colonized cultures; thus, it examines the relationship between the colonizing and the colonized cultures, a violent relationship marked by “stories of contestation and … complicity” (Gandhi 1998, 4-5). Cultural studies deals with “literary and non-literary cultural productions and processes, all being counted as ‘texts’ to be decoded,” and treats “cultural productions” like film and advertisement as a signifying practice whose creation, interpretation, and dissemination as “texts” take part in a complex network of power relations and ideological/discursive contestations (Baldick 2008, 76).

In this way have Filipino critics of the last decades begun to account for the enduring popularity of komiks-based melodramas, formula action films, and clichéd film farces among the mass audience. Critics nowadays highlight the fact that movies are not isolated phenomena; regardless of their form or quality, they can function as either representation or subversion, or both, of the dominant ideology in Philippine society.

Several books and publications gathered a wealth of critical film reviews and considerably augmented the amount of information on Filipino films and filmmakers in the 1980s. The Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson, assembled a selection of the more important essays and reviews by members of the MPP. Readings in Philippine Cinema, 1983, edited by Rafael Ma. Guerrero, is an anthology of 26 articles by film reviewers and feature writers timed to come out during the Manila International Film Festival. Critic Isagani Cruz compiled his reviews and articles in the book Movie Times, 1987, the first ever collection of critical writings by a Filipino film critic. Notes on Philippine Cinema by Emmanuel A. Reyes, 1989, consists of reviews and studies by the young critic who has grappled with the Filipino film as popular culture. In 1983, the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines instituted the Film Ratings Board (FRB), which awarded tax rebates of 50 percent and 25 percent to applicant film productions. The printed organ of the FRB, Filipino Film Review, contains the ratings of the board and views and comments by its members from the time the FRB began to function in January 1983 to the time it folded up in 1987 when the Marcos regime was dismantled.

Like the other fields of film scholarship discussed above, film criticism developed further in the 1990s. Critic Joel David published three books in this decade. In The National Pastime: Contemporary Philippine Cinema, 1990, he has put together over 50 reviews that make this collection a comprehensive guide to the films of the 1980s. Fields of Vision: Critical Applications in Recent Philippine Cinema, 1995, complements National Pastime, for its reviews of Filipino films of the 1980s until 1990, but also goes beyond it in its preoccupation with theory and its applicability to local cinema. Wages of Cinema: Film in Philippine Perspective, 1998, the most theoretical among the three, contains extensive discussion of various theories and concepts like structuralism and post-structuralism, auteur criticism, Foucaldian historiography, feminism, psychoanalysis, and postcolonial theory. Emmanuel Reyes’s second book, Malikhaing Pelikula: Mga Sanaysay tungkol sa Pelikulang Pilipino (Creative Film: Essays on Philippine Cinema), 1996, contains essays on art film, an interview with Mike Accion, and Reyes’s own screenplays for Dreaming Filipinos, 1992, and Suwapings, 1994.

Rolando B. Tolentino’s two related books deserve mention: National/Transnational: Subject Formations and Media in and on the Philippines, 2001, and Contestable Nation-Space: Cinema, Cultural Politics, and Transnationalism in the Marcos-Brocka Philippines, 2014. While the former is more theoretical (subject formation vis-à-vis transnationalism) and broader in scope (covering more topics like mail-order catalogues and Southeast Asian cinema), the latter sheds light on the complex relationship between cinema and nationhood through Brocka’s films and how they critically engage with Marcosian politics. Jessica Zafra came out with a collection of her film reviews, Twisted Flicks, in 2003. Noel Vera collected his film reviews, essays, and interviews from 1994 to 2004 in Critic after Dark: A Review of Philippine Cinema, 2005. The book contains commentaries on the works of acclaimed directors like Mario O’Hara, Mike de Leon, Tikoy Aguiluz, and Carlos Siguion-Reyna. Another important work on Philippine film criticism is Bienvenido Lumbera’s Re-Viewing Filipino Cinema, 2011. The book gathers together Lumbera’s essays from the 1970s up to the early 21st century on film history and the various aspects of film study (film as commodity, as art, and as social commentary) as well as insightful reviews of now classic Filipino movies.

Indeed, from the 1970s onward, film criticism has grown in terms of quality and output. The country can now boast of generations of film critics. In the 1970s, the critics who at one point became members of MPP included Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Pio de Castro III, Justino N. Dormiendo, Mario A. Hernando, Manuel S. Pichel, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Nestor U. Torre, Behn Cervantes, Bienvenido Lumbera, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Isagani R. Cruz, Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo, Agustin L. Sotto, Ricardo Lee, Mario E. Bautista, and Jun Cruz Reyes. In the 1980s, Joel David, Butch Francisco, Tezza O. Parel, Emmanuel A. Reyes, Mauro Feria Tumbocon Jr (also known as Mike Feria), Christian Ma. Guerrero, Alfred A. Yuson, and Alice G. Guillermo joined MPP. In the 1990s, Grace Javier Alfonso, Miguel Q. Rapatan, Rolando B. Tolentino, Paul Daza, Joselito B. Zulueta, and Ellen Paglinauan joined MPP. In the first decade of the 21st century, Benilda S. Santos and Tito Genova Valiente joined MPP.

The formation of the MPP was a major step toward the promotion of true artistry in Filipino filmmaking, coming at a time when quality Filipino films were emerging on the scene in the second half of the 1970s. The MPP’s annual Gawad Urian recognized outstanding films, performances, and technical achievements within a given year. It was to become a much-prized award in the industry because it was reputed to be the result of careful deliberation by the members of the group, free from any form of industry pressure or influence.

The Film Desk of the Young Critics Circle (YCC) included Patrick Flores, Mike Feria, Ariel Valera, Flaudette May Datuin, Nonoy L. Lauzon, Jerry C. Respeto, Noel Vera, Mozart Pastrano, Melissa Contreras, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Noel D. Ferrer, Eulalio R. Guieb III, Gerard Lico, Neil Martial R. Santillan, Ariel N. Valerio, Galileo S. Zafra, James Raneses, and Clare Salaveria. Later, Jason Pilapil Jacobo, Eloisa May P. Hernandez, and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez became members of YCC. From 2010 to the present, the new YCC members include Jaime Oscar Salazar, Skilty C. Labastilla, JPaul S. Manzanilla, Aristotle J. Atienza, Emerald O. Flaviano, Tessa Maria Guazon, Lisa Ito, and Jema Pamintuan.

Manny Espinola started writing film reviews for The Manila Chronicle in the late 1980s. Other critics doing film studies or reviews in the 1990s and 2000s include Anne Frances N. Sangil, J. Neil C. Garcia, Shirley O. Lua, Amor Olaguer-Aljibe, Eileen Meneses, Rito P. Asilo, Philbert Ortiz Dy, and the late Alexis Tioseco (died 2009). Joining the list of critics and film bloggers in this decade are Richard Bolisay, Manuel Pangaruy, Macky Macarayan, Nel Costales, Noli Manaig, Francis Joseph “Oggs” Cruz, Renelson Morelos, Stephanie Mayo, Dodo Dayao, John Tawasil, and Fred Hawson.

The rapid growth of multimedia technology, specifically the Internet, has had an impact on film studies in the country and will continue to do so in the years to come. Film buffs can publish their short comments on or reviews of films in their blog, Facebook account, or other social media sites. Filipino moviegoers can visit Pinoy Rebyu: Pinoy Films through Pinoy Lenses—the local equivalent of Rotten Tomatoes—to access reviews of Philippine movies by film enthusiasts and bona fide critics. At present, the websites of MPP and YCC complement their anthologies and contain insightful reviews of Filipino films, thereby promoting the intelligent appreciation of movies in the country. Magazines that have published film reviews and articles include Movement of Mowelfund, Pelikula of the UP College of Mass Communication, and Sinekultura of the University of San Carlos.
Film Scholarship

Film studies has continued to grow from the 1990s onward. For film history, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) released a series of monographs on Philippine cinema called Pelikula, which was accompanied by videos on various art forms as part of the series Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art). These included Bienvenido Lumbera’s overview monograph Pelikula: An Essay on Philippine Film, 1989; Agustin L. Sotto’s An Essay on the Philippine Film, 1897-1960, 1992; Lumbera’s An Essay on the Philippine Film, 1961-1992, 1992; and Nestor U. Torre’s An Essay on Philippine Film: Touchstones of Excellence, 1994. Later, these essays formed part of the film volume of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994, which also included entries on forms and types of Philippine cinema, aspects of film production, major works of the Philippine cinema, and biographies of important film artists, technicians, and organizations.

One pioneering work in film history and criticism is Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Native Resistance: Philippine Cinema and Colonialism, 1898-1941, 1998, which asserts that “it is possible to see early Filipino cinema not merely as an extension of Hollywood, but as an emergent cultural form and practice that was in itself a critical response to colonialism” (26). Nick Deocampo’s two books may be seen as an extension of or heir to the work of del Mundo. Cine: Spanish Influences on Early Cinema in the Philippines, 2003, is a historical analysis of the origins of cinema in the Philippines and zeroes in on the Spanish influences as gleaned from “a matrix of forces—language, material culture, aesthetics, reception and ideology” (n.p.). His other book, Film: American Influences on Philippine Cinema, 2011, a sequel to Cine, is an examination of how cinema functions as “site in the struggle for a Filipino identity amidst the hegemonic cultural domination of Hispanic and American influences” (n.p.). Jose B. Capino’s Dream Factories of a Former Colony: American Fantasies, Philippine Cinema, 2010, studies “American fantasies and particular workings of decolonization and globalization in a variety of Filipino movies” from 1946 onward (xxxi). All these aforementioned works are grounded in postcolonial theory. Eloisa May P. Hernandez’s Digital Cinema in the Philippines, 1999-2009, 2014, chronicles the history of digital cinema in the country, discusses its production as well as distribution and exhibition, and provides notes on its “aesthetic tendencies” (xiii). Nick Deocampo’s Films from a “Lost” Cinema presents a history of the Cebuano films, using previous studies by Resil Mojares and Erlinda Alburo.

The most extensive work on individual canonical directors so far is Nicanor G. Tiongson’s The Cinema of Manuel Conde, 2008, which discusses the life of the filmmaker alongside his works, including the Juan Tamad series and Genghis Khan, 1950, and in light of the development of Philippine cinema and his contributions to its flowering. The book also discusses the director’s last two decades, which were marked by his stint on television and his entry into politics. CCP also published a book in honor of Lino Brocka for his contributions to Philippine cinema, Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times, 1993, edited by Mario A. Hernando. It contains reviews/studies of Brocka’s films as well as essays on the different facets of his life as director for film and for television, as thespian, as writer, and as political advocate. Works on Jose Nepomuceno include Don Jose and the Early Philippine Cinema, 1983, volume 1 of Jose A. Quirino’s Trilogy: A History of Philippine Cinema, and “Jose Nepomuceno: ‘The Father of Philippine Movies,’” 1979, an interview with his son Luis Nepomuceno by Lino Ofero C. Manalo, Alberto Ramos, and Ivan Yaptangco.

Other biographical writings on canonical artists include Julianito “Boy” Villasanta’s Tio Ticong: Pelikula at Pulitika ( Vicente Salumbides ), 2002, a collection of essays on the life, works, politics, and contributions of Vicente Salumbides to Philippine cinema; and Daisy Hontiveros Avellana’s The Drama of It: A Life on Film and Theater, 2009, a nonfiction work on the Avellanas, which doubles as Daisy’s memoirs and as Lamberto’s biography. Avellana’s work also features a chronology, filmography, family tree, and pictures. Bibsy M. Carballo’s Filipino Directors Up Close: The Golden Ages of Philippine Cinema 1950-2010, 2010, is a collection of features and biographical sketches on the National Artists for Film Manuel Conde, Lamberto Avellana, Gerardo de Leon, Eddie Romero, Lino Brocka, and Ishmael Bernal as well as notable directors like Mike de Leon, Mario O’Hara, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Raymond Red, Lav Diaz, and Brillante Mendoza. With support from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the Cultural Center of the Philippines and Anvil Publishing jointly produced two volumes of The National Artists of the Philippines, 1998 and 2003, which provide biographical notes, brief but insightful commentaries on the works of the artists, and list of their selected works. Volume 1 (1972-97) features Lamberto V. Avellana, Gerardo de Leon, and Lino Brocka; volume 2 (1998-2003), Ishmael Bernal and Eddie Romero.

Short biographical anthologies also emerged in the last 10 years. Khavn de la Cruz, together with Dodo Dayao and Mabie Alagbate, edited the anthology Philippine New Wave: This Is Not a Film Movement, 2010, a collection of interviews and short biographical notes on the independent filmmakers (Philippine New Wave) from Kidlat Tahimik and Adolfo Alix Jr to Lav Diaz and Jeffrey Jeturian to Auraeus Solito and John Torres. 44 Cineastes Filipinos = Filipino Filmmakers = Mga Sineastang Pilipino, 2011, a collaboration between the photographer Oscar Fernandez Orengo and writer Shirley Lua, contains portraits of noted and upcoming Filipino filmmakers by Orengo alongside their short biographies with filmography by Lua. This book was produced by the Instituto Cervantes de Manila.

Important biographies of film personalities include the pioneering Doña Sisa ng and Filipino Movies, 1977, edited by Monina A. Mercado; Dolphy , 2009; Mona Lisa : A Portrait, 2013, by Celine Beatrice Fabie; Celso Ad. Castillo : An Autobiography and His Craft, 2013; and Nelson Navarro’s Armida, 2015.

An example of a work on film audiences is Alfonso B. Deza’s Mythopoeic Poe: Understanding the Masa as Audience through the Films of Fernando Poe, Jr., 2006. It is a study of spectatorship (the fans of Poe) combined with ample reading of FPJ’s films. It explores “the popularity of FPJ films among the masa” (19) and analyzes his films to shed light on this phenomenon (21).

An early study of the short film is Short Film: Emergence of a New Philippine Cinema by Nick Deocampo, 1985. It is an introduction and guide to the appreciation of an alternative to mainstream cinema by an articulate and passionate short-film director and advocate. In terms of genre studies, one highly theoretical book is Bliss Cua Lim’s Translating Time, Cinema, the Fantastic, and Temporal Critique, 2009. Using Bergsonian philosophy and postcolonial theory, this book “argues that fantastic cinema depicts the coexistence of other modes of being alongside and within the modern present, disclosing multiple ‘immiscible temporalities’ that strain against the modern concept of homogeneous time” (n.p.). It includes analysis of local films like Haplos (Caress), 1982; Itim (The Rites of May), 1976, and Aswang, 1992.

Full-fledged studies of film icons are pursued in Rolando B. Tolentino’s Richard Gomez at ang Mito ng Pagkalalake, Sharon Cuneta at ang Perpetwal na Birhen at Iba Pang Sanaysay ukol sa Bida sa Pelikula bilang Kultural na Texto (Richard Gomez and the Myth of Maleness, Sharon Cuneta and the Perpetual Virgin and Other Essays on Lead Actors in the Movies as Cultural Texts), 2000, and Cesar Orsal’s Movie Queen: Pagbuo ng Mito ay Kapangyarihang Kultural ng Babae sa Lipunan (Movie Queen: The Creation of Myth and the Cultural Power of Women in Society), 2007. Tolentino’s book studies actors like Richard Gomez, Robin Padilla, and Manilyn Reynes as “cultural texts” and how each represents or embodies aspects of Philippine culture. Orsal’s book explores the myth of the movie queen in Philippine cinema from Susan Roces to Nora Aunor to Judy Ann Santos, and asserts how movie queens help “usher in changes in the representation of women in society” (167, translation by Ronald Baytan). The works of Johven Velasco (Jovenal D. Velasco) were collated by Joel David and posthumously published as Huwaran/Hulmahan Atbp.: The Film Writings of Johven Velasco (Model/Mold, Etc.), 2009. The book contains studies of film actors like Gardo Versoza and Coco Martin, insights on images of men and women in movies, reviews, and commentaries on the state of contemporary Philippine cinema.

Two important anthologies that appeared this century are Geopolitics of the Visible: Essays on Philippine Film Cultures, 2000, edited by Rolando B. Tolentino; and A Reader in Philippine Film: History and Criticism (Essays in Honor of Nicanor G. Tiongson), 2014, edited by Jonathan Chua, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, and Rolando B. Tolentino. One of the questions Geopolitics asks is, “How has the visible image been constructed such that it implicates issues of colonial, imperial, and nationalist representations and discourses?” (n.p.). The book includes essays on Nora Aunor (Neferti Tadiar and Patrick D. Flores), Chineseness (Caroline S. Hau), and Ishmael Bernal’s Nunal sa Tubig, 1976 (Eulalio R. Guieb III). A Reader contains new articles on the various aspects of and approaches in contemporary Philippine film studies: adaptation, technical aspects of filmmaking, postcolonial theory, horror films, Derridean hauntology, and independent cinema.

Still on anthologies, Kino-Sine: Philippine-German Cinema Relations, 2007, edited by Tilman Baumgärtel and published by Goethe-Institut, explores the fruitful interaction and collaboration between German and Filipino filmmakers from the 1970s onward. Contributors include Kidlat Tahimik, Lav Diaz, Mark Meily, Christoph Janetzko, and Jürgen Brüning. Spirituality and the Filipino Film, 2010, edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, is a collection of essays on Philippine films with faith as the focal point. It contains studies of works of canonical directors like Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Mike de Leon. An anthology on a significant film festival, Making Waves: 10 Years of Cinemalaya, 2014, edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, includes essays examining the various aspects of the festival—its origins, notable films, achievements, audience, and significance in Philippine cinema—together with the list of winners, detailed filmography, audience report, short bio-notes of filmmakers, international awards received by Cinemalaya entries, and full-color plates of the posters of the annual festival and the entries.

The MPP’s first anthology was followed by three more volumes, all edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson: The Urian Anthology, 1980-1989: Film Essays and Reviews by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino with a Filmography of Philippine Movies, 1980-1989, 2001; The Urian Anthology, 1990-1999: Articles, Reviews, and Interviews by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino on the Filipino Cinema, 1990-1999, 2010; and The Urian Anthology 2000-2009: The Rise of the Philippine New Wave Indie Film, 2013. To date, the Urian anthologies—four volumes so far—are the most extensive resource material on Philippine movies. Each volume contains essays on different aspects of Philippine cinema, historical essays, critical essays on films representing various genres, and features and interviews on important figures in cinema. It also contains valuable data on Filipino films (e.g., date of release, production details). In effect, the series is an insightful chronicle of Philippine cinema from the Second Golden Age in the 1970s to its drop in the 1990s and to its revival via independent cinema in the new millennium.

Another group of critics, Young Critics Circle, has also helped boost film studies and criticism in the country. Like MPP, the Film Desk of the YCC “has committed itself to the discussion of film in the various arenas of academe and media, with the hope of fostering an alternative and emergent articulation of film critical practice …” (YCC 2015). Since its founding in 1990, YCC has produced two anthologies: Sampung Taong Sine (Ten Years of Film), 2002, which contains essays on various aspects of, themes, and achievements in Philippine cinema in the 1990s; a list of winners of the YCC annual awards for film throughout the decade; and reviews of selected films; and Sining ng Sineng Filipino (Art of Filipino Films), 2009, a critical/theoretical book about the nature, form, and aspects of the Filipino film. It also includes reviews of 10 significant Filipino films from 1939 to 2000.

For critical notes on film studies in the Philippines, scholars can consult Eileen Ang’s “What Is Philippine Cinema? An Annotated Bibliography of Writings on Film in the Philippines, 1980-2005,” 2005, which summarizes and evaluates the 65 books and other texts included in the study. To date, this is the most extensive bibliographic work on Philippine cinema.

It must also be noted that the founding of multidisciplinary journals like Kritika Kultura, Ideya, and Plaridel has helped promote film scholarship in the country. Plaridel of the University of the Philippines Diliman, as of this writing, is one of the few peer-reviewed journals that regularly publish articles on film studies. Ideya: Journal of the Humanities of De La Salle University, now defunct, published a special issue on contemporary Philippine cinema edited by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr in 2005. The online journal Kritika Kultura of Ateneo de Manila University published a special issue on Ishmael Bernal’s Manila by Night edited by Joel David in 2012.

The government is also doing its share in promoting film appreciation and criticism in the country. The National Commission for Culture and the Arts published Sanghaya: Philippine Arts + Culture Yearbook from 2001 to 2005. The CHED (Commission on Higher Education) Memorandum Order (CMO) Number 20, Series 2013, requires an elective in the arts and humanities in the new general education curriculum. One of the government’s projects through the Cultural Center of the Philippines is Cinemalaya Campus, a workshop for students on how to read film and how to use various approaches in the study of films. This activity is held alongside the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

Still on pedagogy and film appreciation, Nick Deocampo published Sine Gabay: A Film Study Guide, 2008, which contains valuable data and modules (including objectives, film synopsis, and guide questions) on 100 Filipino films.

Many other aspects of Philippine film have yet to be studied and the current milieu of film criticism and scholarship is faced with such challenging task.  Bienvenido Lumbera and Emmanuel A. Reyes,  with notes from Pio de Castro III and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Ronald Baytan

Sections

 

Preproduction
Principal Photography
Postproduction
The Future

 

Digital filmmaking is filmmaking that uses methodologies that combine certain aspects of traditional filmmaking with “new capabilities that have come about through the integration of computers, digital image manipulation, disk recording, and networking” (Ohanian and Phillips 2000, 3-4, 18).

 

Filmmaking used to be a linear process, with tasks and functions dependent on the completion of previous tasks, including—in sequence—preproduction, principal photography, and postproduction. While these three functions still apply, digital technologies have allowed these tasks to happen simultaneously due to the speed, efficiency, and portability of digital data and technologies (Ohanian and Phillips 2000, 22).

 

 

 

Preproduction

Digital technology made its entry into filmmaking through preproduction. The earliest forms of word processing software and platforms enabled screenwriters to turn story lines into scripts quickly and efficiently. Digital files allowed for multiple versions and easily integrated revisions; printouts and copies could also be made quickly and distributed on set to actors or to crew members. Spreadsheets, on the other hand, increased the ability of production managers and producers to manage resources, time, schedules, and material with greater accuracy and efficiency.

 

Current technologies have since led to dedicated preproduction software and systems designed for the film and media industries. Scriptwriting software, for instance, integrates the functions of a word processor while simultaneously incorporating specialized formatting and indexing functions. Softwares, like Celtx, Movie Magic, and Chimpanzee, take the screenwriting function further by integrating production management functionality to create budgets, storyboards, schedules, and shot lists based on the screenplay written in the software.

 

 

One aspect of the filmmaking preproduction process that has grown significantly through digital technology is pre-visualization. Pre-visualization, aka “previz,” is a cinematic process used by filmmakers to preview a film well in advance of principal photography (Olsen 2010). A previz is a rough preview of the film before it is actually shot or produced. The most basic and simplest previz technique is the storyboard, but advanced previz goes far beyond the traditional storyboard; it covers a range that may include low-resolution edits, animated storyboards to pre-recorded dialogue, or “one-light” color correction to actual shot footage. The relatively low cost and speed of digital techniques now allow filmmakers to bring film ideas to life prior to committing money and resources into the main production (Ferster 1998).

 

It is now common for filmmakers to shoot low-resolution versions of a scene to determine if a camera technique or style will work. A composer can add a study of the music while costume designers can see how movements will be affected by the actors’ clothing. Cinematographers can collaborate and brainstorm on lighting design, while visual effects artists can begin the design process for editing later on.

 

 

 

Principal Photography

The most significant developments in digital filmmaking have been in the realm of imaging (cameras) and recording media. Manufacturers like Sony, Panasonic, Arri, and Red have been at the forefront of defining the cutting edge of digital imaging technology for film. Further developments in imaging chip technology—at the heart of digital cameras—have also brought about cheaper, lower-end, but no less capable, cameras that have become accessible to professional consumers (“prosumers”), small production houses, and independent filmmakers. Canon C-Series and Blackmagic Cinema Cameras are professional-grade cameras at the fraction of the cost of an Arri or Red system; while Canon, Nikon, and Sony digital single-lens reflex (DSLR) cameras—the same ones used in photography—have introduced more robust video capabilities. DSLRs, in particular, have revolutionized and democratized digital filmmaking with its low cost, simple technology, familiar form factor, and high photographic quality, opening up digital filmmaking to small independent producers, hobbyists, enthusiastic amateurs, and students.

 

Coupled with innovations in imaging chips and camera technology are advances in recording and storage media. Early digital data used to be recorded on magnetic tape (analog) as digital data. The evolution of faster hard drives gave birth to tape-less digital video; with the advent of solid state storage formats, data transfer and recording rates have been able to keep up with the increasing resolution of cameras and resulting increase in data size. Today, solid-state drives can record hours of high-definition video data in packages no larger than a deck of playing cards, with consumer and prosumer cameras recording on high-capacity memory cards the size of a postage stamp (SD card) or human thumbnail (micro SD). The economic considerations are significant as well—digital storage is cheaper than 16 mm or 35 mm film stock and is reusable (Fair 2006).

 

The combination of developments in camera and storage technology has brought about the evolution of a new key member in principal photography, the digital imaging technician (DIT). The primary role of the DIT is to act as data wrangler for the production—securing, logging, and making multiple backups of raw data footage from the cameras. Beyond making backups, though, the DIT is a crucial liaison between the camera department and postproduction. The DIT makes adjustments to camera and footage settings, such as aperture, ISO, or aspect ratio, based on the cinematographer’s visual design and the director’s final shot objective. The DIT must also coordinate footage with postproduction in anticipation of color-grading plans, visual effects, or workflow processes (Asbury 2013).

 

High-grade professional cameras, such as the Red, Arri, Canon C-Series, and Blackmagic Cinema Camera, record raw, untreated image data intended for color correction in postproduction; the result is usually a flat, washed-out image straight from the camera. On set, the DIT may provide a “one-light” color correction for the cinematographer, director, and, in the case of advertising or commercial projects, the client to simulate how the image might look like after postproduction (Asbury 2013). In a sense, the DIT provides a previsualization of the postproduction color correction process while the footage is being shot to allow for corrections or adjustments before the footage gets sent to the studio for postproduction.

 

Postproduction

Digital filmmaking came to prominence in postproduction. Nonlinear editing technology was what pushed postproduction to truly embrace digital. Nonlinear editing allows the editor to create nondestructive timelines of sequences and scenes without needing to follow a chronological or sequential methodology (Fair 2006). Nonlinear systems allow edits to be cut and re-cut, with multiple versions being saved or tried out, without any damage to the original footage. Developments in the software then allowed for easy compositing of additional elements, such as effects layers, text, and computer-generated imagery (CGI). Synthespians—“synthetic thespians”—or computer-generated actors and characters are now seamlessly integrated with virtual sets into the scene with real actors, with the audience hard-pressed to tell the real from computer-generated images (Ohanian and Phillips 2000).

 

The power of digital postproduction technologies has also boosted the art of color correction and color grading. “Color correction” must be differentiated from “color grading.” In color correction, adjustments are made to affect contrast, color temperature, or color tone. Color grading is introducing changes to create a “look” for the film or a particular scene within it. These changes are localized, and color adjustments may vary across shots or even within a shot itself (Paramour Productions, n.d.; Gates 2013).

 

Color grading is achieved by manipulating ranges, tolerances, and thresholds of a digital image’s red, green, and blue pixel channels. Other parameters a colorist can manipulate include the hue, saturation, and brightness, as well as contrast, highlights, midtones, and shadows. Utilizing layers and masking functions in color grading software, a colorist is able to manipulate specific areas of a shot to change or shift its visual mood, design, or aesthetic (Gates 2013). Color-graded footage is then sent back to the editor for finalization in the edit and eventual production of the release copy.

 

The Future

Digital technologies have changed the world, and the world of cinema and filmmaking most significantly. Creative tools that were once impossible or too expensive have become commonplace and more accessible to the average artist, making available to consumers a wider and more varied range of products, and opening up the industry to new paradigms of business, creativity, and market forces. However, beyond the dazzle and magic of digital technologies, at the core of film and filmmaking will always be a story well told.  Written by Jose Antonio Garcia

The relatively low cost and speed of digital techniques now allow filmmakers to bring film ideas to life prior to committing money and resources into the main production (Ferster 1998).

It is now common for filmmakers to shoot low-resolution versions of a scene to determine if a camera technique or style will work. A composer can add a study of the music while costume designers can see how movements will be affected by the actors’ clothing. Cinematographers can collaborate and brainstorm on lighting design, while visual effects artists can begin the design process for editing later on.
Principal Photography

The most significant developments in digital filmmaking have been in the realm of imaging (cameras) and recording media. Manufacturers like Sony, Panasonic, Arri, and Red have been at the forefront of defining the cutting edge of digital imaging technology for film. Further developments in imaging chip technology—at the heart of digital cameras—have also brought about cheaper, lower-end, but no less capable, cameras that have become accessible to professional consumers (“prosumers”), small production houses, and independent filmmakers. Canon C-Series and Blackmagic Cinema Cameras are professional-grade cameras at the fraction of the cost of an Arri or Red system; while Canon, Nikon, and Sony digital single-lens reflex (DSLR) cameras—the same ones used in photography—have introduced more robust video capabilities. DSLRs, in particular, have revolutionized and democratized digital filmmaking with its low cost, simple technology, familiar form factor, and high photographic quality, opening up digital filmmaking to small independent producers, hobbyists, enthusiastic amateurs, and students.

Coupled with innovations in imaging chips and camera technology are advances in recording and storage media. Early digital data used to be recorded on magnetic tape (analog) as digital data. The evolution of faster hard drives gave birth to tape-less digital video; with the advent of solid state storage formats, data transfer and recording rates have been able to keep up with the increasing resolution of cameras and resulting increase in data size. Today, solid-state drives can record hours of high-definition video data in packages no larger than a deck of playing cards, with consumer and prosumer cameras recording on high-capacity memory cards the size of a postage stamp (SD card) or human thumbnail (micro SD). The economic considerations are significant as well—digital storage is cheaper than 16 mm or 35 mm film stock and is reusable (Fair 2006).

The combination of developments in camera and storage technology has brought about the evolution of a new key member in principal photography, the digital imaging technician (DIT). The primary role of the DIT is to act as data wrangler for the production—securing, logging, and making multiple backups of raw data footage from the cameras. Beyond making backups, though, the DIT is a crucial liaison between the camera department and postproduction. The DIT makes adjustments to camera and footage settings, such as aperture, ISO, or aspect ratio, based on the cinematographer’s visual design and the director’s final shot objective. The DIT must also coordinate footage with postproduction in anticipation of color-grading plans, visual effects, or workflow processes (Asbury 2013).

High-grade professional cameras, such as the Red, Arri, Canon C-Series, and Blackmagic Cinema Camera, record raw, untreated image data intended for color correction in postproduction; the result is usually a flat, washed-out image straight from the camera. On set, the DIT may provide a “one-light” color correction for the cinematographer, director, and, in the case of advertising or commercial projects, the client to simulate how the image might look like after postproduction (Asbury 2013). In a sense, the DIT provides a previsualization of the postproduction color correction process while the footage is being shot to allow for corrections or adjustments before the footage gets sent to the studio for postproduction.
Postproduction

Digital filmmaking came to prominence in postproduction. Nonlinear editing technology was what pushed postproduction to truly embrace digital. Nonlinear editing allows the editor to create nondestructive timelines of sequences and scenes without needing to follow a chronological or sequential methodology (Fair 2006). Nonlinear systems allow edits to be cut and re-cut, with multiple versions being saved or tried out, without any damage to the original footage. Developments in the software then allowed for easy compositing of additional elements, such as effects layers, text, and computer-generated imagery (CGI). Synthespians—“synthetic thespians”—or computer-generated actors and characters are now seamlessly integrated with virtual sets into the scene with real actors, with the audience hard-pressed to tell the real from computer-generated images (Ohanian and Phillips 2000).

The power of digital postproduction technologies has also boosted the art of color correction and color grading. “Color correction” must be differentiated from “color grading.” In color correction, adjustments are made to affect contrast, color temperature, or color tone. Color grading is introducing changes to create a “look” for the film or a particular scene within it. These changes are localized, and color adjustments may vary across shots or even within a shot itself (Paramour Productions, n.d.; Gates 2013).

Color grading is achieved by manipulating ranges, tolerances, and thresholds of a digital image’s red, green, and blue pixel channels. Other parameters a colorist can manipulate include the hue, saturation, and brightness, as well as contrast, highlights, midtones, and shadows. Utilizing layers and masking functions in color grading software, a colorist is able to manipulate specific areas of a shot to change or shift its visual mood, design, or aesthetic (Gates 2013). Color-graded footage is then sent back to the editor for finalization in the edit and eventual production of the release copy.
The Future

Digital technologies have changed the world, and the world of cinema and filmmaking most significantly. Creative tools that were once impossible or too expensive have become commonplace and more accessible to the average artist, making available to consumers a wider and more varied range of products, and opening up the industry to new paradigms of business, creativity, and market forces. However, beyond the dazzle and magic of digital technologies, at the core of film and filmmaking will always be a story well told.
Written by Jose Antonio Garcia
