text:
As the unifying force in the making of a film, the director controls the style, content, and overall form of the movie.

 

In the Philippines, the director usually acquires his skills through apprenticeship and actual participation in the filmmaking process, and/or through formal schooling. Reading film books may help, but the best training is still the hands-on experience of working in the industry itself. Assistant directors, actors, cinematographers, scriptwriters, editors, and set designers may eventually become directors.

 

The principal work of the director is to realize the vision that will bind the elements of film in one work of art. The director literally leads, guiding his screenwriter, cinematographer, actors, production designer, editor, musical director, sound engineer, and even his special effects supervisor to bring together what he envisions as his film. Therefore, the effectiveness of a director is not only measured by his technical skills or the significance of what he has to say. A good director is one who manages to draw out the best from everyone who forms part of his creative and technical team.

 

 

Once the script is ready to be translated into a motion picture, it is the director who assumes control over the film’s form and content. Occasionally, established scriptwriters like Ricky Lee and Jose Lacaba may insist that any essential changes in the script should be made by them or, at least, should merit their approval. In general, though, once the script is turned in, the director takes over and is accountable to the producer for the final product.

 

Once the director is of the opinion that a script is aesthetically and technically consistent with the overall concept of the film, the director, given the freedom he needs, then chooses the people who will assist in the actual production. These include the cinematographer who plays a crucial role in fleshing out the images and, more importantly, the vision of the filmmaker.

 

 

A good example of a perfect choice of cinematographer may be seen in Lino Brocka’ s Maynila: Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, which was photographed by Mike de Leon. Brocka wanted to depict a bleak and cruel city where the principal characters must struggle for physical and emotional liberation. Maynila effectively projected an atmosphere devoid of warmth, employing a kind of photography that was evocative of cold impersonalism. The director-cinematographer relationship in Maynila resulted in the realization of the directorial vision.

 

The contemporary director usually casts the film, selecting actors who will best respond to the director’s work ethos, regardless of their own styles or wishes. Most often, however, it is the producer, especially in the case of the major studios, who has a hand in the final casting.

 

The relationship between actor and director is highly complicated and varies greatly from director to director. Five general styles may be identified, which may in turn be employed in varying ways. First, directors may work closely with the actors, instructing them directly as to movement, facial expressions, inner feelings, and delivery of dialogue without necessarily explaining the purpose of the direction. Second, directors may discuss the character and ideas of the film so that the actors will have a more definite concept of the role assigned to them. In effect, a kind of creative collaboration between director and actor takes place, a collaboration that will enable the actor to understand the director’s interpretation of the film and its characters. Third, directors may leave the actors to their own devices, as the directors concentrate their efforts on the technical aspects of filmmaking. Fourth, directors may require actors to immerse themselves in the places where their characters come from. Last, directors may depend on intuition and improvisation, often waiting for the moment of inspiration.

 

Directors also involve themselves with the work of editors. They usually view the rushes with the editor and set the mood and tone that will guide the editing process. Having already influenced the editing by selecting only certain takes of each scene to be printed, directors move into the editing room and, in effect, control the creative destiny of the film. If the rough cut or first draft of the film does not match the directors’ image, it will be recut until it conforms to that image. Contemporary filmmakers recreate a film in the editing room as they created it on the set, applying all the necessary cures whenever possible. The editors, in this regard, make a major contribution to the film; but from start to finish, the directors remain the principal filmmakers.

 

During the earliest years of filmmaking in this country, the producer also assumed the role of the director. Such was the case of Jose Nepomuceno, acknowledged “father of Philippine movies.” His film was a personal investment; therefore, as director he exercised total control of the creative development and production.

 

But as moviemaking became a much larger industry, studios began to rise and the capability of making movies depended on who had the capital, the greater amount of money to invest and the business plan to sustain not one but a number of projects per year. In the 1930s, with the rise of large film studios like Filippine Films, Excelsior, Sampaguita, and LVN, the role of the director was subsumed under a compartmentalized and more specialized system. The studios hired, maintained, and supervised the actors, writers, editors, and directors. The job of most directors during this period was simply to translate the studio’s scripts into celluloid. Although a number of directors like Carlos Vander Tolosa, Ramon Estella, and Gregorio Fernandez were allowed more creative latitude than a host of others, the director, as a rule, did not have control over the entire film, which was generally the producer’s domain.

 

In the 1950s, some directors were able to assert control over the process of making specific films. They worked closely with the scriptwriter and, in some cases, either collaborated with the scriptwriter or wrote the scripts themselves. Their control of every element and aspect of the filmmaking process resulted in films that displayed their distinctive style. Thus, the directorial genius of Gerardo de Leon, Lamberto Avellana, Manuel Silos, and Manuel Conde.

 

In the 1960s to the 1980s, the ultimate success of a film was usually attributed to an actor. Fernando Poe Jr, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, and Sharon Cuneta were enthroned as the biggest stars in the industry, yet few people know that the creative force of Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, Celso Ad. Castillo, Mike de Leon, and of such latter-day directors as Laurice Guillen and Marilou Diaz-Abaya was behind the best achievements in Philippine cinema. But there is a growing awareness on the part of more informed and discerning moviegoers of the legitimate and central role of the director in filmmaking. In 1981, film directors gained more recognition with the organization of the Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino under the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP). Later, however, many members broke away from the FAP and established themselves as the Directors’ Guild of the Philippines Inc in 2001. Notable directors of the 1980s and 1990s are Chito Roño, Joel Lamangan, Jose Javier Reyes, Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Peque Gallaga, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Mario O’Hara, Mel Chionglo, and Gil Portes.

 

The turn of the century brought great changes in the landscape of Philippine cinema. By the early 1990s, multimedia companies began to rise and the film studios needed to be quick in adjusting to the business atmosphere of the time. When TV networks set up their own moviemaking companies, film directors now came from the pool of talents who had proven their mettle in handling television shows. These are the directors who helm nightly soap operas or dramatic anthologies. Although some still come from the ranks of filmmaking (Olive Lamasan, Rory Quintos, Jerry Lopez Sineneng), the new breed of network-trained film directors actually start working in television shows as directors of continuing series.

 

In the 2000s, working in commercial or mainstream filmmaking has become a corporate procedure. Whereas before studios were owned by families where there is one executive producer, now making films worth over 20 million pesos requires an entourage of creative executives, salespersons, and merchandisers who must all pitch in to bring form to a work. This is to ensure the maximum possibility for a return of investment. The director becomes part of this system where his creativity is also shaped by what is deemed by the businessmen as something that they can sell to their target market. The director becomes answerable to an executive or a committee who becomes the voice of the producer in determining the direction they want the movie to follow.

 

The arrival of inexpensive digital video technology in 1999 freed filmmakers from the dictates of commercial producers, allowing them to pursue their own artistic vision for their films. With this technology and the support of independent film festivals like Cinemalaya and Cinema One Originals, new directors emerged with their fresh voices, offering alternative forms of cinematic experience to the young and enthusiastic audiences. Among the younger roster of directors, particularly from the independent film industry, are Brillante Mendoza, Lav Diaz, Raymond Red, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Mes de Guzman, Auraeus Solito, Alvin Yapan, Adolfo Alix Jr, and Jerrold Tarog.  Written by Nick Cruz and Justino Dormiendo, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Jose Javier Reyes, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
Distribution is the process of bringing the film to its target audience. It is a critical point in the revenue-generating stream of film production. Booking and exhibition are the major stages of this process. Booking means getting the venues and the most profitable playdates for film exhibition ahead of time. Exhibition is the actual showing or presentation of the film to its audience. The theater owner, operator, or manager is also called the exhibitor of the film.

 

Films were first exhibited in Manila during the last years of Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. The earliest account was in a Spanish-language newspaper, announcing an exhibition titled Espectaculo Cientifico (Science Show), comprising seven titles, and shown in a converted warehouse on Escolta, Manila. The event, probably the first clear indication of a local film screening, was held on the first day of 1897, a little over a year since the first public showing of Cinématographe films by the Lumière brothers in Paris.

 

 

Early accounts also point to a Frenchman named Rebarber who, with Eduardo Munarriz and Jose Hernandez as capitalists and Jose Martin as projectionist, took over an old warehouse at the back of Quiapo Church on Evangelista Street and converted it into a cinema, Cine Orpheum, in 1904. Another warehouse on Ongpin Street near Misericordia Street in Santa Cruz, Manila, was made into a movie house called Cine Cervantes. In 1907, a row of accesoria (apartments) along Legarda Street in Sampaloc, Manila, owned by Dr Valentin Guidote (whose daughter, Raymunda Guidote, later appeared in a silent film, Fate or Consequence, 1926), was transformed into Cine Moderno. The next year, 1908, saw the construction of Ideal Theater on Rizal Avenue.

 

The first Filipino feature films that were shown at the Grand Opera House and at the Empire and Majestic theaters were relatively short. Albert Yearsley’s El Fusilamiento de Dr. Jose Rizal (The Execution of Dr Jose Rizal), 1912, had a screening time of only 20 minutes, while Edward Gross’s La Vida de Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal), 1912, came as the standard four-reeler of approximately 5,000 feet with a screening time of almost one hour (one reel of film took about 12 minutes to run in the silent movie projector).

 

 

With the coming of talking pictures, feature films increased in length. The standard was one-and-a-half to two hours of screening time. Films came in 2,000-foot reels and were shuttled among nearby theaters during multiple first-run exhibitions in Metro Manila. The practice was called lagare—literally, “sawing.” This practice guaranteed the simultaneous exhibition of one film in several theaters using only one available print copy. While the lagare system was accepted in the city so as to cut on costs (producers found it too expensive to provide each theater with its own print copy), the unauthorized exhibition system in the provinces known as bisikleta (literally, “bicycle,” referring to the vehicle that was used for transporting the film to a venue not contracted by the producer) was condemned by film distributors and film producers alike. Film checkers who were caught conspiring with unscrupulous exhibitors in the bisikleta system were heavily penalized if not fired outright, while erring theaters were boycotted and their supply of films cut off for a certain period by both the producers’ associations (the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association and the Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines) and the exhibitors’ associations (the Greater Manila Theaters Association and the Metro Manila Theaters Association).

 

In the past, block booking required an exhibitor to take the full package of films or receive none of a studio’s offerings. In order to buy a studio’s products, the exhibitor was asked to purchase—sight unseen—a full year’s program of film features. This resulted in a kind of assembly-line production of films because producers were forced to provide films to the exhibitor on time at all costs. Block booking thrived only in a setup where there was an assured supply of films for a corresponding circuit or chain of exhibitors. This practice was prevalent in the 1950s when the Big Four studios (Sampaguita, LVN, Premiere, Lebran) were bound by block booking arrangements made with the exhibitors of Life and Dalisay theaters.

 

 

Mayor Antonio Villegas, the acknowledged father of local film festivals, contributed to the breakthrough of Tagalog movies into the “English theaters” in downtown Manila, particularly Avenida Rizal. At that time, the only movie houses showing Tagalog films on a regular first-run basis were Life and Dalisay theaters and, occasionally, Center Theater in Quiapo. All other first-run theaters were then tied up to the exhibition of American films: the Ideal Theater for MGM, Universal for Udia Films, Avenue for Warner Bros., Ever for 20th Century Fox, State for Columbia Pictures, and so on. Mayor Villegas initiated the annual Manila Film Festival in 1966 and this festival popularized Tagalog films, thus convincing theater owners that these were marketable and profitable. In 1975, the filmfest was expanded to include theaters and areas outside Manila and was renamed Metropolitan Film Festival, which became Metro Manila Film Festival in 1977.

 

When Tagalog movies were able to penetrate the movie houses showing only films in English, producers who made only a few good pictures a year made the best of the situation through lockout booking. Under this system, a producer books a film for a certain period. For a motion picture with famous stars, a producer would be assured two weeks of continuous booking while an ordinary movie was given only one week or less. Regardless of how the movie fared at the box office (an exhibition term derived from the box-shaped booth where moviegoers paid to get their tickets), the exhibition went on uninterrupted.

 

The holdover system, on the other hand, did not guarantee producers a definite period of showing for their films. Continued showing of a film was guaranteed only for as long as the film reached the holdover figure. This was the minimum amount of daily gross receipts set by the exhibitor as a “break-even” point. When the receipts fell below this figure, the film was withdrawn from exhibition.

 

Gross receipts at the box office were shared by exhibitor and producer after taxes were paid to the government. There were two ways of sharing the proceeds: through the sliding scale system or the fixed percentage system. In the sliding scale system, a producer shared, net of tax, between 40 percent and 65 percent of the gross depending on the income at the box office—the bigger the receipts, the higher the rate for the producer. Under the fixed percentage system, theater owners and producers agreed on a fixed ratio (50:50, 55:45, or 60:40) regardless of the amount received from the box office. A daily box-office report on the hourly income from ticket sales was filled out and signed by the film checker or the representative of the film producer, and confirmed by the theater management. This report indicated how income was to be shared between the film owner and the exhibitor, as well as the amount of taxes to be paid to the government.

 

Film exhibition in the Philippines follows a course, a series of events designed to draw the full patronage of particular groups of moviegoers. The ehibition of a good film usually starts with a good press preview, which has the twofold purpose of marketing the film as well as testing the response of critics, evaluators, movie journalists, and other influential persons who are in a position to spread the good word about the film. Next is the premiere night, when the film officially debuts to a prominent paying public, usually at higher prices. Sometimes this is sponsored by entities, such as the Red Cross or the Catholic Women’s League, which are themselves the beneficiaries of tax proceeds from the film. This is followed by the first-run exhibition of the film, still at premium theaters, though not as large and elegant as the “film palaces” reserved for premieres. Tickets for regular first-run screenings are more affordable than premiere tickets. In recent years, the trend for first-run exhibition has shifted from the big theaters or movie houses to the multicinema complexes in supermarket centers and shopping malls like the Ayala Malls Cinemas and the SM Cinemas in Metro Manila. After some time has elapsed, the film is exhibited on its second-run engagement, this time in a larger number of theaters, accompanied by another picture as a double feature. Lastly, there are the provincial screenings, with the film prints circulating all over the country, from the cities to the towns and municipalities. Some of these provincial exhibitions are held simultaneously on a first-run basis with theater openings in Metro Manila. Occasionally, there are “roadshow” engagements, which precede the first-run regular showings at prices higher than first-run.

 

Other more specialized forms of exhibition are the open-air screenings occasionally held at the Rizal Park in Manila and which in rural areas without theaters are usually done in line with product promotions or political campaigns; campus previews in university auditoriums, which during the 1970s succeeded in promoting mainstream films regarded as artistic but “uncommercial”; the free-admission screenings of retrospectives, embassy films, and alternative (independent) cinema at the Cultural Center of the Philippines; the school-based alternative and experimental film screenings at the UP Film Center, De La Salle University, and other venues, which expose students and faculty to other possibilities in film expression and messages; the screenings at the Manila Film Center, formerly run by the defunct Experimental Cinema of the Philippines, which in the 1980s sparked controversy because it was exempted from censorship and taxation; and the occasional carnival sideshows, featuring novelty presentations such as the 180-degree widescreen shows.

 

Up to the 1990s, the distribution of movies was simple and straightforward as it was only the movie theaters that were involved in the booking and exhibition of the finished film. There were only two distribution circuits that wielded tremendous powers on the booking and distribution of films: the Metro Manila Theaters Association and the Greater Manila Theaters Association. After the 1990s, major changes in the distribution practices began when many venues, other than the stand-alone movie theater, were opened for the screening of films. All these vehicles became possible sources of revenue for the producers.

 

The advent of the shopping mall in the 1970s and 1980s created the venue where majority of the film audience congregate. The comfort of air-conditioned and easily accessible malls provided the public with a one-stop place for shopping, entertainment, and commercial and personal services. The construction of malls in every major city and town saw the mushrooming of the cineplex. A cineplex may have anywhere from 4 to 12 theaters. The current listing of theaters shows 706 theaters or screens that are located in cineplexes inside malls and supermalls. The Ayala Group Corporation has 67 theaters in its malls and accounts for 9.5 percent of all theaters. The Cinema 2000 Theater Group has 111 theaters and accounts for 15.7 percent of all theaters. Robinsons has 127 theaters and accounts for 18 percent of all theaters. The SM Group has 296 theaters and accounts for 42 percent of all theaters. There are 105 more screens under different companies and groups that account for 14.8 percent of all theaters. Stand-alone theaters or movie houses that are separate and unique structures are a thing of the past. Only a few exist now and are insignificant in terms of distribution statistics.

 

A major motion picture often plays at these commercial theaters. After the theatrical release, films are shown on TV and eventually released in the home video consumption market via DVD, Blu-ray and online streaming. Nowadays, the theater-to-home window has been shortened to maximize profit potential in the quickest time possible. There is also video on demand or VOD, which may show a film to the home market concurrently with a theatrical release.

 

A major factor that influences the distribution system is the proliferation of independently produced movies made outside the major film studios beginning in the 2000s. Depending on these agents’ connections and the overall budget of the film being represented, this may or may not be an option for the filmmaker. Sometimes, services like Netflix or iTunes will not accept a submission without the provision of representation. Whether a film is produced by a major studio or is independently produced outside the mainstream of the industry, the following sources of revenue continue to be relevant. First are theater ticket sales. The primary way that movies, particularly mainstream movies, make money is through theater ticket sales. While there are exceptions (such as movies that are transferred directly to DVD after a failure to attract a commercial theater exhibition), the average movie is going to make its income from ticket sales in the local movie cineplexes. A second source of revenue is DVD sales. While a movie studio might only make a few pesos from each DVD sale, the number quickly adds up with the sale of hundreds or thousands of DVDs. Third is free television and cable. article.value: Films were first exhibited in Manila during the last years of Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. The earliest account was in a Spanish-language newspaper, announcing an exhibition titled Espectaculo Cientifico (Science Show), comprising seven titles, and shown in a converted warehouse on Escolta, Manila. The event, probably the first clear indication of a local film screening, was held on the first day of 1897, a little over a year since the first public showing of Cinématographe films by the Lumière brothers in Paris.

Early accounts also point to a Frenchman named Rebarber who, with Eduardo Munarriz and Jose Hernandez as capitalists and Jose Martin as projectionist, took over an old warehouse at the back of Quiapo Church on Evangelista Street and converted it into a cinema, Cine Orpheum, in 1904. Another warehouse on Ongpin Street near Misericordia Street in Santa Cruz, Manila, was made into a movie house called Cine Cervantes. In 1907, a row of accesoria (apartments) along Legarda Street in Sampaloc, Manila, owned by Dr Valentin Guidote (whose daughter, Raymunda Guidote, later appeared in a silent film, Fate or Consequence, 1926), was transformed into Cine Moderno. The next year, 1908, saw the construction of Ideal Theater on Rizal Avenue.

The first Filipino feature films that were shown at the Grand Opera House and at the Empire and Majestic theaters were relatively short. Albert Yearsley’s El Fusilamiento de Dr. Jose Rizal (The Execution of Dr Jose Rizal), 1912, had a screening time of only 20 minutes, while Edward Gross’s La Vida de Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal), 1912, came as the standard four-reeler of approximately 5,000 feet with a screening time of almost one hour (one reel of film took about 12 minutes to run in the silent movie projector).

With the coming of talking pictures, feature films increased in length. The standard was one-and-a-half to two hours of screening time. Films came in 2,000-foot reels and were shuttled among nearby theaters during multiple first-run exhibitions in Metro Manila. The practice was called lagare—literally, “sawing.” This practice guaranteed the simultaneous exhibition of one film in several theaters using only one available print copy. While the lagare system was accepted in the city so as to cut on costs (producers found it too expensive to provide each theater with its own print copy), the unauthorized exhibition system in the provinces known as bisikleta (literally, “bicycle,” referring to the vehicle that was used for transporting the film to a venue not contracted by the producer) was condemned by film distributors and film producers alike. Film checkers who were caught conspiring with unscrupulous exhibitors in the bisikleta system were heavily penalized if not fired outright, while erring theaters were boycotted and their supply of films cut off for a certain period by both the producers’ associations (the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association and the Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines) and the exhibitors’ associations (the Greater Manila Theaters Association and the Metro Manila Theaters Association).

In the past, block booking required an exhibitor to take the full package of films or receive none of a studio’s offerings. text:
Film editing is the process of selecting, assembling, and arranging motion picture shots into a coherent film. It not only provides logical continuity but also creates pace and mood, compresses or expands time and space, and generally underlines the visual meanings of a film. Editing is an art as it requires the careful yet creative juxtaposition of images to coincide with what makes the most effective story. There is always the pacing of the film to consider as well as the arc and progression of important narrative units to make the story clear while at the same time interesting and new. There are times when the editor can completely give a new twist to the storytelling because of the sheer power of his ingenuity and grasp of how to tell a visual story in a unique way.

 

There are two basic categories of editing: simple editing that focuses on continuity from shot to shot, and the more creative and complex type of editing.

 

 

The basic goal of editing is to give continuity and coherence to various shots by putting the film together through simple cutting or trimming and arranging the shots in sequence, following the order specified in the movie script. Before the advent of computer editing, scenes were cut and spliced with tape (dry splice) or film cement (wet splice). The best takes and camera angles were selected for the rough cut, which was the first stage of the edited workprint.

 

The more creative aspect of editing is refining and reshaping the material by further trimming down to achieve the desired structure and rhythm. Before digital editing, editors worked on a machine called the Moviola or the horizontal flatbed editing console, carefully examining each scene to find out whether the shots were arranged and juxtaposed within scenes to create meaning, mood, or effect. Every scene was sharpened and compressed into a desired length and added to other scenes, composing a sequence. Transitional effects like fades, dissolves, and wipes were tentatively marked in the workprint by glaze pencil. The sequences were made to flow into one flawless continuity. Once the rough cut was approved, the rest of the work was done to its final version, the fine cut.

 

 

The workprint became the basis for mixing in the separate sound tracks (dialogue, narration, sound effects, music, etc.) with the film’s visuals. Transitional effects (dissolves, fades, etc.) and titles were also designated by the editor and properly marked on the workprint in preparation for optical printing.

 

In the last phase of editing, the workprint was turned over to a negative cutter who matched it using the edge numbers that correspond to the original negative, which had been carefully kept intact since the first shooting day. With extreme care, using white gloves and working in a dust-free cutting room, the negative cutter cut and spliced the negative exactly the way the workprint had been edited. The matched negative was then delivered to the film laboratory together with the sound negative produced by the optical printer from the mixed track. Specific instructions from the editor and the director accompanied the material.

 

The trial print that came back from the film laboratory was known as the answer print. It was screened and examined carefully during a preview on the big screen to correct light balance, color grading, and other optical details. The answer print was returned to the laboratory for correction and the process went on until a final print was approved. Subsequently, release prints were prepared and copied from the negative, and only then did the film editor complete his work on the film project.

 

When filming no longer required negatives and positives—and digital technology took over—the work of the editor became easier as it also posed much greater demand in terms of creativity and innovation. Without the limitations of physical cutting and splicing of the workprint, the editor is now able to manipulate images more freely, stringing together various shots to tell a story with the luxury of easy revision while finding the best way to tell the story based on the available footage. Creativity in editing comes in reshaping the material and not merely putting together what has been laid out for the editor to follow.

 

The advent of digital technology produced the nonlinear editing system. It uses a computer to arrange and play pictures and sounds, thereby simplifying the cutting of the film in terms of workload and efficiency. It is not merely a tool for cutting or rearranging shots, but it also has the capabilities to do visual effects, graphics, and sound editing in one setup. Shots can be changed or removed with the click of the mouse. The material is stored in the computer’s hard drives. This provides an instant, random access to any part of the footage. Although digital editing seems to make film editing a lot easier and quicker, the main discipline of telling a story remains the same as in the traditional film editing.

 

Like the practice in traditional filmmaking, the editor is given the raw footage of the movie in production. This footage is submitted for digitizing from a day or days of shooting. They are all the shots taken by the director and his cameraman to provide the raw material for the sequences taken for the day. These shots can be viewed by the producer and the director. Roughly edited footage gives a semblance of form beyond a series of shots and takes. Again, directors, producers, and even creative committees view the rough cut to see the progression of the film.

 

The editor is sometimes given the liberty to do the editor’s cut. This is how the editor decides to assemble the movie, but this version is subject to the critique and discrimination of the director. A director may choose to alter, adjust, or even make general revisions of the editor’s cut to come out with his own director’s cut.

 

The director’s cut is presented to the producer who can choose to accept or make revisions from what their commissioned filmmaker has offered them. If there are still changes or even tweaks needed, then the editor proceeds to do the producer’s cut, which is often the release copy.

 

All these versions are rendered off-line. After the finalization of the release copy, the editor proceeds to do the online procedures in order for the film to be transferred to the digital cinema package or other formats required by movie houses or the various platforms.

 

In the early days of the film industry in the Philippines, film editing was such a delicate task that directors and producers like Jose Nepomuceno, Vicente Salumbides, and Julian Manansala could not entrust it to others; they themselves edited their own films. During the silent picture era when there was practically only one movie studio (Malayan Movies) servicing the needs of various film producers, directors like Carlos Vander Tolosa, Jose Domingo Badilla, and Manuel Silos packaged editing work in their contracts with movie producers, subsequently training and hiring cutters to do the elementary job of cutting and joining the materials so that they could devote more time to creative editing work. With the advent of the talking film or “talkies,” editing became a more complicated process, prompting Filipino film technicians to study under Hollywood-trained experts who were brought into the country with the new technology.

 

With the rise of movie studios in the years immediately preceding the Pacific War, film editing as a profession came into its own. Every film studio had its own chief film editor supervising the work of an entire department staffed with film cutters and negative matchers. Filippine Films had Victoriano Calub; Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Films, Leandro German; Sampaguita Pictures, Nario Rosales and Pedro Manlangit; LVN Pictures, Greg Carballo and Enrique Jarlego Sr; and X’Otic Pictures, Antonio Verches, who later became a movie director.

 

Film editors who became directors themselves, aside from Verches, include Marcelino Navarro, Augusto Salvador, Pepe Marcos, and Toto Natividad.

 

Verches was the first film editor to receive an award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS ) for his work in May Isang Tsuper ng Taxi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953. Calub was awarded for Desperado (Desperate), 1956, while Jarlego Sr received his first FAMAS for Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955.

 

The other outstanding film editors and their works are Jose H. Tarnate, Bondying, 1954; Fely Crisostomo, Hanggang sa Dulong Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958; Teofilo de Leon, The Moises Padilla Story, 1961; Atilano Salvador, Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Gervacio Santos, Scout Rangers, 1964; Ben Barcelon, Passionate Strangers, 1966; Marcelino Navarro, Nardong Putik, 1972; Ike Jarlego Jr, Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975; Edgardo Vinarao, Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Efren Jarlego, Salome, 1981; Jess Navarro, Batch ’81, 1982; Steve Paolo, Alapaap (Sky), 1984; Augusto Salvador, Muslim Magnum .347, 1986; George Jarlego, Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988; Abelardo Hulleza, Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988; and the film industry’s only female editor at the time and Asian Film Festival awardee, Elsa Abutan Abellana, Igorot a (Mountain Maiden), 1968. A producer, Albert Joseph, who personally edited his film Hindi sa Iyo ang Mundo, Baby Porcuna (The World Is Not Yours, Baby Porcuna) received the Gawad Urian for Best Editing in 1978.

 

Three examples of finely edited Filipino films are Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, which makes judicious use of editing to establish the movement from fear to terror; Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976, an experimental, unconventional work whose editing pace shows the cyclical instead of chronological movement of the film; and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), a deftly constructed film that explores the highly charged political scenario of the country in the late 1980s.

 

For practical and economic, but sometimes aesthetic, reasons, many of the current editors are also the directors of the films they edit, particularly in independent filmmaking. Today’s most sought-after film editors include Chuck Gutierrez, who edited Boundary, 2011, Debosyon (Devotion) and Mga Ani no ng Kahapon (Shadows of the Past), 2013, and Iisa (As One ), 2015, which he also directed; Carlo Manatad, who edited Supremo (Supreme Chief), 2012, Gaydar (Gay Radar), 2013, and The Trial, 2014; Mikhail Red, who directed and edited Rekorder (Recorder), 2013; Robert Quebral, who edited Luwal, Pag-ibig at Paalam (Birth, Love and Death), 1991, and ImaheNasyon (Portrait of a Nation), 2006; Joyce Bernal, who edited Utol (Brother), 1996, Bullet, 1999, and Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; Marya Ignacio, who edited Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002, Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), 2005, and Bride for Rent, 2014; and Manet Dayrit, who edited Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, Radyo (Radio), 2001, and Urduja, 2008.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, with notes from Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Jose Javier Reyes, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu and Rica Arevalo

In the last phase of editing, the workprint was turned over to a negative cutter who matched it using the edge numbers that correspond to the original negative, which had been carefully kept intact since the first shooting day. With extreme care, using white gloves and working in a dust-free cutting room, the negative cutter cut and spliced the negative exactly the way the workprint had been edited. The matched negative was then delivered to the film laboratory together with the sound negative produced by the optical printer from the mixed track. Specific instructions from the editor and the director accompanied the material.

The trial print that came back from the film laboratory was known as the answer print. It was screened and examined carefully during a preview on the big screen to correct light balance, color grading, and other optical details. The answer print was returned to the laboratory for correction and the process went on until a final print was approved. Subsequently, release prints were prepared and copied from the negative, and only then did the film editor complete his work on the film project.

When filming no longer required negatives and positives—and digital technology took over—the work of the editor became easier as it also posed much greater demand in terms of creativity and innovation. Without the limitations of physical cutting and splicing of the workprint, the editor is now able to manipulate images more freely, stringing together various shots to tell a story with the luxury of easy revision while finding the best way to tell the story based on the available footage. Creativity in editing comes in reshaping the material and not merely putting together what has been laid out for the editor to follow.

The advent of digital technology produced the nonlinear editing system. It uses a computer to arrange and play pictures and sounds, thereby simplifying the cutting of the film in terms of workload and efficiency. It is not merely a tool for cutting or rearranging shots, but it also has the capabilities to do visual effects, graphics, and sound editing in one setup. Shots can be changed or removed with the click of the mouse. The material is stored in the computer’s hard drives. This provides an instant, random access to any part of the footage. Although digital editing seems to make film editing a lot easier and quicker, the main discipline of telling a story remains the same as in the traditional film editing.

Like the practice in traditional filmmaking, the editor is given the raw footage of the movie in production. This footage is submitted for digitizing from a day or days of shooting. They are all the shots taken by the director and his cameraman to provide the raw material for the sequences taken for the day. These shots can be viewed by the producer and the director. Roughly edited footage gives a semblance of form beyond a series of shots and takes. Again, directors, producers, and even creative committees view the rough cut to see the progression of the film.

The editor is sometimes given the liberty to do the editor’s cut. This is how the editor decides to assemble the movie, but this version is subject to the critique and discrimination of the director. A director may choose to alter, adjust, or even make general revisions of the editor’s cut to come out with his own director’s cut.

The director’s cut is presented to the producer who can choose to accept or make revisions from what their commissioned filmmaker has offered them. If there are still changes or even tweaks needed, then the editor proceeds to do the producer’s cut, which is often the release copy.

All these versions are rendered off-line. After the finalization of the release copy, the editor proceeds to do the online procedures in order for the film to be transferred to the digital cinema package or other formats required by movie houses or the various platforms.

In the early days of the film industry in the Philippines, film editing was such a delicate task that directors and producers like Jose Nepomuceno, Vicente Salumbides, and Julian Manansala could not entrust it to others; they themselves edited their own films. During the silent picture era when there was practically only one movie studio (Malayan Movies) servicing the needs of various film producers, directors like Carlos Vander Tolosa, Jose Domingo Badilla, and Manuel Silos packaged editing work in their contracts with movie producers, subsequently training and hiring cutters to do the elementary job of cutting and joining the materials so that they could devote more time to creative editing work. With the advent of the talking film or “talkies,” editing became a more complicated process, prompting Filipino film technicians to study under Hollywood-trained experts who were brought into the country with the new technology.

With the rise of movie studios in the years immediately preceding the Pacific War, film editing as a profession came into its own. Every film studio had its own chief film editor supervising the work of an entire department staffed with film cutters and negative matchers. Filippine Films had Victoriano Calub; Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Films, Leandro German; Sampaguita Pictures, Nario Rosales and Pedro Manlangit; LVN Pictures, Greg Carballo and Enrique Jarlego Sr; and X’Otic Pictures, Antonio Verches, who later became a movie director.
Film editors who became directors themselves, aside from Verches, include Marcelino Navarro, Augusto Salvador, Pepe Marcos, and Toto Natividad.

Verches was the first film editor to receive an award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS ) for his work in May Isang Tsuper ng Taxi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953. Calub was awarded for Desperado (Desperate), 1956, while Jarlego Sr received his first FAMAS for Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955.

The other outstanding film editors and their works are Jose H. Tarnate, Bondying, 1954; Fely Crisostomo, Hanggang sa Dulong Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958; Teofilo de Leon, The Moises Padilla Story, 1961; Atilano Salvador, Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Gervacio Santos, Scout Rangers, 1964; Ben Barcelon, Passionate Strangers, 1966; Marcelino Navarro, Nardong Putik, 1972; Ike Jarlego Jr, Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975; Edgardo Vinarao, Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Efren Jarlego, Salome, 1981; Jess Navarro, Batch ’81, 1982; Steve Paolo, Alapaap (Sky), 1984; Augusto Salvador, Muslim Magnum .347, 1986; George Jarlego, Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988; Abelardo Hulleza, Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988; and the film industry’s only female editor at the time and Asian Film Festival awardee, Elsa Abutan Abellana, Igorot a (Mountain Maiden), 1968. A producer, Albert Joseph, who personally edited his film Hindi sa Iyo ang Mundo, Baby Porcuna (The World Is Not Yours, Baby Porcuna) received the Gawad Urian for Best Editing in 1978.

Three examples of finely edited Filipino films are Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, which makes judicious use of editing to establish the movement from fear to terror; Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976, an experimental, unconventional work whose editing pace shows the cyclical instead of chronological movement of the film; and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), a deftly constructed film that explores the highly charged political scenario of the country in the late 1980s.

For practical and economic, but sometimes aesthetic, reasons, many of the current editors are also the directors of the films they edit, particularly in independent filmmaking. Today’s most sought-after film editors include Chuck Gutierrez, who edited Boundary, 2011, Debosyon (Devotion) and Mga Ani no ng Kahapon (Shadows of the Past), 2013, and Iisa (As One ), 2015, which he also directed; Carlo Manatad, who edited Supremo (Supreme Chief), 2012, Gaydar (Gay Radar), 2013, and The Trial, 2014; Mikhail Red, who directed and edited Rekorder (Recorder), 2013; Robert Quebral, who edited Luwal, Pag-ibig at Paalam (Birth, Love and Death), 1991, and ImaheNasyon (Portrait of a Nation), 2006; Joyce Bernal, who edited Utol (Brother), 1996, Bullet, 1999, and Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; Marya Ignacio, who edited Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002, Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), 2005, and Bride for Rent, 2014; and Manet Dayrit, who edited Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, Radyo (Radio), 2001, and Urduja, 2008.

Special effects in film are devices used to enhance the cinematic language and aid the director in achieving credibility and communication in film. They can help create a different world or even a planet only seen in fantasy and science-fiction movies. They can also help recreate the past and envision the future. Initially, there were two types of effects: special effects and optical effects. Special effects were produced by artificial photographic process, to represent a building on fire, a mine exploding on the battlefield, and other such effects. Optical effects were done in the laboratory and include such technical devices as dissolves, split-screens, superimpositions, wipes, and fades.

 

Dissolves are two or more superimposed images, one gradually coming into prominence and the other or others disappearing. Split-screen refers to the juxtaposition of two or more separate images on screen. Superimpositions are two or more images, one over the other, occurring simultaneously on screen. The wipe refers to an image being pushed offscreen by another image either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. The fade shows an image gradually appearing or disappearing.

 

 

The director decides, in consultation with the editor, where each optical is going to occur and how long the transition will be. Opticals have to be accurately calculated because they are crucial to the film’s rhythm. While these effects were achieved before through a tedious process with the optical printer, today these effects are achieved with the computer and a flick of the mouse and, more importantly, can be previewed immediately on the monitor.

 

Special effects may also refer to sounds that are not recorded during shooting but are produced artificially and recorded separately in an effects track to synchronize with the appropriate shots. They help create the illusion of reality by enhancing the pictorial representations of catastrophic disasters (earthquake, volcanic eruption), terrifying accidents (the sinking of a ship, a plane crash), and natural calamities (flood, typhoon, hurricane).

 

 

The person from the special effects department has the difficult job of making all these look and sound real. He is also responsible for other feats like making actors fly, undergo split-second physical transformation, or perform acts of the supernatural, which must look credible and seem natural on the screen.

 

Richard Abelardo, recipient of the Natatanging Gawad Urian in 1989, was the acknowledged pioneer cinematic wizard of Philippine cinema. He turned a prince into stone in Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941; reproduced a castle in the air in Prinsesang Basahan (Princess in Rags), 1949; and made Jaime de la Rosa grow hair on his face, transforming him into a bat monster in Taong Paniki (Bat Man), 1952.

 

It was Abelardo who introduced background projection in Philippine cinema via the movie Ibong Adarna . This is a special effect obtained by a photographic process. It was done by projecting a film taken on location onto a screen behind the actors as they performed on the sound stage with all its conveniences. Knowledge of proper cinematic lighting was important for the special effects crew to carry out their task, as improper lighting might produce a halo effect around the heads of actors in the foreground and dullness in the background image. Later, background or rear projection was widely used in scenes of speeding cars on the highway, a plane in flight, or other moving objects requiring passing scenery while actors performed and delivered their lines without distraction.

 

Abelardo also excelled in the use of glass shots, recreating a Moorish palace atop the walls of Intramuros for Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954, and the biblical kingdom of King Solomon, which he built atop the ruins of the Augustinian monastery in Guadalupe, Makati, for Haring Solomon at Reyna Sheba (King Solomon and Queen Sheba), 1952. A plate of glass on which an artist had painted an addition to the scenery was placed before the camera, thus recording a composite image. This could be done in the camera with mirrors, or in matte shots (a mask covers one portion of the film while it is exposed and then a reverse mask is used while the previously unexposed portion photographs an additional effect). Abelardo used matte shots to recreate the medieval kingdoms of Rodrigo de Villa, 1952, and Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954. Abelardo also pioneered in the use of prosthetics for the giant monster in Tuko sa Madre Kakaw (Gecko at Madre Cacao), 1959.

 

The effects specialist has to be something of an engineer, an inventor, and an expert in construction as well as destruction. Totoy Torrente, a special effects person of the 1950s, was all these. He was particularly in demand in war scenes calling for difficult setups, such as a tunnel being blown up in Mga Kanyon ng Corregidor (Cannons of Corregidor), 1964, or a minefield exploding while soldiers were fleeing from a battle scene. In highly dangerous action scenes like these, the timing must be precise and nothing was left to chance.

 

Miniatures were the forte of Ben Resella, who learned special effects from Abelardo. For El Indio (The Native), 1953, Resella designed a small ship and built a miniature substitute model to be wrecked during a storm scene.Miniatures were often animated by the laborious process of photographing their movements one frame at a time to achieve the illusion of reality.

 

Prosthetics, the art of cinematic makeup and costuming, has now become a regular feature of many films, particularly of the horror-fantasy scene. Filipino directors who pioneered in the use and application of prosthetics include Gerardo de Leon, who in Dyesebel, 1953, created a mermaid’s costume for Edna Luna. Later, Cecille Baun became known for creating some of the most memorable characters and monsters in Filipino movies in the last 40 years. She first started as a prosthetics and makeup artist for the Vilma Santos fantasy movie Darna and the Giants, 1973. Since then, she has worked as prosthetics and makeup artists in various movies, such as Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984; Halimaw sa Banga (Monster in a Jar), 1986; Darna, 1991; Jose Rizal , 1998; Spirit Warriors, 2000; Baler, 2008; Aswang, 2011; and the indie film Espesyal Kopol (Special Couple), 2015.

 

The introduction of digital technology in the mid-1990s also resulted in tremendous improvements in the field of film effects as every special effect imaginable can be done digitally by creating computer-generated images (CGIs). This coincided with the introduction of the digital film format, which challenged the supremacy of celluloid film. As to be expected, Hollywood pioneered the advancements in computer-generated special effects. Today, CGIs are the most widely used type of special effect as more and more films are being shot on digital format. In 2012, filmmaker Erik Matti made Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, the first Filipino movie to be shot entirely on a green screen chroma key. The background and the monsters were all CGIs.  Written by Nick Cruz and Lena S. Pareja, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Elvin Valerio

text:
A film festival is an event at which films are shown in one or more screening venues, usually in a single city or region over a period of several days. Awards may be given to films of particularly high quality by jury members. Typically, film festivals are attended by filmmakers, actors, film connoisseurs, and students, among others.

 

Several countries all over the world hold film festivals regularly, ranging from larger film festivals, like the Cannes Film Festival, to smaller regional events that focus on works by local filmmakers.

 

 

Europe is considered the cradle of the film festival phenomenon. The Venice Film Festival in Italy was founded in 1932 as part of the Venice Biennale. It is the oldest film festival and one of the most prominent in the world. The Cannes Film Festival was established in 1946 as a combined French, British, and American effort to go against the fascist dominance of the film festival in Venice. Another prominent festival is the Berlin International Film Festival, which was founded in 1951 and is annually held in Berlin, Germany. Film festivals have since then become showcases of national cinemas, eventually also functioning as both protectors of the cinematic art and facilitators of film industries. Soon after, there was a global spread of film festivals.

 

In 1966, Manila mayor Antonio J. Villegas inaugurated the Manila Film Festival. For the first time, locally produced films were screened in downtown theaters like Ideal, Odeon, State, Ever, Galaxy, and Capitol, which usually screened only Hollywood and foreign films. The festival provided respite from competition against Hollywood, giving Filipinos the opportunity to watch Tagalog pictures in Manila’s “first-class” theaters. Atty Espiridion Laxa served as chairman of the festival, which began on 14 Jun and culminated on 24 Jun, coinciding with the city’s foundation day. Eighteen local films (14 new, four re-releases) were screened. The top prize, the Rajah Soliman Grand Award for Best Picture, was given to Gerardo de Leon’s Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965.

 

 

During its first run, many journalists praised the festival as the much-needed government action that manifests their support for the local filmdom. However, through the years, critics dismissed the festival as merely token support that did not address the more pressing issues plaguing the industry. Critics pointed out that US-Philippine co-productions like The Brides of Blood Island, 1966, and The Passionate Strangers, 1966, were allowed into the festival on the grounds that they were locally produced with Filipino actors. Furthermore, critics pointed out that some of the festival’s box-office hits, like Tony Ferrer’s secret agent thrillers Sabotage, 1966, and Modus Opera ndi, 1967, seemed to be the most imitative of Hollywood.

 

In spite of the controversies and criticism, the festival lasted until 1974. Throughout its nine-year stint, the festival exhibited several popular films, such as Celso Ad. Castillo’s Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko (The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko), 1973, Luciano Carlos’s Dolphy-starrer Facifica Falayfay, 1969, German Moreno’s Guy and Pip, 1971, among others. In the last edition, the festival did not award the Rajah Soliman Grand Award to any of the competing films for the first time since its establishment.

 

 

The Manila Film Festival became the Metropolitan Film Festival in 1975, covering the Greater Manila Area. In 1977, the festival was renamed Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF). Under the new direction of the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association, the festival now encompassed the satellite cities that comprise Metro Manila. Today, the festival is presented by the Metro Manila Development Authority.

 

The first edition began on 21 Sep 1975 to commemorate the third anniversary of the imposition of martial law. A year after, the festival started on Christmas day for the first time. In its first year, Augusto Buenaventura’s Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), won the six major awards, including Best Picture. Films like Lino Brocka’s Bona, 1980, Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, Ishmael Bernal’s Himala (Miracle), 1982, and the Shake, Rattle & Roll horror anthology all premiered in the festival.

 

The festival’s 1986 edition was considered to be the worst in the festival’s 12-year history at the time. For the first time, no competing film was awarded Best Picture and Second Best Picture. Only a Third Best Picture was cited, Mario O’Hara’s Halimaw sa Banga (Monster in a Jar). Tingting Cojuangco, chair of the board of jurors, announced during the ceremonies that none of the seven competing films deserved the Best Picture award and that the entries did not “reinforce and inculcate positive Filipino values” as they were only “portraying negative stereotypes, imitating foreign films, and perpetuating commercially oriented movies” (quoted in Vera 2014). In 1990, the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Awards was first established to award the film that best portrays Filipino culture and Filipino people to the world. It was named after the festival’s father, the late former Manila mayor Antonio J. Villegas who died in 1984. The award’s first recipient was Gil Portes’s Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990. Other later recipients were Peque Gallaga’s Magic Temple, 1996, Jose Javier Reyes’s Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, and Brillante Mendoza’s Thy Womb, 2012.

 

In 2010, the festival underwent significant changes. The commercial viability criterion for the selection of Best Pictures was removed. In the past editions, commercial viability accounted for 50 percent of the criteria for selection. The criteria dedicated 70 percent to artistic, creative, and technical excellence whereas the remaining 30 percent was devoted to values. In the same year, a new competitive section that featured local independent films was created. It was named “New Wave” in the following year. The section usually preceded the main competition. It included five full-length features and student short films. The first recipient of the Best Film award in this section was Adolfo Alix Jr’s Presa (Female Prisoner), 2010. Since then, the MMFF criteria have changed a number of times, often leaning toward commercial viability of films.

 

Short film production, which was significant in the 1950s, contributed to the growth of cinema in the Philippines—particularly, alternative filmmaking.

 

In 1962, the Film Society of the Philippines, founded by Benedicto Pinga, a filmmaker and World War II veteran, held the First National Festival of Short Films. The entries in the competition attested to the status of the local short films as an alternative to the commercial narrative film. The second edition was held in 1964.

 

In 1981, the Manila Short Film Festival was held at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater in the University of the Philippines (UP). It was organized by Nick Deocampo. Raymond Red’s 25-minute short Ang Magpakailanman (Eternity) won first prize in the experimental category during the 1983 edition of the festival. The festival primarily focused on short films to promote alternative filmmaking at a time when the mass media were controlled by the Marcos dictatorship.

 

Conversely, the Marcos government’s Experimental Cinema of the Philippines also sponsored the Annual Short Film Festival from 1982 to 1985. The objectives of the festival include showcasing the craft and talent of the Filipino short filmmaker and celebrating his perseverance and passion for the film art. In its inaugural year, it was able to gather 96 entries, which was later reduced to 44.

 

Today, short film competitions are integrated in several film festivals as sections. Moreover, most regional film festivals—if not all—primarily focus on short films. The Mindanao Film Festival, started in 2004 in Davao, usually programs more than 50 short films from all over the island every year. Other regional film festivals—such as the CineKabalen Film Festival, established in 2009 in Pampanga; the BINISAYA Film Festival, established in 2011 in Cebu; and the Cinemagis Short Digital Film Festival, established in 2009 in Cagayan de Oro—also program short films in their respective regions.

 

These regional short films ultimately culminate in the Cinema Rehiyon Film Festival, which is presented by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). It was first organized in 2008 through the Cinema Committee of the NCCA Subcommission on the Arts with the objective of showcasing cinematic works from various regions of the country, specifically outside Metro Manila. The festival is usually held every February, coinciding with the National Arts Month. The Cinema Rehiyon annually showcases an average of 50 short films from different regions outside Metro Manila as well as some regional full-length films. The first two editions were held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Since 2011, a different region hosted the festival every year. The 2011 edition was in Davao, while the following editions were held in Bacolod, Los Baños, Cagayan de Oro, and Cebu, respectively.

 

In the early editions, the festival followed rather informal curatorial policies. Films only had to showcase a level of competence in production quality, and they had to be reflective of their respective regions. The need for equal regional representation was also considered in the selection of the films to be exhibited. In 2012, the festival began to implement a more formal curatorial process, although it still retained the “regional” qualifier.

 

Meanwhile, some film festivals were established with the objectives of reviving Philippine cinema and, at the same time, promoting independent filmmaking.

 

Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF) was founded by Filipino filmmaker Amable “Tikoy” Aguiluz VI in 1999. The festival was named after Lino Brocka’s production company, which was formed in 1974. The festival’s goals include the revitalization of the Philippines as the center of Southeast Asian cinema and the production of international caliber Filipino films. The CIFF specifically aimed to: (1) nurture young Filipino directors by providing them with the opportunity to see the best of World Cinema, (2) discover new talents in the Philippines and Southeast Asia in order for the Philippines to become the hub of Southeast Asian films, and (3) create a revitalized Filipino film industry that will become a major player in the Asian content industry.

 

CIFF yearly celebrated and gave tribute to outstanding independent filmmakers. It celebrated outstanding Filipino and foreign filmmakers, including American director Quentin Tarantino, Indonesian actress/producer Christine Hakim, Filipino-American actors Lou Diamond Phillips and Tia Carrere, and Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Meirelles. Some of these as well as other important film artists gave lectures during the festival.

 

When it opened, CIFF had the following categories: International Competition, Southeast Asian Competition, Young Cinema: Documentaries, and Young Cinema: Shorts. Digital Lokal was added in 2006.

 

The Cinemanila festival icon is the bulol, which is a Cordillera rice deity that is believed to ensure good harvest. The bulol trophy was designed by National Artist Napoleon Abueva. Due to lack of funding, the CIFF stopped in 2013, after 15 years of existence.

 

But other international film festivals were established. The SalaMindanaw International Film Festival was founded by Mindanaon filmmaker Gutierrez Mangansakan II in General Santos City in 2013. It is the first international film festival in Mindanao. It held competitions for Asian full-length features, Asian short films, and Mindanao short films.

 

Philippine cinema experienced a steady decline in film production in the early 2000s. From around 120 films a year for wide release, only 49 films were produced in 2006. This decline can be attributed to several factors, such as rising cost of raw film stock, taxation, and foreign competition. However, digital filmmaking managed to revive the industry through the help of the Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival and Cinema One Originals Film Festival, both established in 2005.

 

In 2004, Cinemalaya was officially established by businessman Antonio Cojuangco, Film Development Council of the Philippines chairperson Laurice Guillen, film enthusiasts Joey Avellana and Maan Hontiveros, CCP president Nestor Jardin, and then-UP College of Mass Communications dean Nicanor Tiongson.

 

Cinemalaya aims to (1) help develop and support the production of cinematic works of Filipino independent filmmakers that boldly articulate and freely interpret the Filipino experience with fresh insight and artistic integrity; (2) discover, encourage, support, train and recognize gifted Filipino independent filmmakers; (3) promote Filipino independent films locally and internationally; and (4) establish a network for exchange, communication, and cooperation among members of the independent film sector. The Cinemalaya festival logo is the balanghai, a vessel that the early Filipinos used during precolonial times in search of a land where they could live in freedom. The balanghai represents artistic expressiveness and boldness.

 

Cinemalaya is the first festival that began its selection process with the submission of synopses rather than finished projects. The selected projects would each receive a seed grant amounting to 500,000 pesos. The first edition exhibited nine digital features and six digital shorts, giving the first Best Film awards to Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Pepot Artista (Pepot Superstar) in the full-length category, and to Joel Ruiz’s Mansyon (Mansion) in the short film category.

 

Throughout the festival’s 11 years of existence, it produced 112 films, some of which were commercially successful and received both local and international awards and critical acclaim. Some of these notable films are Auraeus Solito’s Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros  (he Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005, Pepe Diokno’s Engkwentro (Clash), 2009, and Milo Tolentino’s Andong, 2008. Moreover, since 2006, five films that debuted in the festival were submitted to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS) for consideration for the Best Foreign Film category of the annual Oscar Awards: Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros, 2006, Adolf Alix Jr’s Donsol, 2007, Marlon Rivera’s Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011, Jun Robles Lana’s Bwakaw, 2012, and Hannah Espia’s Transit, 2013.

 

In 2010, entries were separated into two categories: the New Breed and the Directors Showcase. While the New Breed category featured films by new filmmakers directing their first full-length feature, the Directors Showcase category was reserved for veteran directors. However, the festival organizers decided to remove the New Breed category after the 2014 edition, limiting the competition to short films.

 

The Cinema One Originals Film Festival is a project of Creative Programs Inc, an entertainment subsidiary of ABS-CBN, the country’s largest media corporation The festival is produced by Cinema One, the country’s popular Filipino cable channel that also airs local digital films. Similar to Cinemalaya’s system, film projects are selected on the basis of scripts submitted and then awarded production grant of 600,000 pesos, which was later raised to 700,000 pesos in 2006, and to one million pesos in 2008. However, unlike in Cinemalaya, Cinema One reserves solo ownership of the film grantees.

 

Some of the Cinema One Originals entries that won Best Film are Sherad Anthony Sanchez’s Huling Balyan ng Buhi ( The Woven Stories of the Other), 2006, Jerrold Tarog’s Confessional, 2007, Sanchez’s Imburnal (Sewers), 2008, Rey Defante Gibraltar’s Wanted: Border, 2009, Remton Siega Zuasola’s Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria (The Dream of Eleuteria), 2010, and Sari Lluch Dalena’s Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang), 2011.

 

In 2012, entries were categorized according to blockbuster potential and market appeals. The two categories are called Currents and Plus. Three films that were deemed to be “most commercial” among the entries were included in the first batch of the Plus category. In 2013, five films in the Plus category were each given two million pesos compared to the one million peso grant given to the 10 entries in the Currents category (least commercial). In 2014, however, the two categories were removed. In future editions, the 10 selected films would compete in only one category.

 

Other similar grant-giving film festivals have since then emerged, such as the Mindanao Film Festival, 2004; the Cinema Rehiyon Festival, 2008; the Film Development Council’s Sineng Pambansa, 2012; Unitel Productions’ CineFilipino Film Festival, 2013; the Quezon City International Film Festival (QCinema), 2013; GMA News TV’s Cine Totoo Documentary Film Festival, 2014; and Sinag Maynila, 2015, which was founded by filmmaker Brillante Mendoza.  Written by Khurshid Kala bud Jr, with notes from Christian Co  and Gregory del Carmen

article.value: Several countries all over the world hold film festivals regularly, ranging from larger film festivals, like the Cannes Film Festival, to smaller regional events that focus on works by local filmmakers.

Europe is considered the cradle of the film festival phenomenon. The Venice Film Festival in Italy was founded in 1932 as part of the Venice Biennale. It is the oldest film festival and one of the most prominent in the world. The Cannes Film Festival was established in 1946 as a combined French, British, and American effort to go against the fascist dominance of the film festival in Venice. Another prominent festival is the Berlin International Film Festival, which was founded in 1951 and is annually held in Berlin, Germany. Film festivals have since then become showcases of national cinemas, eventually also functioning as both protectors of the cinematic art and facilitators of film industries. Soon after, there was a global spread of film festivals.

In 1966, Manila mayor Antonio J. Villegas inaugurated the Manila Film Festival. For the first time, locally produced films were screened in downtown theaters like Ideal, Odeon, State, Ever, Galaxy, and Capitol, which usually screened only Hollywood and foreign films. The festival provided respite from competition against Hollywood, giving Filipinos the opportunity to watch Tagalog pictures in Manila’s “first-class” theaters. Atty Espiridion Laxa served as chairman of the festival, which began on 14 Jun and culminated on 24 Jun, coinciding with the city’s foundation day. Eighteen local films (14 new, four re-releases) were screened. The top prize, the Rajah Soliman Grand Award for Best Picture, was given to Gerardo de Leon’s Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965.

During its first run, many journalists praised the festival as the much-needed government action that manifests their support for the local filmdom. However, through the years, critics dismissed the festival as merely token support that did not address the more pressing issues plaguing the industry. Critics pointed out that US-Philippine co-productions like The Brides of Blood Island, 1966, and The Passionate Strangers, 1966, were allowed into the festival on the grounds that they were locally produced with Filipino actors. Furthermore, critics pointed out that some of the festival’s box-office hits, like Tony Ferrer’s secret agent thrillers Sabotage, 1966, and Modus Opera ndi, 1967, seemed to be the most imitative of Hollywood.

In spite of the controversies and criticism, the festival lasted until 1974. Throughout its nine-year stint, the festival exhibited several popular films, such as Celso Ad. Castillo’s Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko (The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko), 1973, Luciano Carlos’s Dolphy-starrer Facifica Falayfay, 1969, German Moreno’s Guy and Pip, 1971, among others. In the last edition, the festival did not award the Rajah Soliman Grand Award to any of the competing films for the first time since its establishment.

The Manila Film Festival became the Metropolitan Film Festival in 1975, covering the Greater Manila Area. In 1977, the festival was renamed Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF). Under the new direction of the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association, the festival now encompassed the satellite cities that comprise Metro Manila. Today, the festival is presented by the Metro Manila Development Authority.

The first edition began on 21 Sep 1975 to commemorate the third anniversary of the imposition of martial law. A year after, the festival started on Christmas day for the first time. In its first year, Augusto Buenaventura’s Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), won the six major awards, including Best Picture. Films like Lino Brocka’s Bona, 1980, Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, Ishmael Bernal’s Himala (Miracle), 1982, and the Shake, Rattle & Roll horror anthology all premiered in the festival.

The festival’s 1986 edition was considered to be the worst in the festival’s 12-year history at the time. For the first time, no competing film was awarded Best Picture and Second Best Picture. Only a Third Best Picture was cited, Mario O’Hara’s Halimaw sa Banga (Monster in a Jar). Tingting Cojuangco, chair of the board of jurors, announced during the ceremonies that none of the seven competing films deserved the Best Picture award and that the entries did not “reinforce and inculcate positive Filipino values” as they were only “portraying negative stereotypes, imitating foreign films, and perpetuating commercially oriented movies” (quoted in Vera 2014).
