article.value: Music for the Silent Film
Music in Pre-World War II Sound Films
Film Music from 1946 to 2000
Film Music, 2000 to Present

Music in film refers to the music that accompanies visual images in film. Music that is part of the represented scene is termed diegetic or source music; that which is external to the narrative is termed non-diegetic or extradiegetic. In diegetic music, characters in the film can hear the music that is part of the fictional world being depicted or which they inhabit. This contrasts with the extradiegetic music, also called the score, which can only be heard by the audience.

Music has three fundamental functions in Philippine films: (1) as accompaniment to silent film images; (2) as scoring, using existing or original music, which deepens the mood of the scene and the emotions of characters; and (3) as theme song, the elements of which become the basis for further musical variations that enhance the visual sequences. In principle, the second and third uses may overlap as required by this integrative audiovisual medium.
Music for the Silent Film

The first film was shown in the Philippines on 8 Sep 1897 by Swiss business partners Leibman and Peritz. They screened several Lumiere films, using a lumiere cinematograph. The show was accompanied by music provided by a guitarist under maestro Francisco P. de Barbat. The next year, 1898, Antonio Ramos, a Spanish military officer from Barcelona presented his own program of films, including those that he himself had shot in the Philippines, like Escenas Callejeras (Street Scenes), Fiesta de Quiapo (Quiapo Fiesta), and Panorama de Manila (Manila Panorama). Ramos is considered the first person to shoot a film in Manila. In 1905, Herbert Wyndham of the Edison Biograph also shot scenes in the Manila Fire Department (Sotto 1992, 5-6).

The music accompaniment was needed in silent films to muffle the noise of the projector, which probably was overwhelming, given the fact that the early films in the Philippines were shown in a small room adjacent to a store and the audience was seated near the projector. Moreover, early films had to compete with live public entertainments such as bailes (dances held in clubs and theaters) and the popular sarsuwela.

From 1902 until the erection of Albert Yearsley’s Majestic Theater of 1912, which was large enough to be described as the first building solely dedicated to films, the screening of films, especially those managed by Walgraph, was billed with sarsuwela, songs, and musical interludes. But because they could not yet compete with the sarsuwela, which was the dominant genre of public entertainment, films rode on the popularity of the form. Thus, in 1906, the Cinematografo-Teatro Cervantes showed films as enticers, front acts, or divertissements to Praxedes Fernandez’s zarzuela, Sensitiva. In the advertisement for this zarzuela, the titles of films were not even announced, manifesting their low value compared to the main entertainment. Besides, up until 1909, only a limited number of films, mainly those from Pathe in France, were shown in Manila again and again, and so the medium quickly lost its novelty.

The orchestras for film were small chamber music ensembles, similar or identical to those that played in the sarsuwela. From 1902 to 1910, musicians involved in accompanying films were Jose Estella, with the Rizal orchestra quintet, at the Cinematografo-Teatro Nuevo Cervantes in 1905; Pedro Madariaga who directed music for the Gran Cinematografo Filipino in 1905 and the Gran Cinematografo del Oriente in 1906; Bonifacio Abdon, with Sexteto Orquesta Rizal, at the Gran Cinematografo-Teatro Cervantes in 1906; Manuel Egea who was in the Gran Teatro-Cinematografo Libertad; and Jose Vedal and Henri Niviere at the Walgraph. Except for Estella, a Filipino whose career was already well established in Manila, it was the foreign musicians who dominated the exhibition and marketing of film entertainment in Philippine cities. After Pedro Madariaga left the Gran Cinematografo del Oriente, Francisco Buencamino replaced him as the director of the orchestra. Estella, Abdon, and Buencamino were therefore three of the important film music practitioners in early silent films. From them, the next generation of urban Filipino musicians, such as piano players Francisco Santiago and Nicanor Abelardo, would learn how to eke out a living by playing the piano to accompany silent films.

In the absence of archival data, it is not known specifically how the chamber music ensembles or orchestras from 1902 to 1910, and later the piano, managed to accompany the films—specifically, how they matched their music to the visuals’ narratives. What is clear, however, is that music was still just an arbitrary accessory to the images because music was performed ad hoc and was external to its production; it was added later in real time and was not part of the making of the film product. The repertory of music in silent films came from different foreign sources; but as years went by, local music must have been used more and more. Evidence of many extant collections of semiclassical music for small ensembles and piano albums from the period, many of which had simplified arrangements of popular classical music, would seem to prove that film musicians were quite equipped to tackle the wide range of moods and sentiments embodied in the projected images and narratives.

When the first American-owned movie production companies started to produce original films in the 1910s, there was an impetus to make music more expressive of the film’s narrative, and sounds began to be organically connected to the visuals. Scoring, which appropriated canned music, was made through phonographs and records when these became available beginning 1910. Some theater owners utilized gramophones to substitute for live music performance in order to fill in the aural vacuum in silent films and to save up on the cost of employing live musicians.

Canned music paralleled the stock music in albums which comprised of classical music with light and easy arrangements that were played by small music ensembles and pianists. However, phonographs were fragile machines with tiny sounds and not as reliable as pianos whose industrial cast-iron strength and versatility were unmatched by any other instrument. In some cases, the songs that were supposed to be performed by actors on-screen were dubbed live by actors who sang behind the screen, in sync with the screen images. In Jose Nepomuceno’s production of Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), a film adaptation of the highly successful Hermogenes Ilagan-Leon Ignacio sarsuwela of the same title in 1919, Atang de la Rama herself came on stage to sing “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Claypot Broke) in sync with the movements of her own image on-screen.

The decade of 1910s was an important time in Philippine film history, for it was then when films began to be locally produced. Then American resident Albert Yearsley was said to be the first to produce films locally. These were mostly documentaries of local events and historical subjects. His sensational 20-minute fictional film on the death of Rizal titled La Pasion y Muerte de Dr. Rizal (The Passion and Death of Dr Rizal), alternately called El Fusilamiento de Dr. Jose Rizal (The Execution of Dr Jose Rizal), was hurriedly shot in 1912 to compete with the American tandem of Harry Brown and Edward Meyer Gross who were going to screen in the same month the hour-long La Vida de Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal). What types of music accompanied these two Rizal films are not known, but by that time, there were already numerous pieces of music commemorating Rizal’s death and heroism that musicians could choose from. Later on, American films that were locally produced depicted cultural practices like the pilgrimage to Antipolo, which both Yearsley and Brown-Gross produced.

In the 1920s, Nicanor Abelardo’s generation was succeeded by musicians like Spanish criollo Benito Trapaga, Miguel Velarde Jr, Juan Silos Jr, Leon Ignacio, Constancio de Guzman, Ariston Avelino, Tito Arevalo, Santiago Suarez, and Spanish expatriate concert pianist Julio Esteban Anguita. There were no hard-and-fast rules on how the necessary piano music supplement could be realized in theater. But considering the expertise of Filipino musicians in composing for live musical theater, local music such as kundiman, balitaw, and danza must have been utilized to meet the emotional requirements of the scenes.

The practice of using canned music during the silent film era was to continue in sound films from the 1930s all the way to 1960s. It is still practiced in contemporary TV production. Canned music is properly called appropriated scores, which means music by composers other than the music director of the film, and it was definitely inferior to live performances, which were tailored to the specific communicative requirement of the film’s narrative. Besides, canned music can never fully express the complexity of moods and emotions in a film.

The extant scores of Jose Estella’s “Un Escena Musical en Antipolo” (A Musical Scene in Antipolo) and “Es La Virgen de Antipolo: Escena 161” (It’s the Virgin of Antipolo: Scene 161), now archived at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music Library, are original film music scores made either for Yearsley’s or Brown-Gross’s film in the mid-1910s or perhaps during the early 1930s. Which version was composed for whose film on Antipolo cannot be determined. The number “161” marked on the piece “Es La Virgen de Antipolo” in red-colored pencil would suggest that this score was linked to an original playscript, which may have been for a silent or a sound film. Other extant Jose Estella film music scores of the period that are now in UP are “Ang Buhay ng Mangingisda” (The Life of a Fisherman), a song from the film Ang Uliran (The Ideal) with words by Ilagan, and “Apache Vals.”
Music in Pre-World War II Sound Films

The establishment of the movie studio system in the country—with companies like the Nepomuceno-Harris-Tait partnership Filippine Films, 1934; Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, 1935; Sampaguita, 1937; LVN, 1939; and X’Otic Films, 1939—was a watershed in the history of Philippine film music. The task of synchronizing dialogue and environment sound with image involved other tasks such as dubbing, music recording, playback recording (a type of lip-synching), and rerecording. A well-known singer who did the singing voice of non-singing vedettes was Fely Vallejo, who later married director Gerardo de Leon. The clapper device was necessary for syncing sound recording and image into separate tracks in the reels.

Film music score, technically speaking, therefore only arrived when the talking picture or sound movie technology became available. The first film of this kind in the Philippines was George Musser’s Ang Aswang (The Aswang) produced by Manila Talktone in 1932. Not long after, Jose Nepomuceno, the “Father of Philippine Movies,” made Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger), 1933, the first Filipino sound film. At that time, because the technology was new and the synchronization of sound and image was a challenge, Nepomuceno had to seek the help of American producer George Harris and his Hollywood technical team. Because there is no extant copy of Nepomuceno’s film, one is deprived of describing the film score as an object of analysis and criticism. Nonetheless, in Harris’s film Zamboanga, 1936, which was a joint project of Filipino and foreign technical crews, one witnesses the incorporation of classic Hollywood techniques in Edward Kilenyi’s film scoring, which was composed in Hollywood.

There are five extant films from 1938 to 1941, which allow us to discuss the different uses of film music before it blossomed in the 1950s, a golden age of Philippine cinema. These films were Zamboanga, 1937, directed by Eduardo de Castro; Giliw Ko (My Love), directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, 1939; Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), directed by Octavio Silos, 1939; Pakiusap (Plea), directed by Octavio Silos, 1940; and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), directed by Vicente Salumbides and Manuel Conde, 1941. Zamboanga was a south sea adventure film, Giliw Ko and Pakiusap were romances, Tunay na Ina was a melodrama with music, and Ibong Adarna was mythological. Their being musical unmistakably had its influence from the Filipino sarsuwela tradition, and therefore they can be called sarsuwela films —a term Nicanor Tiongson coined for films that are made in the sarsuwela tradition, as opposed to filmed sarsuwela or an already existing sarsuwela made into film like Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat (No Wounds). Sarsuwela film music style was one that developed internally, even if there were some influences from Hollywood. Other sarsuwela films were Carlos Vander Tolosa’s Nasaan Ka Irog (Where Are You, Beloved?) 1937, Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937, and Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938; Octavio Silos’s Paruparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1938; and Santiago Suarez’s Magbalik Ka Hirang (Come Back, My Love), 1940. No copies of these films have survived, however.

The majority of the musical numbers in these pre-World War II films were newly composed by Edward Kilenyi for Zamboanga, Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino for Giliw Ko, Miguel Velarde Jr and Juan Silos Jr for Pakiusap, Miguel Velarde Jr for Tunay na Ina, and Francisco Buencamino Sr with his son Francisco Jr for Ibong Adarna.

Zamboanga is an interesting film because it contains actual footage of the Muslim war dance sagayan, accompanied by authentic diegetic kulintang (brass gongs of graduated sizes) music. Its newly composed extradiegetic score for the dramatic actions, however, came from the convention of Hollywood, which uses a lush, late 19th-century romantic symphonic sonority, which has nothing to do with the Southeast Asian musical traditions.

In Giliw Ko, many songs and dances were diegetic. This is so because the story revolves around Guia, a barrio lass who aspires to be an urbanite singer, following her attraction to the landlord’s Americanized son Antonio, a musician. The matching of the characters’ identities and musical styles are apt and convincing. Well-thought-out is the imaginary scene showing the blind old man, the father of Jose who belonged to the peasant class and therefore more suited to be Guia’s partner, playing an instrument of the poor, a bamboo cello or musikong bumbong. In this scene, the blind old man is hearing an extradiegetic music, as if telepresencing his auditors, the moviegoers, who are outside the screen’s reality. What is remarkable in this scene is that it happens at around the time when the hacienda owners are listening to the voice of country girl Guia via the cosmopolitan radio, thus producing a parallelism, a poignant layering that mirrors what the old man is hearing. The intelligent musical plan in the scene clearly manifests Silos’s sensitivity to the difference between diegetic and extradiegetic music.

The success in matching song genres with characterization is also evident in the other three extant films. In Pakiusap, the male protagonist named Ernesto sings Santiago’s kundiman “Pakiusap” in an uncannily haunting scene by a river beside a nipa hut, which is the abode of his beloved Amparing. This song is the theme song of the movie, so to speak. In a romantic scene when Ernesto, the landlord’s son, disguises himself as a peasant so he can approach Amparing in the fields, the danza "Buhat," one of Velarde’s most beloved songs, captures beautifully the coquettish lightness of the first encounter between the soon-to-be lovers. In Tunay na Ina, the unwed mother named Magdalena (named after the biblical figure) intones the "Ave Maria" in Latin as a song of mourning—a funeral song in front of the tomb of her father. Oppressed by conservative patriarchal values, Magdalena has to relinquish her motherly right to raise an illegitimate daughter to protect her family’s honor. The song expresses the pain of her subjection to a cruel social world, which she cannot transcend. In Ibong Adarna, the bird sings exotic coloratura runs—a Spanish mannerism—as if this were the bird’s language from a past and distant world.

Moreover, in these extant films, diegetic music correctly gives viewers a sense of Filipino lifeworlds: musikong bumbong orchestra and jazz orchestra as symbols of rural and urban spaces, respectively, in Giliw Ko; marching brass bands and rondalla in Pakiusap; and even fantastical Filipino orientalist imagination of distant places in Ibong Adarna. Sentimental scenes of longing are captured by kundiman songs, coquettish romance by the danza especially in Pakiusap, and humor by the dirty songs of lowly “clownish” characters. In these song-and-dance numbers, one feels a manifestation of a distinctly Filipino sensibility. They have no counterpart elsewhere because they are rooted in the tradition of the indigenized sarsuwela. Even the convention of composing the music of opening and closing credits owes to the tradition of writing overtures, entr’acte, and finales of sarsuwela music.

While Giliw Ko, Pakiusap, Tunay na Ina, and Ibong Adarna are effective as sarsuwela films, specifically in correlating the characters with music genres and in rendering the liveliness of scenes through the kinetic spectacle of festive celebration, folk dancing, and collective music making, the dramatic articulation of the four films’ narratives generally fails to be at par with the musical and dance numbers. The function of the extradiegetic music to articulate the dramatic element is important, and it is this function that moves the story to action and suspense, thereby generating the film’s energy and intensity. Except for Giliw Ko, the films rely heavily on stock musical formulas or canned music in most of their extradiegetic music in rendering dramatic scenes. In Pakiusap, for example, Bach’s Air in G is used to simply fill in the passage of time as the distraught Amparing tries to borrow money that she needs to bail out her imprisoned father. The effect of this appropriated music is static, for it simply judges Amparing to be already pitiable and does not draw in the audience to increasing empathy. In Ibong Adarna, the horse chase depicting Juan abducting Maria and bringing her to his kingdom is accompanied by the orchestra playing the clichéd passage of 16 notes from Rossini’s William Tell Overture .In the next scene, while Maria stays in an inn, dialogues are backgrounded, as in melodrama, with inert appropriated—even ballet-like—symphonic music coming from a played-back sound recording machine that does not relate in any way to the emotional cues of danger and anxiety that Maria is facing. Canned extradiegetic music is all the more glaring in Tunay na Ina where it is used, as in Pakiusap, as a melodramatic filler, thus failing to make the audience understand the complex dramatic emotions that Magdalena as a mother has to struggle with vis-à-vis the loss of her daughter—that is, between her biological instinct to care for her and the cruel and unjust patriarchally ordered social world that took her daughter away from her.

In the said pre-World War II films, the practice of canned music seems to be, on the one hand, a legacy of the less-planned matching of music score to visuals from the silent film era, during which time extradiegetic music simply filled in the acoustic space, without a careful planning of the score to move the dramatic shape of sound into a cohesive multimedia. On the other, this kind of scoring may have been influenced by the formulaic melodramatic music of soap operas of radio programs that had to cut down on the high cost of composing and recording original scores. Canned music was to survive many more decades and was even evident in the best dramatic films that the Philippines had made during the 1970s and 1980s.
Film Music from 1946 to 2000

Film music in Philippine cinema during the postwar era was greatly influenced by the need to rehabilitate and uplift the Filipinos’ war-torn spirits. The tradition of theater and entertainment from American musicals and vaudeville became staples for many films during this era. The primary studios then—LVN Pictures, Sampaguita Pictures, and Premiere Productions (founded 1946)—mostly came up with films that provided escape for the audience. Thus production numbers, songs, and dances, just like the musical stage shows in the old Manila opera houses, were integrated into the film narratives. LVN’s producer Doña Narcisa Buencamino de Leon, or Doña Sisang to her colleagues, opted to produce films based on metrical romances such as Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939; Ibong Adarna, 1941 and 1955; and Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954. Correspondingly, the type of music and soundtrack used in these films accompanied the dances and movements required by the film genre, while traditional music, folk songs, kundiman music, and Spanish-influenced music filled the aural atmosphere of the films. The acoustic texture also coincided with the producer’s vision to portray Filipino countryside life and tradition through the music and dances. In the film Barrio Fiesta, 1959, the effervescence of the festivities was expressed through a merriment of guitar tunes and songs, and playful frenzy between the ladies and the men from the barrio.

Dominating the decade were prominent film scorers such as Francisco Buencamino, whose score for the film Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), 1950, featured the titular song composed by Nicanor Abelardo. Buencamino also created the film score for Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959, which used Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kundiman ng Luha” (Love Song of Tears) as theme song. This is a film reminiscent not of the festive music of the town’s celebration but of the rhythm produced by the pounding of a mortar and pestle which uniquely transitioned from a diegetic sound to non-diegetic, depicting the lives of people from the countryside. Another one of his works was the score for Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, a film portraying the plight of the impoverished, which was a complete departure from the usually cheerful song-and-dance movie theme. The film’s theme, “Anak Dalita,” a kundiman composed by Francisco Santiago with lyrics by Jesus Balmori and Deogracias Rosario, was an apt rendition and orchestration of the postwar crises faced by the Filipinos. It showed the ruins of the Manila Cathedral, displaced families, makeshift shelters, and a bleak picture of a dying woman whose last wish was to see her only son who was sent to war. Other notable film scorers of this era, who continued with their craft until the 1960s, were Carlos Aguilar, Tito Arevalo, Ariston Avelino, Josefino Cenizal, Joe Climaco, F. H. Constantino, Constancio de Guzman, Juan Silos Jr, Leopoldo Silos, Santiago Suarez, Restie Umali, Mike Velarde, and Joaquin Velasco.

Aside from the use of traditional folk songs, Juan Silos Jr also composed music that had sprightly rhythms, influenced by the tango and the polka, and were used to accompany vibrant film visuals. His works were mostly heard in films that showcased romantic comedy narratives starring Nestor de Villa and Nida Blanca, who depicted a boisterous tandem dancing spiritedly to fast-paced tunes and songs that were later on played in jukeboxes and over the airwaves. Among these films were Waray-Waray , 1954; Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955; and Bahala Na (Come What May), 1957. In an interview (Mercado 1977), Silos said that he was being very modest when he said that the music in a film actually is the reason why a film becomes a blockbuster.

Music and sound heavily influence the audience’s reaction and patronization of the films. Some Filipino films used Western canned music instead of original film compositions as soundtracks, an observation that received a stark commentary from film critic Pio de Castro (Del Mundo 1986). Jukebox film musicals that starred Diomedes Maturan, a young singer and Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) champion, captivated the audience in the late 1950s and early 1960s. His film Rose Tattoo ng Buhay Ko (Rose Tattoo of My Life), 1958, was a romance musical about an amateur singer who won a national contest, and it launched Maturan’s career with LVN. The song was initially sung and popularized by a British solo singer named Lita Roza in 1956. Maturan also starred in comedy musicals such as Botika sa Baryo (Pharmacy in the Barrio), 1960, and Prinsipe Diomedes at ang Mahiwagang Gitara (Prince Diomedes and the Magical Guitar), 1961, both scored by Francisco Buencamino, and filled with lively musical and dance numbers. He was also the lead for other film musicals such as Oy, Akin Yata Yan (Hey, I Think That Is Mine), 1962 and Yeba Chiquicha, 1963, which were both scored by Leopoldo Silos.

The late 1960s to the early 1970s was a continuation of romance musicals, especially with the rise of the young singing love team of Nora Aunor and Tirso Cruz III. Their film musicals included Guy and Pip, 1971; My Blue Hawaii, 1972; and Winter Holiday, 1972. Many of their films were musicals featuring song-and-dance numbers and using mostly foreign pop hits. The song “Alone Again (Naturally),” written and originally performed by Irish singer-songwriter Gilbert Sullivan, was sung by Nora Aunor as the theme song for A Gift of Love, 1972, which was filmed in the United States. Film critics of this era lamented the commercialization of musicals, which merely cashed in on the popularity of the Aunor-Cruz tandem while perpetuating the use of canned foreign music in the film scores (del Mundo, in Tiongson 1983).

The mid-1970s to the early 1980s presented a counterpoint in film narratives, deviating from the long period of preoccupation with musicals and shifting to narratives that portray social and political realities while employing film aesthetic techniques from the West. Film music and sound went along with these changes, so visual narratives were now accompanied and relayed not by repetitive canned foreign music but by original, restrained tunes that communicated the sensibility and timbre of the issues articulated by the films. The Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, a reputable film critics organization formed in 1976, handed out the Best Musical Score award only to films that use original music, preferably music created solely for the film itself. This award thrusts the film composer and scorer into the limelight.

Max Jocson was a frontrunner in film music scoring during this period, with his well-received scores for Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila in the Claws of Light), 1975, and Itim (The Rites of May), 1976. Both scores conveyed the films’ temperament, highlighting the range of his musical capabilities. In Itim, the music was interwoven within the dynamics of both pagan and Catholic rituals, in between the anguished sounds of a distressed spirit during a séance and the sorrowful chants of the townsfolk during a pabasa (chanting of the passion of Christ). The music tracks created by the synthesizer were jarring but not overpowering, haunting but not horrifying, and melancholic but not melodramatic. Jocson’s intentional irregular melodies and abruptly ended tones coincided with the combination of the mystery, darkness, and somehow the eerie solemnity in the film’s scenes. Vanishing Tribe, a band composed of four members, used electronic music for the scores of Jaguar (Guard), 1979, and Manila by Night, 1980. For both film scores, the band employed a jazz-funk fusion aura for the sinister and dark character of the city spaces explored in the film narratives.

Another noteworthy film scorer for this decade was Minda Azarcon, a famous opera singer in the 1970s, who created the scores for Insiang, 1976, and Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976. Insiang opens with a melodramatic track against the backdrop of the 1970s urban life in Tondo, Manila—the garbage dump that coincides with the raucous environment, vulgar language, and chaos that envelope the community where Insiang lives. The rape and violence she endures in the hands of her mother’s lover are foreshadowed by repeating snippets of initially soft melodies, which transform into quivers of malice as these are accompanied by the sound of running water from the faucet. The soft melodies eventually become sinister and dark, and the squeals of animals in the slaughterhouse at the beginning of the film are replaced by screams of a rapist butchered by his former lover. Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos has the same ominous timbre; the gloomy bass and organ tones are piled up along with the corpses and remains in the midst of death and destruction essayed by World War II and the Japanese occupation in the Philippines.

Lutgardo Labad scored important films such as Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976, and Bona, 1980, and highlighted his flexibility and originality as a film composer. In Ganito, guitar and string melodies, as well as patriotic themes, complement the film’s Spanish setting and aid in recreating the context of the Philippine Revolution through the eyes of a simpleminded peasant, Kulas. Bona is all about the sacrifice and irrational servitude of Bona to an aspiring actor, which is mirrored in the simple, repetitive percussion sound sequences that compose her character’s leitmotif. The beats and cadences are like Bona’s daily expressions of devotion to an abusive object of affection such as the chores and errands that occupy her day in a life of masochistic subservience. Ryan Cayabyab did the scores for Aguila, 1980, and Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983. In Aguila, Cayabyab creates a melodious theme song that varies to suit the temper of each scene and generally weaves in and out of the different types of music he uses to characterize each major period from the 1890s to the 1980s. In Karnal, Cayabyab’s powerful orchestra music adeptly matches, balances, and supplements the themes of family tragedy and the cruelty of patriarchy in the film. From soft and deceivingly tender tones to soaring and shrill sounds, the music tracks carefully narrates the tension, violence, and darkness that plagued the family.

Many dramatic films from the 1980s widely used original Filipino compositions as titular theme music. The practice of using Western canned music was replaced by the use of original film tracks, if not original Filipino pop songs or ballads. Filipino ballads composed by Willy Cruz, George Canseco, and Rey Valera became theme songs for various local films in the 1980s and 1990s that capitalized on the genre of melodrama. The film narratives were woven around these songs. Willy Cruz’s “Bituing Walang Ningning” (Star without Sparkle), 1985, and “Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas” (I Wish This Were Forever), 1986, both titular theme songs, were sung by the lead film actress for both films, Sharon Cuneta. Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (Wishing It Would Never End) used the theme song’s fragments throughout the film, narrating the scenes of three female singers brought together by friendship, broken apart by jealousy, and eventually reunited through music. The titular theme song, which was sung at the end of the film, was an homage to the father of the lead character, who also composed the song before his death. George Canseco’s “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan” (How Often Is Once), 1982, and “Sinasamba Kita” (I Worship You), 1983, were also recognized by award-giving bodies, with the former winning Best Theme Song and the latter Best Original Song. Rey Valera’s compositions became popular movie theme songs in the early 1990s. Some of these were “Maging Sino Ka Man” (Whoever You May Be), 1991, sung by Sharon Cuneta, and “Di Na Natuto” (You Never Learn), 1993, sung by Gary Valenciano. These theme songs were constantly played on the radio and topped the original Pilipino music charts, and records and cassette tapes of these were sold out.

Film music themes since the 1990s were a combination of both Filipino and Western pop hits. Cayabyab continued to create scores that employed his own compositions and original Filipino music, two of which were Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991, and Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993. The song “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (Until the End of Eternity), composed by George Canseco, was the theme song for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit, and “Saan Ka Man Naroroon,” composed by Restie Umali, was for the movie with the same title. Dionisio Jose “Nonong” Buencamino Jr did the score and theme song for Natutulog Ba ang Diyos (Is God Sleeping), 1988, with the titular theme music sung by Gary Valenciano. He also created the scores for May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993, with the theme music composed by Willy Cruz and sung by Rachel Alejandro; for Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You), 1993, composed by Manuel Mallilin and sung by Ogie Alcasid; and for Sana Dalawa ang Puso Ko (Wish I Had Two Hearts), 1995, composed by Bodjie Dasig and sung by Ariel Rivera. Buencamino also lent his musical skills to do the scores for Milagros, 1997, and Jose Rizal, 1998, which both won honors at the Gawad Urian. His film music contributions continued up to the new millennium. With the songs being played on the radios and sung by the singers on television, and with the advent of better sound quality through CD players, the rise of the artists in the 1990s, such as Valenciano, Alcasid, Alejandro, and Rivera, reinforced how the audience recognized and supported the films with titular theme songs, similar to the film-theme music partnership in the 1950s.

Other film composers who were usually tapped by both mainstream and independent productions in the 1990s and 2000s were Jesse Lucas, Jessie Lasaten, Joy Marfil, and Vincent de Jesus. Jesse Lucas created the score for Babae sa Breakwater (Woman of Breakwater) and put into good use the songs of Yoyoy Villame, which can be categorized as novelty songs about the lives of the ordinary folk. Villame’s witty rhymes and upbeat rhythms are realized within the film’s desolate themes of urban migration and urban poverty. Soft music tracks also contrast Villame’s lively limericks, allowing the viewer/listener space to balance out the varied melodies. Jessie Lasaten’s work in Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996, foregrounds the familiar sounds of the business districts of Metro Manila where the main character Karen is an insurance agent by day and a guest relations officer in a karaoke bar by night. Karaoke pop songs and the lively ballroom dance music begin to fade and are replaced with slow, sad tunes once Karen sets foot on her lahar-stricken hometown in Pampanga. And an innocent lullaby accompanies her bedtime stories while she puts her child to sleep, and signals another dizzying day of traveling back to the city. Joy Marfil’s work for Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002, brims with hope and idealism, just like its main character Melinda, a young substitute teacher who chooses to serve in a public school in a remote province. Poverty and political unrest beleaguer the community, and the only respite of the children from this predicament is Melinda’s effort to inspire them to hone their singing talents and participate in a local contest. The song’s theme song, “Mga Munting Tinig,” is sung at the end of the film to remember one of the fallen choir members who became a victim of a clash between the military and the rebels.

Vincent de Jesus’s film scores for Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh (Zsazsa Zaturnnah: The Movie), 2006, and I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012, are well-known. In contrast to the film musicals in the 1970s, the songs for these films are local and original. De Jesus created the music for Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh, an adaptation of Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah), published in 2003 and also adapted into stage by Tanghalang Pilipino in 2005 in which de Jesus was the lyricist, composer, and musical director. The film’s opening scene sets the mood for the entire film—a vivacious production number with characters singing and dancing in the rain, not like Gene Kelly’s and Debbie Reynold’s stylized version but capturing local color, complete with Manila’s enormous puddles and hopeful teens hoping for a cancellation of classes. I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! starts with a medley of songs from the Apo Hiking Society, the pop trio with the longest staying power in the country. The film is a scrapbook of pop music, gaudy costumes, and color splattered across the backdrop of Manila’s bustle, its streets, landmarks, and daily commute. The images alternate with the medley’s vibrancy and the flamboyance of the characters, which include a young couple expecting a child and are torn between their respective families.

For some films during the late 1990s to the early 2000s, the theme music became the blueprint for the other film tracks. Same tunes were carved from the main theme song and spread out as fragments of music throughout the film’s scenes, using a variety of instrumentations. This could have helped create a musical leitmotif for a specific character or space, but the repetitive tunes simply added to the recall of the theme song, instead of creating a tenuous synchronization of image and sound.

Mainstream and major production studios dictate the use of foreign popular songs as film titles, and some films in the 2000s repeated the earlier practice of using Western canned music, some of which were even initially used already as foreign film theme music and as foreign film titles. Some examples include Till There Was You, 2003, produced by Star Cinema and Let the Love Begin, 2005, produced by GMA Films. “Till There Was You,” a song written by Meredith Wilson in 1957, was also the title of a 1997 Hollywood romantic comedy film, produced by Lakeshore Entertainment and directed by Scott Winant. “Let the Love Begin” was written by Gloria Sklerov and Lenny Macaluso and was also used as a theme for the American movie Thrashin, 1986. For the Filipino film title adaptations, the popular songs were used not only as a means to boost the careers of the pop artists who sang the movie themes but also as a marketing strategy to sell the film and the CD soundtrack that came with it.
Film Music, 2000 to Present

The advancements in digital film at the start of the millennium pose more opportunities not only for independent filmmakers but for film music composers as well. With independent production comes more freedom in creative expression, versatility, and innovation in the use of sound and music apparatus, especially since the members of the film crew are no longer under the watchful eyes and control of a mainstream production studio. There is no need to create a contrived film narrative that could match a foreign or local pop hit, and the film scorer can focus on his/her individual artistic freedom.

Composers and musicians who are products of independent film festivals, such as Cinemalaya and Cinema One Originals, and other independent productions contribute to the growing list of film scorers. With the available technology, these composers have become more daring, experimenting with the different permutations of sound and instrumentation and allowing them further diversity and variation in the creation of film sound tracks.

Teresa Barrozo’s film score for Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, won at Sitges Catalonian International Film Festival for Best Original Soundtrack and demonstrated her prowess in revealing the character’s gradual mental torment through the use of a metal pad decay’s sharpness and thinness, and an oboe’s glissando. Diwa de Leon’s work in Busong (Palawan Fate), 2011, offered a fresh and crisp dimension to Filipino indigenous instruments such as the mouth harp and native flute when he used them to accompany the main character Punay as she embarked on a journey to find a cure for her mysterious affliction. Francis de Veyra’s music in Tribu (Tribe), 2007, featured the rap culture in the ghetto district of Tondo, Manila. The poetic street rhythms and amateur beatboxing dialogued with the danger and adrenaline rush of the proliferation of Tondo’s gang wars and petty crimes. Francis Reyes collaborated with musicians Jett Pangan (lead vocalist of The Dawn) and Buddy Zabala to create the soundtrack of Tulad ng Dati (Just Like Before), 2006, which featured the songs of the famous 1990s band The Dawn. The film used a semidocumentary format and revolved around the Filipino rock band’s members, central of which was Jett Pangan’s character.

Popong Landero, a composer and actor from Mindanao, did the music for Hunghong sa Yuta (Earth ’s Whisper), 2008. Landero’s music explored the vestiges of war. The deafening sounds of guns and grenades destroyed the hearing of the children living in the remote town of Hinyok. Somehow, music allowed for the articulation of these children who spoke using only hand gestures. Jerrold Tarog’s work in Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria (The Dream of Eleuteria), 2010, accentuated the film’s landscape, Olango Island, where Eleuteria was sent off by an entourage of townspeople as she slowly, and eventually, accepted her fate as a mail-order bride. Emerzon Texon’s music in Sonata , 2013, delved into an opera singer’s loss of voice, which led to the decline in her career and her self-destructive tendencies. In between the classical tunes and string melodies, she found redemption in her friendship with a kind boy from her hometown.

The development in sound technology was crucial in the transitions in Philippine film music and sound. The variations in the reverberation levels and quality of sound and music in films, the types of microphones used over the decades, the differences in methods of recording sound, and the diversities in mixing practices, all contributed to the work of the film scorer and the audience’s reception of the film music and sound. Technology allowed for a more polished and crisp sound color and quality, which gave leverage and freedom to the scorer and sound designer to explore more potentials in film scoring. The early decades dealt with the issue of matching reverberation quality to specific scenes or spaces. Thus the playback system was developed, which was a way to record the music separately in a conducive atmosphere to come up with the illusion that the sound was created by the image, where in fact, it was independent from it. From the playback system, some film scorers in the latter decades (1990s to present) also experimented with the use of live music in the film scenes.

Beginning 1990s, contemporary film and sound studios use more advanced and sophisticated sound engineering equipment. With the different computer music programs available for free download or purchase such as Audacity, Logic Pro, and LinuxSampler, the film scorer is now able to manipulate how sound and music can be designed and how these elements can effectively shape the viewers’ understanding of visual images on the screen. It is now easier for the scorer to fuse diegetic and non-diegetic sound and music, with a clarity and smoothness of transition and flow. Technology has also paved the way for higher quality of music embedded in, or accompanied by, soundscapes.

Film composer Teresa Barrozo explained that the collaboration between a film composer and a sound designer is important because with the designer’s mastery of the sound equipment, he or she can create the specific, high-quality sound or tone needed by the composer to accompany his or her music. When she worked on the music for the film Kinatay, the drone sound produced from the sound designer’s end effectively complemented the glissando sound created by her oboe instrumentation. She also added that a film composer’s music composition is not realized until it is tested and implemented into a concrete sound space; in this aspect, the sound designer and sound engineer aid in maximizing the use of technology to further enhance the composer’s creation, thus delivering an enriched and heightened multisensory experience for the listener/audience (Barrozo 2015).

The use of computer music programs also gives the scorer flexibility and can prove to be more cost-efficient most of the time, compared to live studio film music recording. An example of which is producing a full orchestra track, without the need to hire an actual orchestra. The downside of this, however, is the possible lack of authenticity in sound as it is a mere sampling of the instruments. Thus some scorers still opt for the actual orchestra, quartet, or band, and live recording, instead of relying on the computer programs, so as not to sacrifice the quality and original timbre of the required music or sound for the film.
Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo and Jema Pamintuan

text:
In the Philippines, organizations related to film are of different types and compositions. While most of them are of a voluntary or nongovernment nature, they vary according to the purpose for which they are established. There are associations of film artists and technicians whose goals are to institute training and development, promote professionalism, and recognize excellence in members’ achievements. There are associations formed to protect common interests, acting as a powerful lobby against various threats to the well-being of their members. There are associations of movie writers and film critics that seek to foster and elevate the cinema to the level of art and meaningful cultural expression. And there are also independent film outfits and collectives that produce and offer alternative films outside mainstream productions.

 

In the early 1950s, the Big Four movie producers—Sampaguita, LVN, Premiere, and Lebran—organized the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association (PMPA). One of the requirements for membership in the PMPA was ownership and maintenance of a studio. Consequently, other producers who merely leased studio facilities and equipment could not get into the association. The situation drastically changed in the 1960s when import controls on raw stock and film equipment were lifted, thus giving way to decontrol. Anyone who had the means to buy raw film stock could purchase it anywhere: Eastman Kodak from the United States, Fuji from Japan, Ilford from England, and Agfa from Germany. The PMPA revised its policies and opened its doors to the other film producers. Many movie stars who turned producers swelled the ranks of the association, among the new outfits being FPJ, Virgo, RVQ, JE, and AM Films. The PMPA was renamed Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association (PMPPA).

 

 

By 1981 the original Big Four were no longer active in movie production: Lebran had bowed out early in 1957, LVN concentrated on its color film laboratory, while Sampaguita and Premiere opted to provide postproduction services to the industry. Sampaguita, LVN, and Premiere, however, still hold honorary membership status in the present PMPPA.

 

Another organization of producers and importers has since been established, the Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines (IMPIDAP). It is composed mostly of theater owners and film importers even if two of its more prominent members, Regal Films and Seiko Films, have become associated with local film production. The IMPIDAP numbers over 70 members who are consistently represented in film festivals and film marketing activities here and abroad.

 

 

In the 1950s, attempts were made to band film workers together in such organizations as the Motion Picture Guild of the Philippines, Philippine Motion Picture Workers Association, Cinema Workers Union of the Philippines, Premiere Productions Workers Union (PPWU), and Motion Picture Workers Union. The PPWU figured in a labor strike, which eventually led to the closure of Premiere Productions studio and the collapse of the studio system. But it was the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (Mowelfund) that proved viable among these workers’ groups. Since its establishment in 1974 by actor-producer turned Philippine president JosephEstrada, Mowelfund has provided welfare assistance to its less fortunate members and their dependents/beneficiaries in the form of medical services, hospitalization, and death insurance. Its educational arm, the Mowelfund Film Institute, provides the necessary funds, equipment, expertise, and scholarship for the continuing development of a wider base of filmmakers through training programs, seminars, and workshops.

 

Among the craft-oriented guilds, the two oldest are the cinematographers’ guild and the film editors’ guild. The former was earlier known as the Philippine Society of Cinematographers. In 1952, it was already listed in Vicente Salumbides’s book, Motion Pictures in the Philippines, as among the oldest associations of film professionals in the country. Later, it changed its name to Filipino Society of Cinematographers. From its ranks have emerged movie directors and filmmakers, such as Ben Pinga, Dik Trofeo, and the late Emmanuel Rojas who worked with Gerardo de Leon before becoming a movie director himself. The editors’ guild was formerly known as the Film Editors’ Union of the Philippines. It originally started as a union of film artisans out to protect the rights of its members by way of standardizing fees and adhering to acceptable working conditions. In 1981 it opted to become the Filipino Editors Guild for Motion Pictures (FEGMP), but it continues to regard itself as a labor union with economic matters receiving highest priority. It has over a hundred members composed of full editors, assistant film editors, and a number of apprentices or trainees. The members generally work as a team: a chief editor, one or two assistant editors, a negative cutter, and an apprentice or trainee who does the work of a joiner. The FEGMP has an organized secretariat that attends to its members’ needs, including working conditions and wages.

 

The Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) is the biggest organization in the cinema industry. Established by a presidential decree in 1981, it is an umbrella organization set up purposely to oversee the activities of the major guilds, associations, and institutions in the Philippine film industry. To date there are 14 autonomous, independent groups composing the FAP: Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association; Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines; Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino; Katipunan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino; Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines; Filipino Society of Cinematographers; Filipino Editors Guild for Motion Pictures; Sound Technicians Association for Motion Pictures; United Film Music Directors Association of the Philippines; Production Designers Guild of the Philippines; Assistant Directors and Production Managers Guild; Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc; Actors Workshop Foundation; and Organization of Specialized Filipino Filmmakers (OSFILM).

 

The youngest guild in the FAP is OSFILM. It was organized by Ben Pinga and Lamberto V. Avellana in 1989 to help develop and train young filmmakers. With the entry of OSFILM into the FAP, the country’s young filmmakers have gained some recognition from their co-practitioners in mainstream cinema.

 

In 1991, months after Lino Brocka’s death, a breakaway organization from the Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng mga Pelikulang Pilipino was formed due to some internal conflicts. Ishmael Bernal, later National Artist for Film, and several prominent film directors became instrumental in formalizing the Directors Guild of the Philippines Incorporated (DGPI). To date, DGPI is still active in recruiting members with credible bodies of work (Chionglo, pers. comm., 2015; Portes pers. comm., 2015).

 

The FAP gives awards annually to honor the important members of the industry and their outstanding achievements as well as pay tribute to the pillars and pioneers for their lifetime achievements. Voting is done by an electoral college in the FAP, and value is placed on peer recognition. During the 1990 FAP Awards, trophies, and citations were also awarded to young filmmakers who won in the short film and documentary categories.

 

In the local film industry are several theater associations. In the 1950s, there was only one theater association, the Manila Theaters Association (MTA) headed by Marcos Roces Sr. Toward the 1970s, the MTA became the Greater Manila Theaters Association (GMTA) while another group was formed, the Metro Manila Theaters Association (MMTA). The GMTA is known as the Roces-Rufino group and includes owners/operators of Avenue, Lyric, State, Ideal, Ever, Quezon, Quad, Remar, Maxim, Miramar, Roxan, Roben, Act, Luneta, Delta, Circle, Odeon, and Makati Cinema Square. The MMTA is known as the Tama-Monteverde group, which has Gotesco, Universal, Capri, Ali Mall, New Frontier, New Love, Galaxy, Dilson, Dynasty, Ocean, Sampaguita, Virra Mall, and Greenbelt Cinema. A third theater association, the Kapisanan ng mga Sinehan sa Pilipinas, is nationwide in scope. Some of its theaters belong to the association known as the Motion Pictures Export Association of America, composed of foreign film exchanges operating in the Philippines, like Paramount, Warner Bros, M-G-M, Universal, 20th Century Fox, and United Artists.

 

Outside the film industry are the movie press clubs, film critics organizations, and other award-giving bodies.

 

The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) is the oldest award-giving body in the country. Established in 1951 by a group composed mostly of movie journalists, it committed itself to the advancement of Filipino cinema by honoring the industry’s most outstanding achievements. At the start, FAMAS organizers envisioned an institution patterned after the United States Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, with its membership open to directors, actors, scriptwriters, musicians, and technicians. The FAMAS trophy or statuette would be the counterpart of the Hollywood “Oscar.” Over the years it lost most of its movie industry members and is now made up chiefly of writers, professionals, and civic-spirited individuals from different sectors of Philippine society.

 

The organization that gave birth to the FAMAS was the Movie Press Club of the Philippines. It is now known as the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) and is made up of movie press people who write for fan magazines, newspapers, and other publications that specialize in movie reporting. In 1984, the PMPC instituted its own Star Awards as an annual event, which it has continued to the present. However, in 2003, several members of the PMPC formed a breakaway organization called the Entertainment Press Society (ENPRESS). Just like the PMPC, the new group also instituted an annual event, the Golden Screen Awards.

 

The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) is the film critics’ organization. Established in 1976 by a group of 10 members—Nestor U. Torre, Bienvenido Lumbera, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Pio de Castro III, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Mario Hernando, Justino Dormiendo, Manuel Pichel, and Behn Cervantes—the MPP has espoused excellence in film art and craft. Composed mainly of critics and academicians, the MPP has since invited other film writers to join its ranks. Academic and popular venues and avenues for film criticisms and reviews have been employed by MPP. Members publish articles in scholarly journals and broadsheets and hold an annual event, the Gawad Urian. It has also published four volumes of its Urian anthology, which collects film writings of the group from 1970 to 2009.

 

In 1990, a group of academicians founded the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk. A year later, it held its first annual citation. The YCC Film Desk departed from the other award-giving bodies in the country for it only hands out seven awards: Best Film, Best Performance, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration, and Best First Feature Film. The members of the group are composed of professors and college instructors from different universities in Metro Manila (YCC Film Desk 2015).

 

The Philippine Cinematheque program serves as an alternative and accessible arena of local and foreign independent and art-house films outside Metro Manila. At present, the four regional cinematheques are located in Baguio, Iloilo, Davao, and Zamboanga (FDCP 2015).

 

The new wave in Philippine cinema and the arrival of digital technology also paved the way for independent film collectives. These film collectives aimed to contribute to the rise of the independent film movement in terms of output, scope of subject matter, and the process of production and reception. Most important film collective is the Independent Film Collective or IFC, which is currently chaired by Coreen Jimenez. For a few years IFC succeeded in asking Robinsons Cinema to devote one of its cinemas to the screening of mainly independent films.

 

Other film collectives produce and exhibit political works, usually documentaries, that aim to interrogate the ruling and dominant establishments. Political film collectives that are flourishing in the different regions and sectors in the country include Sine Patriyotiko, Kodao Productions, Tudla Productions, and Southern Tagalog Exposure (Tolentino 2009). These collectives usually hold screenings, educational discussions, and integrations in and with the community.

 

The Society of Film Archivists, a nonstock, nonprofit, and nongovernment organization, was organized in 1993. It is now known as the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film (SOFIA). It is a group of professionals who are passionate in archiving and preserving Filipino films. The group is known for conducting short-term trainings and workshops on retrieval and restoration of films that are close to being endangered. Through the assistance and help from the National Commission for the Culture and the Arts, SOFIA has managed to restore some old films.  Written by Lena S. Pareja and Justino Dormiendo,  with notes from Pio de Castro III, Bienvenido Lumbera, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Jay Jomar F. Quintos,  with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

article.value: In the early 1950s, the Big Four movie producers—Sampaguita, LVN, Premiere, and Lebran—organized the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association (PMPA). One of the requirements for membership in the PMPA was ownership and maintenance of a studio. Consequently, other producers who merely leased studio facilities and equipment could not get into the association. The situation drastically changed in the 1960s when import controls on raw stock and film equipment were lifted, thus giving way to decontrol. Anyone who had the means to buy raw film stock could purchase it anywhere: Eastman Kodak from the United States, Fuji from Japan, Ilford from England, and Agfa from Germany. The PMPA revised its policies and opened its doors to the other film producers. Many movie stars who turned producers swelled the ranks of the association, among the new outfits being FPJ, Virgo, RVQ, JE, and AM Films. The PMPA was renamed Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association (PMPPA).

article.value: By 1981 the original Big Four were no longer active in movie production: Lebran had bowed out early in 1957, LVN concentrated on its color film laboratory, while Sampaguita and Premiere opted to provide postproduction services to the industry. Sampaguita, LVN, and Premiere, however, still hold honorary membership status in the present PMPPA.

Another organization of producers and importers has since been established, the Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines (IMPIDAP). It is composed mostly of theater owners and film importers even if two of its more prominent members, Regal Films and Seiko Films, have become associated with local film production. The IMPIDAP numbers over 70 members who are consistently represented in film festivals and film marketing activities here and abroad.

article.value: In the 1950s, attempts were made to band film workers together in such organizations as the Motion Picture Guild of the Philippines, Philippine Motion Picture Workers Association, Cinema Workers Union of the Philippines, Premiere Productions Workers Union (PPWU), and Motion Picture Workers Union. The PPWU figured in a labor strike, which eventually led to the closure of Premiere Productions studio and the collapse of the studio system. But it was the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (Mowelfund) that proved viable among these workers’ groups. Since its establishment in 1974 by actor-producer turned Philippine president JosephEstrada, Mowelfund has provided welfare assistance to its less fortunate members and their dependents/beneficiaries in the form of medical services, hospitalization, and death insurance. Its educational arm, the Mowelfund Film Institute, provides the necessary funds, equipment, expertise, and scholarship for the continuing development of a wider base of filmmakers through training programs, seminars, and workshops.

Among the craft-oriented guilds, the two oldest are the cinematographers’ guild and the film editors’ guild. The former was earlier known as the Philippine Society of Cinematographers. In 1952, it was already listed in Vicente Salumbides’s book, Motion Pictures in the Philippines, as among the oldest associations of film professionals in the country. Later, it changed its name to Filipino Society of Cinematographers. From its ranks have emerged movie directors and filmmakers, such as Ben Pinga, Dik Trofeo, and the late Emmanuel Rojas who worked with Gerardo de Leon before becoming a movie director himself. The editors’ guild was formerly known as the Film Editors’ Union of the Philippines. It originally started as a union of film artisans out to protect the rights of its members by way of standardizing fees and adhering to acceptable working conditions. In 1981 it opted to become the Filipino Editors Guild for Motion Pictures (FEGMP), but it continues to regard itself as a labor union with economic matters receiving highest priority. It has over a hundred members composed of full editors, assistant film editors, and a number of apprentices or trainees. The members generally work as a team: a chief editor, one or two assistant editors, a negative cutter, and an apprentice or trainee who does the work of a joiner. The FEGMP has an organized secretariat that attends to its members’ needs, including working conditions and wages.

The Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) is the biggest organization in the cinema industry. Established by a presidential decree in 1981, it is an umbrella organization set up purposely to oversee the activities of the major guilds, associations, and institutions in the Philippine film industry. To date there are 14 autonomous, independent groups composing the FAP: Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association; Integrated Movie Producers, Importers, and Distributors Association of the Philippines; Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino; Katipunan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino; Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines; Filipino Society of Cinematographers; Filipino Editors Guild for Motion Pictures; Sound Technicians Association for Motion Pictures; United Film Music Directors Association of the Philippines; Production Designers Guild of the Philippines; Assistant Directors and Production Managers Guild; Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc; Actors Workshop Foundation; and Organization of Specialized Filipino Filmmakers (OSFILM).

The youngest guild in the FAP is OSFILM. It was organized by Ben Pinga and Lamberto V. Avellana in 1989 to help develop and train young filmmakers. With the entry of OSFILM into the FAP, the country’s young filmmakers have gained some recognition from their co-practitioners in mainstream cinema.

In 1991, months after Lino Brocka’s death, a breakaway organization from the Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng mga Pelikulang Pilipino was formed due to some internal conflicts. Ishmael Bernal, later National Artist for Film, and several prominent film directors became instrumental in formalizing the Directors Guild of the Philippines Incorporated (DGPI). To date, DGPI is still active in recruiting members with credible bodies of work (Chionglo, pers. comm., 2015; Portes pers. comm., 2015).

The FAP gives awards annually to honor the important members of the industry and their outstanding achievements as well as pay tribute to the pillars and pioneers for their lifetime achievements. Voting is done by an electoral college in the FAP, and value is placed on peer recognition. During the 1990 FAP Awards, trophies, and citations were also awarded to young filmmakers who won in the short film and documentary categories.

In the local film industry are several theater associations. In the 1950s, there was only one theater association, the Manila Theaters Association (MTA) headed by Marcos Roces Sr. Toward the 1970s, the MTA became the Greater Manila Theaters Association (GMTA) while another group was formed, the Metro Manila Theaters Association (MMTA). The GMTA is known as the Roces-Rufino group and includes owners/operators of Avenue, Lyric, State, Ideal, Ever, Quezon, Quad, Remar, Maxim, Miramar, Roxan, Roben, Act, Luneta, Delta, Circle, Odeon, and Makati Cinema Square. The MMTA is known as the Tama-Monteverde group, which has Gotesco, Universal, Capri, Ali Mall, New Frontier, New Love, Galaxy, Dilson, Dynasty, Ocean, Sampaguita, Virra Mall, and Greenbelt Cinema. A third theater association, the Kapisanan ng mga Sinehan sa Pilipinas, is nationwide in scope. Some of its theaters belong to the association known as the Motion Pictures Export Association of America, composed of foreign film exchanges operating in the Philippines, like Paramount, Warner Bros, M-G-M, Universal, 20th Century Fox, and United Artists.
Outside the film industry are the movie press clubs, film critics organizations, and other award-giving bodies.

The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) is the oldest award-giving body in the country. Established in 1951 by a group composed mostly of movie journalists, it committed itself to the advancement of Filipino cinema by honoring the industry’s most outstanding achievements. At the start, FAMAS organizers envisioned an institution patterned after the United States Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, with its membership open to directors, actors, scriptwriters, musicians, and technicians. The FAMAS trophy or statuette would be the counterpart of the Hollywood “Oscar.” Over the years it lost most of its movie industry members and is now made up chiefly of writers, professionals, and civic-spirited individuals from different sectors of Philippine society.

The organization that gave birth to the FAMAS was the Movie Press Club of the Philippines. It is now known as the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) and is made up of movie press people who write for fan magazines, newspapers, and other publications that specialize in movie reporting. In 1984, the PMPC instituted its own Star Awards as an annual event, which it has continued to the present. However, in 2003, several members of the PMPC formed a breakaway organization called the Entertainment Press Society (ENPRESS). Just like the PMPC, the new group also instituted an annual event, the Golden Screen Awards.

The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) is the film critics’ organization. Established in 1976 by a group of 10 members—Nestor U. Torre, Bienvenido Lumbera, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Pio de Castro III, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Mario Hernando, Justino Dormiendo, Manuel Pichel, and Behn Cervantes—the MPP has espoused excellence in film art and craft. Composed mainly of critics and academicians, the MPP has since invited other film writers to join its ranks. Academic and popular venues and avenues for film criticisms and reviews have been employed by MPP. Members publish articles in scholarly journals and broadsheets and hold an annual event, the Gawad Urian. It has also published four volumes of its Urian anthology, which collects film writings of the group from 1970 to 2009.

In 1990, a group of academicians founded the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk. A year later, it held its first annual citation. The YCC Film Desk departed from the other award-giving bodies in the country for it only hands out seven awards: Best Film, Best Performance, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration, and Best First Feature Film. The members of the group are composed of professors and college instructors from different universities in Metro Manila (YCC Film Desk 2015).

The Philippine Cinematheque program serves as an alternative and accessible arena of local and foreign independent and art-house films outside Metro Manila. At present, the four regional cinematheques are located in Baguio, Iloilo, Davao, and Zamboanga (FDCP 2015).

The new wave in Philippine cinema and the arrival of digital technology also paved the way for independent film collectives. These film collectives aimed to contribute to the rise of the independent film movement in terms of output, scope of subject matter, and the process of production and reception. Most important film collective is the Independent Film Collective or IFC, which is currently chaired by Coreen Jimenez. For a few years IFC succeeded in asking Robinsons Cinema to devote one of its cinemas to the screening of mainly independent films.

Other film collectives produce and exhibit political works, usually documentaries, that aim to interrogate the ruling and dominant establishments. Political film collectives that are flourishing in the different regions and sectors in the country include Sine Patriyotiko, Kodao Productions, Tudla Productions, and Southern Tagalog Exposure (Tolentino 2009). These collectives usually hold screenings, educational discussions, and integrations in and with the community.

The Society of Film Archivists, a nonstock, nonprofit, and nongovernment organization, was organized in 1993. It is now known as the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film (SOFIA). It is a group of professionals who are passionate in archiving and preserving Filipino films. The group is known for conducting short-term trainings and workshops on retrieval and restoration of films that are close to being endangered. Through the assistance and help from the National Commission for the Culture and the Arts, SOFIA has managed to restore some old films.
Written by Lena S. Pareja and Justino Dormiendo,
