text:
Producing refers to the process of preparing for, shooting, and completing the film. Film production encompasses three stages: preproduction, principal photography, and postproduction. Each phase is separate from the other although their activities may overlap in the course of movie production.

 

Preproduction involves the acquisition of the rights to the material (story, play, historical account, etc.) to be filmed, the appointment of a director who will be on top of the whole process of production, the writing of the screenplay or scenario treatment, as well as budgeting, casting, location hunting, building of sets, and preparing props, costumes, and special effects. All contracts and negotiations for services of other talents and personnel, as well as rentals of equipment and studio facilities, are finalized in the preproduction stage. When 35 mm film was the format for filmmaking, the availability of film stock and laboratory services had to be ensured to avoid delays during film production.

 

 

Transportation must be arranged, not only to deliver equipment and personnel to the location but also to retrieve equipment, and the like. Location filming includes both interior and exterior shooting. Permits are usually required in certain locations and should therefore be obtained in advance. Police clearance might also be needed in some circumstances. Provisions must be made for transportation, food, and lodging for production personnel. For big scenes that require more than one camera, an extra shooting unit may be contracted for in advance.

 

The kind of budget a film gets usually depends on the type of film as well as the bankability of its stars. Aside from the director’s fees and those for the principal cast and supporting players, items such as wages, overhead, transportation, overtime, insurance, copyright fees and other clearances, music rights, library stock footage, and special effects like prosthetics must be budgeted accordingly.

 

 

Principal photography is also known as production proper. This is the actual shooting phase of the film production. It begins with the first “take” on the set and ends with a “wrap” or “pack up” on the final shooting day. Upon completion of the principal photography phase, the shooting unit’s work is done but the other film personnel may still be involved in postproduction.

 

Postproduction refers to activities that include editing, sound transfers, sound effects, dubbing, and mixing. When film was the raw stock, a lot of laboratory work was done during postproduction, including optical transfers and the final processing that produces the composite mix. This traditional process ended with the “marrying” of sound and picture in one film negative, from which copies were made for distribution and exhibition.

 

 

The main person in charge is the producer. In the Philippines, the producer of a film may be any one or all of the following: the owner of a movie company, the investor or financier of a movie production, the highest executive in a multimedia company who is specifically in charge of the entertainment art and/or its most dominant platforms, the individual who makes the necessary arrangements for the making of a film or motion picture, or the person who is accountable for the success or failure of the movie in terms of box-office receipts and/or critical acclaim. Often, two or more of these functions are handled by one person.

 

Those who assist the investor of a film are the following. The executive producer is the individual in charge of the finances of the film from its moment of inception to development. He or she is the officer entrusted by the producer to ensure proper budgeting, disbursement, and even designing marketing strategies to put together and sell the film. The supervising producer is the conduit between the executive producer and the line producer. He or she is usually given the task of following through the project from inception to postproduction. The line producer is given a budget to deliver the film from preproduction until the finalization of the producer’s cut. He or she answers to the supervising and executive producers and must ensure that the movie’s quality is maintained while keeping within the budget. The associate producer works hand in hand with the line producer. He or she assists in the negotiations for below-the-line talents, technical and creative crew; helps prepare the budget; and coordinates with the production manager and postproduction coordinator. In the Philippine cinematic setting, however, the distinctions among these positions and occupations become blurred for practical and economic reasons.

 

Although it is the director who dominates the entire filmmaking process from conceptualization to postproduction, it is the wishes of the producer that are carried out to the final cut. The hand that guides it all along the way is the director’s, but the producer retains the authority to revise the director’s work, either by ordering cures (changes) after seeing the daily rushes, or by taking control of the final cutting and assembly of the workprint.

 

In the early days of cinema in the Philippines, the producer was also the director of the movie. The pioneer Filipino producers Jose Nepomuceno, Vicente Salumbides, and Julian Manansala bought or prepared scripts, hired artists and technicians, and themselves acted some parts, designed sets, and handled cameras as well as editing and laboratory equipment. They generally attended to all the details of production aside from directing the actual shooting scenes. As the industry progressed, the need to expand the territory of manpower to include other people in the preparation, production, and distribution of films also became apparent.

 

With the advent of the talkies and the rise of movie studios, what had been a craft took on some of the trappings of an industrial enterprise. Producers like George Harris and Edward Tait, Nepomuceno’s American partners in the first Filipino all-talking film, Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger), 1933, hired directors like Manuel Silos and Carlos Vander Tolosa to make movies for Filippine Films. In Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, Nepomuceno started the trend of hiring a production manager to oversee studio operations. He convinced silent film producer Vicente Salumbides to come out of retirement and take charge of production at Parlatone. After his stint with Parlatone, Salumbides formed his own company, Salumbides Film Company Ltd, and produced the memorable classic Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939. Another producer whom Nepomuceno trained as production manager was Luis F. Nolasco, who later organized Nolasco Bros. Pictures and produced Fort Santiago , 1946, and Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948.

 

It was Nolasco who spurred Rep Pedro Vera to establish Sampaguita Pictures in 1937, bringing with him such big names as Elsa Oria, Rogelio de la Rosa, Mike Velarde, and Carlos Vander Tolosa. A year later, Doña Sisang Buencamino de Leon established LVN Pictures. By 1940, Filipino movies had become a mass entertainment phenomenon, attracting more investors and financiers who assumed the role of industrial film producer. J. Amado Araneta, who bought out Harris and Tait’s shares in Filippine Films after the Americans bowed out of movie production, expanded the concept of industrial film producer by bringing into the fold an assorted group of movie directors ranging from politicians and journalists like Nick Osmeña and Hermenegildo Atienza to playwrights and theater personalities like Severino Montano and Lamberto V. Avellana. The concept of a director as filmmaker—that is, one whose involvement in the making of films is creative rather than business-oriented—evolved with this group. This is seen in some of the movies produced by Filippine Films before the outbreak of the Pacific War: Avellana’s Sakay, 1939; Atienza’s Hating Gabi (Midnight), 1940; and Osmeña’s Magdalena, 1941. Respect for the director as creative filmmaker was the principal concern of Dr Ciriaco Santiago when he established Premiere Productions in 1946. His studio gave the director more latitude, autonomy, and cinematic freedom. Premiere became the home of such outstanding directors as Ramon Estella, Cesar Gallardo, Consuelo P. Osorio, and the late National Artist Gerardo de Leo n.

 

Movie stars who achieve a certain degree of stature in the industry can become producers of their own picture and exercise total control over the production. Rogelio de la Rosa was among the first to do this when he left Sampaguita to form RDR Productions.

 

Fernando Poe Sr also pioneered in setting up his own Royal Productions, which made such films as the war epic Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), 1946, and the fantasy film, Darna , 1951. Following his death in 1951, his son Fernando Poe Jr became an actor and eventually set up his own FPJ Productions, which became one of the country’s major film companies.

 

Among the actor-director-producers, the most successful are Manuel Conde with his Genghis Khan, 1950, and Juan Tamad series; and Eddie Rodriguez with his love-triangle dramas like Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967, and Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984.

 

The list of successful actor-producers include Joseph Estrada (JE Productions and Emar Pictures), Dolphy (RVQ Productions), Ramon Revilla (Imus Productions), Susan Roces (Rosas Productions), Amalia Fuentes (AM Productions), Nora Aunor (NV Productions), Vilma Santos (VS Films), Chiquito (Sotang Bastos Productions), Lisa Moreno (Virgo Productions), Vivian Velez (Amazaldy Films), Lito Lapid (LL Productions), Armida Siguion-Reyna (Reyna Films), Charo Santos (Vision Films), and Rudy Fernandez and Lorna Tolentino (Reflection Films). Their more successful efforts have resulted in movies that won critical acclaim or at least set box-office records: Emar’s Ito ang Filipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; FPJ’s Asedillo, 1971; Imus’s Nardong Putik, 1972; NV’s Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; JE’s Bakya Mo Neneng (Your Wooden Slippers, Neneng), 1977; VS’s Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; and Rosas’s Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978.

 

Before their assimilation into the Philippine Movie Producers Association (PMPA), these producers were known as indies or independent producers, which in movie parlance was the opposite of major. The indies made only one or two pictures a year against the major producer’s dozen or more films. They did not own movie studios or equipment but only rented facilities and shooting units, and they did not have stars on exclusive long-term contracts. But the number of the indies grew so that, sometime in the 1960s, the PMPA was changed to the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association to accommodate them all. Membership swelled from the original Big Four to more than 40.

 

Producers often have to contend with the dichotomy between art and popular entertainment, creativity and commerce. Faced with the question of survival in a highly competitive industry, director-producers choose to be pragmatic, putting commerce above creativity. But serious artists desiring greater freedom in their work tried to make the transition from director-filmmaker to director-filmmaker-producer. To this group belong producers like Eddie Romero (Hemisphere Productions), Lino Brocka (Cine Manila Corporation), and Mike de Leon (Cinema Artists). Despite the many pitfalls that beset them as director-producers, they have produced such classics as Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976; Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974; Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975; and Itim (The Rites of May), 1976.

 

The more successful producers who are neither stars nor directors have skills for conceiving viable film projects and marshalling the necessary resources. Jose R. Perez of Sampaguita, Marichu Maceda of MVP Pictures, Lily Monteverde of Regal, Jesse Ejercito of Crown Seven and Seven Stars, Espiridion Laxa of Tagalog Ilang-Ilang, Vic del Rosario of Viva, Robbie Tan of Seiko, Emilia Blas and Teodorica Santos of Lea, Orly Ilacad of OctoArts all belong to this group. Known as a star builder, Dr Perez transformed unknowns into outstanding movie personalities, among them Gloria Romero, Lolita Rodriguez, Dolphy, Susan Roces, Amalia Fuentes, Eddie Garcia, and Nora Aunor. His achievement has been emulated by other producers like Monteverde, del Rosario, Tan, and later, by German Moreno in television.

 

In the 1990s, trends in moviemaking among the major studios point to the importance of line producers. Where there is need to coordinate the mass production of films, a great bulk of the responsibility in the hands of the producer is relegated to line producers. As the producer’s representatives, they see to it that important activities of filmmaking are undertaken only with their approval. The line producers think like producers, motivated by the commercial viability of a project and the need to meet the playdate. They keep the budget low with their direct involvement in the production: difficulties are foreseen and remedied early, and crippling delays are averted during production and postproduction.

 

However, the landscape of producing changed with the rise of power of the multimedia companies. When television became the most dominant medium, the whole landscape of film production in the Philippines changed. Whereas before there was a distinct difference between film and TV stars, the merging of the two media relegated the big screen as a feeder of content for the much wider and more encompassing television business. TV networks began to have their film production outfits to be able to provide movies to be shown in both their commercial as well as cable channels. Examples of these are GMA Films, established in 1995 by GMA Network Inc, and Star Cinema (also known as ABS-CBN Film Production Inc), which was founded in 1993 by ABS-CBN. As the digital age opens more and more possibilities in terms of platforms, there is a greater need for multimedia networks to create products to fill their requirements, which now include viral as well as short-length entertainment by demand in smart phones, tablets, and personal computers. Due to economic effects created by this demand, there has been a decline of film production among the previously major film companies, such as Regal Films and Viva Films in the recent years.

 

With the introduction of inexpensive digital video (DV) technology in 1999 and its widespread use by 2005, filmmakers could afford to produce their own films, whose production cost would usually be from two to three million pesos. To many of them, this meant liberation from the clutches and dictates of commercial producers who lorded it over the filmmakers because only they could afford the price of celluloid. With DV technology, filmmakers were now free to pursue their artistic visions for their films. With grants given by the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and Cinema One Originals starting 2005 and other grant-giving bodies later, indie films blossomed from 2005, accounting for the greater majority of films produced from 2005 to the present. And because many of these films are marked by originality and artistic integrity, they have been recognized by prestigious local and international award-giving bodies. Among the companies established by indie filmmakers are Center Stage Productions of Brillante Mendoza, which produced Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, which won for Mendoza the Palme d’Or for Best Director at Cannes Film Festival; UFO Pictures of Raymond Lee, Jade Castro, Ned Trespeces, Emmanuel de la Cruz, and Michiko Yamamoto, which produced the multi-awarded Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005; and Quantum Films, which produced Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006, and co-produced Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011.  Written by Nick Cruz, Joel David, and Rosalie Matilac, with notes from Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera  and Nicanor G. He or she answers to the supervising and executive producers and must ensure that the movie’s quality is maintained while keeping within the budget. The associate producer works hand in hand with the line producer. He or she assists in the negotiations for below-the-line talents, technical and creative crew; helps prepare the budget; and coordinates with the production manager and postproduction coordinator. In the Philippine cinematic setting, however, the distinctions among these positions and occupations become blurred for practical and economic reasons.

Although it is the director who dominates the entire filmmaking process from conceptualization to postproduction, it is the wishes of the producer that are carried out to the final cut. The hand that guides it all along the way is the director’s, but the producer retains the authority to revise the director’s work, either by ordering cures (changes) after seeing the daily rushes, or by taking control of the final cutting and assembly of the workprint.

In the early days of cinema in the Philippines, the producer was also the director of the movie. The pioneer Filipino producers Jose Nepomuceno, Vicente Salumbides, and Julian Manansala bought or prepared scripts, hired artists and technicians, and themselves acted some parts, designed sets, and handled cameras as well as editing and laboratory equipment. They generally attended to all the details of production aside from directing the actual shooting scenes. As the industry progressed, the need to expand the territory of manpower to include other people in the preparation, production, and distribution of films also became apparent.

With the advent of the talkies and the rise of movie studios, what had been a craft took on some of the trappings of an industrial enterprise. Producers like George Harris and Edward Tait, Nepomuceno’s American partners in the first Filipino all-talking film, Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger), 1933, hired directors like Manuel Silos and Carlos Vander Tolosa to make movies for Filippine Films. In Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, Nepomuceno started the trend of hiring a production manager to oversee studio operations. He convinced silent film producer Vicente Salumbides to come out of retirement and take charge of production at Parlatone. After his stint with Parlatone, Salumbides formed his own company, Salumbides Film Company Ltd, and produced the memorable classic Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939. Another producer whom Nepomuceno trained as production manager was Luis F. Nolasco, who later organized Nolasco Bros. Pictures and produced Fort Santiago , 1946, and Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948.

It was Nolasco who spurred Rep Pedro Vera to establish Sampaguita Pictures in 1937, bringing with him such big names as Elsa Oria, Rogelio de la Rosa, Mike Velarde, and Carlos Vander Tolosa. A year later, Doña Sisang Buencamino de Leon established LVN Pictures. By 1940, Filipino movies had become a mass entertainment phenomenon, attracting more investors and financiers who assumed the role of industrial film producer. J. Amado Araneta, who bought out Harris and Tait’s shares in Filippine Films after the Americans bowed out of movie production, expanded the concept of industrial film producer by bringing into the fold an assorted group of movie directors ranging from politicians and journalists like Nick Osmeña and Hermenegildo Atienza to playwrights and theater personalities like Severino Montano and Lamberto V. Avellana. The concept of a director as filmmaker—that is, one whose involvement in the making of films is creative rather than business-oriented—evolved with this group. This is seen in some of the movies produced by Filippine Films before the outbreak of the Pacific War: Avellana’s Sakay, 1939; Atienza’s Hating Gabi (Midnight), 1940; and Osmeña’s Magdalena, 1941. Respect for the director as creative filmmaker was the principal concern of Dr Ciriaco Santiago when he established Premiere Productions in 1946. His studio gave the director more latitude, autonomy, and cinematic freedom. Premiere became the home of such outstanding directors as Ramon Estella, Cesar Gallardo, Consuelo P. Osorio, and the late National Artist Gerardo de Leo n.

Movie stars who achieve a certain degree of stature in the industry can become producers of their own picture and exercise total control over the production. Rogelio de la Rosa was among the first to do this when he left Sampaguita to form RDR Productions.

Fernando Poe Sr also pioneered in setting up his own Royal Productions, which made such films as the war epic Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), 1946, and the fantasy film, Darna , 1951. Following his death in 1951, his son Fernando Poe Jr became an actor and eventually set up his own FPJ Productions, which became one of the country’s major film companies.

Among the actor-director-producers, the most successful are Manuel Conde with his Genghis Khan, 1950, and Juan Tamad series; and Eddie Rodriguez with his love-triangle dramas like Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967, and Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984.

The list of successful actor-producers include Joseph Estrada (JE Productions and Emar Pictures), Dolphy (RVQ Productions), Ramon Revilla (Imus Productions), Susan Roces (Rosas Productions), Amalia Fuentes (AM Productions), Nora Aunor (NV Productions), Vilma Santos (VS Films), Chiquito (Sotang Bastos Productions), Lisa Moreno (Virgo Productions), Vivian Velez (Amazaldy Films), Lito Lapid (LL Productions), Armida Siguion-Reyna (Reyna Films), Charo Santos (Vision Films), and Rudy Fernandez and Lorna Tolentino (Reflection Films). Their more successful efforts have resulted in movies that won critical acclaim or at least set box-office records: Emar’s Ito ang Filipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; FPJ’s Asedillo, 1971; Imus’s Nardong Putik, 1972; NV’s Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; JE’s Bakya Mo Neneng (Your Wooden Slippers, Neneng), 1977; VS’s Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; and Rosas’s Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978.

Before their assimilation into the Philippine Movie Producers Association (PMPA), these producers were known as indies or independent producers, which in movie parlance was the opposite of major. The indies made only one or two pictures a year against the major producer’s dozen or more films. They did not own movie studios or equipment but only rented facilities and shooting units, and they did not have stars on exclusive long-term contracts. But the number of the indies grew so that, sometime in the 1960s, the PMPA was changed to the Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association to accommodate them all. Membership swelled from the original Big Four to more than 40.

Producers often have to contend with the dichotomy between art and popular entertainment, creativity and commerce. Faced with the question of survival in a highly competitive industry, director-producers choose to be pragmatic, putting commerce above creativity. But serious artists desiring greater freedom in their work tried to make the transition from director-filmmaker to director-filmmaker-producer. To this group belong producers like Eddie Romero (Hemisphere Productions), Lino Brocka (Cine Manila Corporation), and Mike de Leon (Cinema Artists). Despite the many pitfalls that beset them as director-producers, they have produced such classics as Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976; Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974; Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975; and Itim (The Rites of May), 1976.

The more successful producers who are neither stars nor directors have skills for conceiving viable film projects and marshalling the necessary resources. Jose R. Perez of Sampaguita, Marichu Maceda of MVP Pictures, Lily Monteverde of Regal, Jesse Ejercito of Crown Seven and Seven Stars, Espiridion Laxa of Tagalog Ilang-Ilang, Vic del Rosario of Viva, Robbie Tan of Seiko, Emilia Blas and Teodorica Santos of Lea, Orly Ilacad of OctoArts all belong to this group. Known as a star builder, Dr Perez transformed unknowns into outstanding movie personalities, among them Gloria Romero, Lolita Rodriguez, Dolphy, Susan Roces, Amalia Fuentes, Eddie Garcia, and Nora Aunor. His achievement has been emulated by other producers like Monteverde, del Rosario, Tan, and later, by German Moreno in television.

In the 1990s, trends in moviemaking among the major studios point to the importance of line producers. Where there is need to coordinate the mass production of films, a great bulk of the responsibility in the hands of the producer is relegated to line producers. As the producer’s representatives, they see to it that important activities of filmmaking are undertaken only with their approval. The line producers think like producers, motivated by the commercial viability of a project and the need to meet the playdate. They keep the budget low with their direct involvement in the production: difficulties are foreseen and remedied early, and crippling delays are averted during production and postproduction.

However, the landscape of producing changed with the rise of power of the multimedia companies. When television became the most dominant medium, the whole landscape of film production in the Philippines changed. Whereas before there was a distinct difference between film and TV stars, the merging of the two media relegated the big screen as a feeder of content for the much wider and more encompassing television business. TV networks began to have their film production outfits to be able to provide movies to be shown in both their commercial as well as cable channels. Examples of these are GMA Films, established in 1995 by GMA Network Inc, and Star Cinema (also known as ABS-CBN Film Production Inc), which was founded in 1993 by ABS-CBN. As the digital age opens more and more possibilities in terms of platforms, there is a greater need for multimedia networks to create products to fill their requirements, which now include viral as well as short-length entertainment by demand in smart phones, tablets, and personal computers. Due to economic effects created by this demand, there has been a decline of film production among the previously major film companies, such as Regal Films and Viva Films in the recent years.

With the introduction of inexpensive digital video (DV) technology in 1999 and its widespread use by 2005, filmmakers could afford to produce their own films, whose production cost would usually be from two to three million pesos. To many of them, this meant liberation from the clutches and dictates of commercial producers who lorded it over the filmmakers because only they could afford the price of celluloid. With DV technology, filmmakers were now free to pursue their artistic visions for their films. With grants given by the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and Cinema One Originals starting 2005 and other grant-giving bodies later, indie films blossomed from 2005, accounting for the greater majority of films produced from 2005 to the present. And because many of these films are marked by originality and artistic integrity, they have been recognized by prestigious local and international award-giving bodies. Among the companies established by indie filmmakers are Center Stage Productions of Brillante Mendoza, which produced Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, which won for Mendoza the Palme d’Or for Best Director at Cannes Film Festival; UFO Pictures of Raymond Lee, Jade Castro, Ned Trespeces, Emmanuel de la Cruz, and Michiko Yamamoto, which produced the multi-awarded Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005; and Quantum Films, which produced Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006, and co-produced Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011.

text:
Production design is the conceptualization, planning, and execution of all the backgrounds against which the action of a motion picture takes place. It involves set design and construction, makeup, costumes and props, and the use of miniatures and small-scale models. These are employed to create character, reflect atmosphere and mood, and project themes and conflicts. Production design requires the creation of the total look of the film in terms of actors, location, costumes, and texture, all in the service of the movie’s theme.

Production design necessitates understanding of human character, grasp of the various periods of history, and, most of all, knowledge of the camera and its effects on color, texture, and tones. The work of production designers begins with a study of the script. Designers are responsible for any research required by the movie whether it is set in contemporary or historic times, or whether it is a fantasy or science fiction film requiring imaginary props, costumes, and sets. They work closely with the director to determine what will be used to project in the best possible way the director’s vision in visual terms.

 

Production design covers numerous departments headed by the lead designer, who, together with the director of photography, collaborates with the director to determine the look and feel of the film, whether the piece is period or contemporary. To perform his or her function, the production designer supervises many departments. The wardrobe department is headed by the chief custodian who is in charge of the care of the costumes made or acquired specifically for the film. Together with the script continuity, the custodian ensures that all costumes assigned to lead, support, and atmosphere talents abide by consistency, continuity, and logic. The wardrobe is usually designed or styled by the costume designer. The production designer supervises the choice, arrangement, and embellishments of sets. This involves not only furniture but also details referring to the authenticity of the period and more so the revelation of the character or characters who shall populate the scene. Sets can either be built in soundstages or adjusted/improvised on existing locations that the production designer selects with the location manager with the approval of the director. The properties custodian handles all the props, which are preselected by the production designer and the set decorator. The principal role of the head of the props department is to ensure continuity as well as the care of these materials during and after their use in the shoot. A film may not be mounted inside a soundstage but the carpentry and electrical services are still needed for construction of sets, repair of damaged set panels and furniture as well as emergency repairs during the shooting. The electrical services department ensures that all electrical requirements are met while the shoot is ongoing.

 

In the era of silent pictures, producer-directors like Jose Nepomuceno, Vicente Salumbides, and Carmen Concha designed their own films. Nepomuceno used techniques that originated in the theater for his filmed sarsuwela, Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919. Interiors consisted of simple painted canvas backdrops photographed on a stage built on the studio premises. With the coming of color and more sophisticated equipment, sets had to appear more real. Today, with more and more films being produced on location, the production designer is more often called upon to change and adapt actual sites and structures to fit the demands of the script.

 

In the days of the studio system, after talking pictures replaced the silent films, studios had their own “art directors.” The main task of the art directors was to design and build props and sets for the production. They headed art departments, which became storehouses for costumes, props, and sundry requirements of the production. Production design became a principal component of moviemaking because grandeur sold. When Hollywood started churning out its historical epics in order to lure audiences to go back to the movie houses and turn off their televisions, the significance of sets, costumes, and the recreation or speculation of a world gone or simply imagined became a selling point for movies. The importance of the production designer became all the more prominent as studios depended on the sensory overload that audiences demanded in return for their money.

 

The Sampaguita art director Benjamin Resella was responsible for the research and production design of such films as the Maria Clara award-winning Baguio Cadets, 1950, and the fantasy film Bernardo Carpio, 1951. He was head of the studio’s art and special photographic effects department from 1947 to 1960. In 1963, he was commissioned to work as art director of an American production filmed in the Philippines by Universal Studios, No Man Is an Island, where Sampaguita star Barbara Perez was paired off with Hollywood actor Jeffrey Hunter. This was followed by another assignment as art director in To Be a Man (Cry of Battle), starring Hollywood’s Van Heflin and Rita Moreno together with local filmdom’s Leopoldo Salcedo. Resella had since been based in Hollywood, shuttling between 20th Century Fox and MGM Pictures where he was under contract. Although his name does not appear in film credits, he did work as scenic artist for the films Hello Dolly, 1969, Planet of the Apes, 1968, The Poseidon Adventure, 1972, The Towering Inferno, 1974, Earth quake, 1974, Battle Star Galactica, 1978, Buck Rogers in the 25th Century, 1979, and Star Trek, 1979.

 

Also in the 1950s, Manuel Conde brought in the fine arts painter and muralist Carlos “Botong” Francisco, later National Artist for visual arts. Francisco worked on Conde’s carefully researched productions, Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils), 1950, and Genghis Khan, 1950, which won critical acclaim at Venice International Film Festival. He also designed the production of other LVN pictures, among them Haring Kobra (King Cobra), 1951; Rodrigo de Villa, 1952; Dagohoy, 1953; Doce Pares (Twelve Peers), 1954; and Higit sa Korona (Above the Crown), 1956. In the 1960s, Francisco was commissioned to do the production design for Gerardo de Leon’s interpretations of the Rizal novels, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962.

 

Production design was established as an important aspect of filmmaking when the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) formally recognized the work of the production designer by including this category in their first awards event in 1976. Such recognition helped to call attention to the importance of production design in the contemporary film. Ganito Kami Noon… Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were… What Happens to You Now?), 1976, won for Peque Gallaga and Laida Lim-Perez the first Gawad Urian in this category. Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped), 1977, earned a Gawad Urian for Dez Bautista the next year. In their award-winning film, Gallaga and Lim-Perez dressed up contemporary buildings to approximate the look of turn-of-the-century Philippines. For his part, Bautista recreated the provincial milieu of the 1930s when religious fanaticism was at the core of the dissident movement. In Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, Rodell Cruz and Don Escudero recreated the look of Negros before and during the last world war.

 

The work of the production designer extends to films that deal with more contemporary subjects and milieus. In Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird), 1977, Bobby Bautista made the film’s setting integral to the film, expressing the predicament and personalities of the principal characters. In Ikaw ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1978, Mel Chionglo used sets and costumes to highlight the contrast between the two principal rival characters, portrayed by Nora Aunor and Vilma Santos. Peque Gallaga’s design for Ishmael Bernal’s City After Dark, 1980, was greatly instrumental to the success of the film as it reproduced the danger and sleaziness of the underbelly of Manila as seen through the eyes of an ensemble of nocturnal characters.

 

Other production designers who have been recognized for their work are Fiel Zabat in High School Circa ’65, 1979, and Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Peter Perlas in Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; Napoleon Enriquez in Ang Lihim ng Guadalupe (The Secret of Guadalupe), 1980; Cesar Hernando in Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, and Bayani (Hero), 1992; Rolando Sacrista in Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith… Third Chapter), 1982; Don Escudero in Virgin Forest, 1985; Elmer Manapul in Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; Brillante "Dante" Mendoza in Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation), 1986; Benjie de Guzman in Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986; Lea Locsin in Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988; Ray Maliuanag in Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988; Charlie Arceo in Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990; Joey Luna in Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; Randy Gamier in Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995; Edgar Martin Littaua in Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996; Len Santos in Milagros, 1997; Leo Abaya in Jose Rizal , 1998; Ronnie Cruz in Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), 1999; Mike Guison in Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000; Arthur Nicdao in Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002; Melody Teodoro in Babae sa Breakwater (Woman of Breakwater), 2003; and Benjamin Padero in Serbis (Service), 2008.

 

Since the establishment of the Production Designers Guild of the Philippines and its affiliation with the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1981, production designers have organized workshops, seminars, and tours aimed at upgrading and refining the skills of production designers.

 

With the rise of digital video technology, neorealism has become the style of choice of many indie film directors—notably, Brillante Mendoza, who started out as a production designer, who is known for films such as Lola (Grandmother), 2009, and Thy Womb, 2012. Mendoza’s films are known to strive for verisimilitude, emphasizing everyday clothes and settings. As Mendoza derives stories from actual locations and uses people found in those locations as actors, he insists that the design of his movies be ultrarealistic. As he would put it, “the less production design, the better.” This trend toward neorealism is also seen in other indie movies designed by award-winning production designers like Mes de Guzman in Ang Daan Patungong Kalimugtong (The Road to Kalimugtong), 2005, and Leo Abaya in Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006.  Written by Nick Cruz and Lena S. Pareja, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Jose Javier Reyes, with notes from  Nicanor G. Tiongson and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
Film promotion is the process of creating an audience for a film through a comprehensive publicity program. The promotional campaign includes press conferences, press releases, and press previews; teasers, trailers, radio plugs, and TV commercials; posters, streamers, banners, still photos, cutouts, standees, and other theater lobby displays; magazine and newspaper advertising layouts, pictorials, handbills, feature articles, endorsements, and testimonials; billboards, marquees, and other outdoor displays; contests and giveaways; guest appearances on radio, television, benefit, and other shows; and premiere nights and opening-day theater tours.

 

This elaborate multimedia plan is geared toward one purpose: to sell the movie using all resources available to the producer or promotions manager. From the late 1980s up to the present, a film to be successful at the box office must be alloted a budget of millions of pesos for promotional expenses.

 

 

The campaign to sell a movie begins right at the time the producer decides to produce a film or acquires the rights to a material that he would like to make into a film. It may be a true-to-life story, like Bingbong: The Vincent Crisologo Story, 1991; an event headlined in the newspapers, such as Dope Addict, 1961; a novel, like A Child of Sorrow, 1930; a popular comic strip, like Kenkoy, 1950; a radio drama, like Kasaysayan ni Dr. Ramon Selga (The Story of Dr Ramon Selga), 1951; a television show, like Lovingly Yours, Helen (The Movie), 1984; a remake, like Jack n’ Jill of the Third Kind, 1978; or sequel to a previous movie, like Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990. The announcement is usually made through press releases or in a press conference, during which time the stars as well as the production staff are introduced to members of the print and broadcast media, who, in turn, will relay the information to their audiences of readers and viewers.

 

In the course of the production, announcements are made from time to time about the progress of the film shooting and other details that may be of interest to the moviegoing public. Updates are made on the latest happenings on the movie set, including trivial problems that crop up and how they are resolved, imagined amorous relations between leading actors, supposed fights between the principal protagonists and newsmakers, and how they affect the completion of the movie.

 

 

The producer enlists the services of publicists to promote the film. Some publicists resort to the gimmickry of public relations agents, manufacturing scandals to keep their stars in the limelight. The good publicist promotes the movie in more sober fashion, with the accent on balanced, credible accounts in the media.

 

Trailers are very important in view of the scope and influence of the broadcast media. The commercial value of a movie trailer is so important that a major film producer like Lily Monteverde of Regal Films has been known to approve scripts on the basis of their having high points that could effectively be exploited in a trailer, such as crying and slapping scenes, kissing scenes, fight scenes, and shoot-outs with simulated explosions.

 

 

Television commercials are expensive but very effective because of their maximum exposure to a general audience of TV viewers. TV commercials are usually tied up with promotional appearances of the film’s stars on noonday programs and other TV variety shows, such as showbiz-oriented news programs and talk shows. Guesting on these shows gives stars greater visibility that is supposed to heighten audience interest in the movie. Rumors of offscreen romance become a point of discussion while guesting to promote the film. The young love-team Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, for example, were put “on the hot seat” when they guested on the showbiz-oriented talk show The Buzz to promote their Star Cinema movie Must Be… Love, 2013, as the host Boy Abunda brought up the persistent rumor of the two being officially a couple. Abunda, employed by the same group of companies that produced the film, wrote about the interview in the major daily Philippine Star.

 

On some TV promo shows, contestants are required to act out a scene from the movie. Occasionally, the film’s stars are requested to dance or to sing their movie’s theme song or any song. TV guesting may occur before and during the run of the movie.

 

Radio is equally important and relatively cheaper than TV commercials. It is most effective when the aim is to reach specific audiences. Women doing housework are mostly daytime listeners. Rock music stations are youth-oriented. Radio helps promote a movie through its theme song, which usually carries the title of the film itself—for instance, “Miss Na Miss Kita” (I Miss You So Much) boosted ticket sales for Miss na Miss Kita: Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum 2 (I Miss You So Much: My Hoodlum Brother 2), 1992. The continuous playing/singing of the theme song from day to day generates interest and recall for a particular film. Radio plugs are also important, especially when last-minute announcements fail to meet print deadlines and the fastest way to communicate relevant information about the film is via the airwaves.

 

A film is a very perishable product, and news about a forthcoming motion picture should be kept fresh. It cannot afford to go stale and cease to interest its prospective audience. A publicity campaign, therefore, must concentrate on the time immediately prior to the opening of the movie. The newspaper is a prime medium for advertising when and where a movie will be shown, is currently showing, or about to close. Families that have no radio or television can rely on newspapers to give them this kind of information about the movies that they see occasionally. The first motion picture shown in the country was announced on 17 Dec 1896 in the newspaper El Comercio before its opening in January the next year. The succeeding motion-picture exhibitions were promoted based on the novelty of the technology and its subjects as seen in the newspaper announcement about Lumière’s Cinematographe films on 31 Aug 1897: “The exhibition of fenómenós naturales (natural phenomena) and actos solemnes de actualidad (formal acts of current events) was accompanied by an orquesta under the direction of Don Francisco de P. Barbat” (del Mundo 2000, 89).

 

In the 1910s, the pioneer film producers Albert Yearsley and Dr Edward Gross used print media extensively to promote their movies, La Vida de Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal) and El Fusilamiento de Dr. Jose Rizal (The Execution of Dr Jose Rizal), both 1912. They capitalized on events of the Philippine revolution, but what generated considerable interest among moviegoers was the “war of newspaper ads” between them when they showed their films simultaneously.

 

Kundiman (traditional love song) queen Atang dela Rama helped promote Jose Nepomuceno’s first silent movie, Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919, by singing its theme song on stage during film screenings. The movie rode on the popularity of the sarsuwela as an entertainment medium.

 

In Fate or Consequence, 1926, actor-director-producer VicenteSalumbides featured “society girls” from respected families in Manila and students from the University of the Philippines, Philippine Law School, and Philippine Normal School, plus a beauty queen, “Miss Cotabato” (Sofia Lotta). Their appearance in his movie was quite unprecedented, generating interest in the film.

 

With the rise of movie studios in the 1930s, each film-producing outfit had its own publicist/writer who had access to different publications. Parlatone’s Luis F. Nolasco, who was editor and columnist of Literary Song Movie Magazine, initiated the practice of movie stars appearing on magazine covers and color print ads to promote a motion picture, like that of Diwata ng Karagatan, 1936. Filippine Films’ advertising and publicity manager, T. D. Agcaoili, edited the prewar Graphic and later the Sunday Times Magazine, which had an entertainment section for views and reviews.

 

Colorful events like the annual Carnival Exposition of the 1930s were good venues for promotion and publicity. The participation of Gamu-gamong Naging Lawin (Moth That Became a Hawk), 1937, in the exposition parade and its winning the prize of “Most Artistic Float” two weeks before the film opened, gained unprecedented media mileage for the film and its stars, Leopoldo Salcedo and Rosa del Rosario. This practice has been carried on to the present day with the participation of movie floats in the annual parade of stars that precedes the opening of the Metro Manila Film Festival.

 

When radio dramas and soap operas became the vogue in the 1950s, film producers utilized the medium, dramatizing their films in such radio shows as Luz Mat Castro’s The Big Broadcast. The show became so popular that Sampaguita eventually made a film version, The Big Broadcast, 1962. Another popular medium of that era was the short film used as added attraction to a motion picture. Doña Sisa ng’s 78th Birthday Celebration, a star-studded short feature, helped boost Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955, when it was shown together with the movie.

 

Doña Sisang was also known to encourage publicity by controversy in promoting LVN’s love teams. She encouraged screen lovers to be seen together in public even when there was no real romance between them, so that stories about them would fill movie columns and gossip sections in fan magazines and periodicals. When movie stars did fall in love with each other, producers cashed in on the popularity of their real life/reel life romances to promote their films. This was true for Tita Duran and Pancho Magalona in Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), 1948; Gloria Romero and Juancho Gutierrez in Eternally, 1957; Fernando Poe Jr and Susan Roces in Ang Daigdig Ko’y Ikaw (You Are My World), 1965; Janice de Belen and Aga Muhlach in Pakasalan Mo Ako (Marry Me), 1991; and Sharon Cuneta and Gabby Concepcion in Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 1992.

 

The hype of a film’s subject matter, particularly its shock value, may serve as promotion. Olivia Lamasan’s In My Life, 2009, breaks away from the conventions of Star Cinema romantic dramas by depicting a same-sex relationship starred by two matinee idols, whose kissing scene created fanfare even before the film’s premiere. Furthermore, its New York setting targets the overseas Filipino worker (OFW) market, as observed in preceding films that also portrayed Filipinos working abroad, like Dubai, 2005, and Caregiver, 2008. Many OFWs flocked to the theaters in hope of identifying with the characters (Bolisay 2009).

 

Lobbying against censorship can be another effective method to promote a film. Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997, piqued the public’s interest after it was X-rated but finally received exhibition approval with cuts from the Appeals Committee under the Office of the President.

 

The decision to hold the annual “Gabi ng Parangal” (Awards Night) on the third instead of the last day of the Metro Manila Film Festival was dictated by promotional considerations. Early recognition generates interest in the award-winning films, which ordinarily do not attract as much box-office attention as the more commercial or escapist films. During the festival, winning entries are announced in the movie ads to entice moviegoers into seeing the better-made films.

 

Festivals of independent films collectively promote the year’s entries. Recognizing its limited market, Cinemalaya reaches out to universities, partners with film groups like UP Cineastes, and conducts special screenings in the regions that feature a Q&A with the filmmakers. Its other methods of promotion are “inviting foreign festival directors to become members of the jury, distribution of Cinemalaya catalogues and brochures to international film practitioners and critics, and organizing ‘Focus Philippines’ in several international film festivals and inclusion of Cinemalaya and other indie films in this line-up” (Jardin 2014, 208). Festivals mobilize promotion of an independent film because being part of the selection already suggests quality.

 

The global scale of the Internet, especially the social media, has made accessible to the public an important venue for the promotion and exhibition of films. Trailers are uploaded to YouTube and get shared on Facebook and Twitter. Facebook pages are created to provide information about the film, such as synopsis, stills, and screening schedules. The same platform facilitates promotion by viewer recommendation. Jerrold Tarog’s Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015, for example, started slow at the box office and major cinemas threatened to pull it out, until netizens launched a petition to keep the film in theaters. Drawing crowds after the massive online campaign, the film allegedly grossed 240 million pesos on its fifth week.

 

Major production companies have also jumped on the popularity of Wattpad, a social media platform dedicated to free self-publication. Regarded as the “largest community of readers and writers online,” Wattpad has gathered five million Filipino users and amounted to one billion reading minutes. Stories with a high number of hits—that is, the instance of opening the work—have been adapted into films and promoted as such, like Diary ng Panget (Diary of the Ugly), 2014, and She’s Dating the Gangster, 2014.

 

Most of these efforts are geared to getting the audience into the theaters on opening day. After the first few days of showing, what becomes significant is word-of-mouth or audience reaction to the movie. At this point, advertising can air on TV interviews or comments of critics and of ordinary folk who have seen the film. When a movie is being shown, advertising serves to remind people that the film is still around, telling them where to go if they have not seen it yet or if they want to see it again.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, with notes from Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Julian de la Cerna

text:
Scriptwriting is the process by which the film characters and plots are fleshed out in specific scenes and dialogues. When written down, the script represents the first and most basic element in filmmaking. It constitutes the raw material from which is derived the sequence of images that, when strung together in a cohesive whole, make up a film. The person responsible for this is known as the scriptwriter.

 

Scripts for film may come from sources that the filmmaker believes can be translated into the film medium. These sources may include literature, theater, music, dance, the visual arts, print and broadcast media, as well as actual personalities, events, and even locations, past or present. The scriptwriter and director have to decide whether such material can be the vehicle for their ideas and whether it lends itself to cinematic visualization.

 

 

Scriptwriting involves two elements: narrative flow and dialogue. In general, one minute of screentime requires one page of script, and scripts may consist of anywhere from 60 to several hundred pages. Scripts may likewise employ a wealth of details, ranging from suggestions for visual style to descriptions of the setting. This is crucial to the work not only of directors but also of actors, cinematographers, and editors. Unlike TV, the film experience is a community activity that requires total focus on what is projected on-screen while submerged in total darkness to be able to let go of the real and actual world for 100 or so minutes.

 

There are two kinds of screenplays based on how and why they are created. The commissioned screenplay is when a studio or producer hires a scriptwriter to create a specific work based on the needs of the company or individual financing the project or to provide a vehicle for actors and actresses prized not only for their talent but also for their bankability. In other words, commissioned screenplays are tailor-made to comply with certain needs enumerated by the studio heads. The speculative screenplay is created by the writer with no specific production plans. This can be an entry in a screenwriting competition or simply a work to fulfill the desire to give form and substance to a story in the mind of the artist. A speculative screenplay can be submitted to directors and producers for consideration. The writer may also interest a filmmaker or an actor to be part of the project—thus having their names attached when the script is pitched to a producer.

 

 

The screenplay provides the map that traces the journey of a character or characters to achieve or fail in their goals, thus illustrating the value of its theme. The script provides the structure of events that lead characters into their various tests—where both their failure and success form the backbone of understanding their sense of purpose, ambition, or even validation. The challenge to the director is to bring to life the words in the script—while at the same time making this his own vision. The collaboration between director and scriptwriter is considered the most essential in the filmmaking process. In the ultimate analysis, the successful collaboration is determined by how effectively the director interprets on film the scriptwriter’s ideas and concepts, in collaboration with the cinematographer, production designer, editor, and other film artists.

 

From the early days of Philippine cinema, producers have exercised control over the kind of material that they make into films. Most of the stories that became popular during the pre-World War II era were translations and adaptations of sarsuwela, and popular and metrical romances. There was, however, no discernible surefire formula for box-office success in the choice of material. Examples of the prewar era’s biggest box-office hits are Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939, and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, which were both adaptations of well-known metrical romances that were to have several remakes. Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), 1950, and Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1958, were popular radio serials that later became big box-office hits. On the other hand, such box-office sensations as Señorita (Young Mistress), 1940, and Roberta, 1951, relied mainly on their stars—Carmen Rosales and Tessie Agana, respectively—and the tremendous appeal of their material. After World War II, stories based on the war appeared, like Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), 1946, and Fort Santiago , 1946.

 

 

In the 1950s, when the studios of the Big Four flourished, the producers dominated the choice of material for their productions. Each of the major studios hired a regular stable of writers whose chief function was to translate the producer’s own storylines into scripts. At Sampaguita, for instance, Jose R. Perez, the chief executive, would himself write the draft of a script, which he then passed on to a writer to work on and complete. Most of Perez’s scenarios were done under the pseudonym Jose Leonardo. The same was true at LVN, Premiere, and Lebran, where the studio moguls wielded considerable power in shaping the material, from the moment it was conceived up to the time the film was completed.

 

In the 1950s and 1960s, however, there were writers like Cesar Amigo, Rolf Bayer, Pierre Salas, and Eddie Romero who wrote scripts at a time when these were not yet fashionable or considered essential by producers.

 

The situation hardly changed in the studio setup of the 1970s. In the big studios of Regal, Seiko, or Viva, the idea for a film most often came from the producer. It was the producer who ultimately decided to film the scripts that had been approved for filming or still need to be written. The practice was simply to hire a scriptwriter upon the recommendation of the producer or director who, in turn, may either closely follow or revise the script, to please the producer or appease a “bankable” star.

 

 

A welcome development took place in the 1970s when a group of scriptwriters, playwrights, and poets formed the Philippine Scriptwriters Inc, upon the initiative of then censors’ chief Guillermo de Vega. The group was organized mainly to help enhance the overall quality of films made locally and at the same time promote the welfare and well-being of writers for the motion picture industry. However, their efforts were nipped in the bud with the death of de Vega.

 

Scriptwriting received an accidental boost from new guidelines set by the censors in 1975. The censors’ board required that scripts be submitted for scrutiny and approval before actual production. The ultimate objective was to ban film material that may contain political statements against the martial law regime of Pres Ferdinand Marcos. Indirectly, the requirement resulted in the commissioning of full-blown scripts. Improvement of the quality of scripts was the aim of the scriptwriting contest sponsored by the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) in the early 1980s. By providing sufficient incentives to writers and ensuring the filming of award-winning scenarios, the ECP was able to draw a number of established and serious writers to join the competition. Thus were created the scripts of such noteworthy ECP films as Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; Soltero (Bachelor), 1983; Himala (Miracle), 1982; and Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984, With the entry of writers like Ricardo Lee, Bienvenido Noriega Jr, and Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, more literary artists began to offer their services as scriptwriters. To this list can be added such names as Marina Feleo-Gonzales, Jose Y. Dalisay Jr, Jose F. Lacaba, Jorge Arago, Jose Carreon, Lualhati Bautista, Rene O. Villanueva, and Amado Lacuesta.

 

The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, the critics’ organization founded in 1976, gave scriptwriters much-deserved recognition by extolling their work after that of the directors’ during its awards rites. The message was loud and clear: without writers, there would be no directors and consequently no films.

 

Also at about this time, the craft of scriptwriting was finally beginning to be studied, taught, and discussed in workshops and seminars and through film courses in schools like the University of the Philippines (UP), the Ateneo de Manila University, and the De La Salle University. Del Mundo’s award-winning script of Edgardo Reyes’s Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag started as a thesis for his scriptwriting class at the Ateneo under Nestor Torre. Regular workshops on scriptwriting were offered by Mowelfund and the UP Film Center, now the UP Film Institute. Similarly, leading film writers, like Ricky Lee, Jose Javier Reyes, and Armando Lao, conducted their own workshops at one time or the other for aspiring writers and students. Del Mundo published Writing for Film in 1981. In 1998, Lee published his Trip to Quiapo, a manual for scriptwriting.

 

Scriptwriters continued to work under difficult conditions imposed by the studio. The most typical problem they faced concerns the endless revisions made on their material either by the producer or the director (unless the latter happens to be the scriptwriter himself). Thus, it was common for writers to complain that their work had been mangled and even completely altered by these people. Others complained that their work was no longer theirs.

 

Among the few directors who gave scriptwriters their rightful importance are Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Mike de Leon. These directors tried to follow the shooting script religiously; when revisions had to be made, they made it a point to consult their scriptwriters. Brocka’s best films were written by award-winning literary figures like Lee, Dalisay, and Lacaba. Bernal’s scripts were mostly written by Arago, while de Leon’s were mostly done by del Mundo. The published scripts by Lee (Moral/Brutal and Himala), Lualhati Bautista (Bata, Bata... Paano Ka Ginawa?), and del Mundo (Maynila … ’Merika at Alyas Raha Matanda) serve as models of scriptwriting and guides for scriptwriters and students who want to understand more fully the language of film.

 

With the rise of the New Wave Independent Film in 2005, the screenplay was again given importance by festivals and competitions, like Cinemalaya and Cinema One Originals, who chose to give grants to certain directors based on the scenarios they submitted. Because most of the indie directors are auteurs, they wrote their own scripts or had a part in its writing. These include Jun Robles Lana, Chris Martinez, Adolfo Alix Jr, Yam Laranas, Raya Martin, Auraeus Solito, Jerrold Tarog, John Torres, Sherad Anthony Sanchez, and Alvin Yapan. Among the scriptwriters who did the screenplays for award-winning indie films are Michiko Yamamoto and Armando Lao. Armando Lao is known for his found story, which stipulates that the story of a film must come from an actual place and the people in it, as exemplified in films such as Serbis (Service), 2008, and Thy Womb, 2012.

 

In 1982, scriptwriters were organized into the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines, and their elected president sits in the Board of Governors of the Film Academy of the Philippines. Here, screenwriters discussed and sought solutions to their common problems. Another boost to scriptwriting came with the inclusion of the screenplay writing category in the annual Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.  Written by Nick Cruz and Justino Dormiendo, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson,  updated by Jose Javier Reyes,  with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
In movie production, sound recording is the application of dialogue, music, narration, sound effects, and other aural elements to the film. Before the emergence of digital technology, there were two ways of recording sound. One was the optical method, which refers to recording sound on sound film stock. The other was the magnetic method, in which sound is recorded on 35 mm magnetic tape and the final mix (dialogue, music, narration, effects) is transferred to film negative.

 

In the optical method, the key factor in shooting sound and film together is synchronization. If the picture negative and the sound film do not move at the same speed in relation to each other, lip movements and dialogue will not be coordinated and the film will be “out of sync.”

 

 

One of the most important activities in the second method is post-sync dialogue dubbing. Here, the sound track recorded at the time of photography is used only as a guide and is referred to as a cue track. The scenes are projected silently on a big screen and the actor watches lip movements carefully while listening through headsets to the audio track. The film and audio track are played over repeatedly until the dubber can repeat the lines into a microphone at the speed and timing of the original recording, in effect matching the original track. The new recorded dialogue, now free of extraneous sounds or noise and corrected during the dubbing, becomes the dialogue track of the film.

 

Carefully controlled ambient sounds or other background sounds go into the special effects track. Music goes into the music track. The sound engineer or designer must consider the relationships among these different tracks when, together with the film director, he or she judges the relative value of sounds to be heard in each scene. When all sound tracks have been edited and cleaned, the final creative task—the sound mixing—begins. The mix is the artistic and skillful blending of all sound tracks into a single track, a process that is accomplished with the use of 35 mm magnetic tape recording. This is done in a special sound recording studio equipped with interlock machines to run many separate sound tracks synchronously with the projected picture. The sound engineer sits at a large console with controls and adjusts the volume and quality of each track.

 

In the past, the most common accusation mistakenly directed against the sound engineer is that of poor synchronization of sound and visuals. This responsibility is actually shared by the film editor, the negative matcher, and the laboratory technician doing the optical transfers. A more serious offense was the industry’s dependence on dubbed sound, which resulted in a lack of realism.

 

When sound was first used in Philippine movies in 1932, studios were equipped with sound booths and re-recording facilities, which merely refined what had already been recorded during photography. Seldom, if at all, was dialogue reproduced in the picture’s entirety. Songs were prerecorded in the studio by singers whose voices matched the actors’ to the accompaniment of a group of musicians. The finished compositions were played back during the shooting so that the actors could “lip-sync” the songs as they performed before the camera. Since this was done without sound, the shooting would proceed at a faster pace, and after photography the playback tape was dubbed into the sound track of the film.

 

The first Filipino sound recording engineer in Philippine cinema was Isabela-born William Smith, who worked on Ang Aswang (The Aswang), 1932, the first Filipino talking picture. He set up the studio sound systems of Parlatone Hispano-Filipino in 1935 and Sampaguita Pictures in 1937. Another Filipino sound pioneer, Charles Gray from Tacloban, Leyte, trained in Filippine Films under American sound engineer Louise R. Morse. Gray set up the sound studio of X’Otic Films in 1941 and later organized Movietec for Lebran Studio after the war.

 

During the days of the studio system, each major studio had its own sound engineer who supervised the work of recordists and technicians hired as regular employees. They were Joseph Straight at Sampaguita, July P. Hidalgo at LVN, Demetrio de Santos at Premiere, and Angelo Larraga at Lebran. Others who followed in their footsteps were Nestor Tanquintic, Flaviano Villareal, and Gaudencio Barredo at Sampaguita; and Juanito Clemente at LVN with the father-and-son team of Luis Reyes and Ramon Reyes.

 

A major change in sound technology in Philippine cinema occurred in the late 1960s when all sound recording studios were equipped with interlock machines and projectors. This was the transition from field-recorded sound to magnetic film recording. The entire film production was shot with guide sound and dubbed in completely with entire tracks of dialogue, music, narration, and effects. This innovation allowed the director greater creative freedom as he worked side by side with the sound engineer and the film editor in the postproduction phase of the film. The effect of sounds, like dogs barking offscreen or a plane’s wheels touching down when landing, heightened the sense of urgency or realism and added mood or atmosphere to the film. The overdependence on dubbing resulted in a kind of artificiality in some films. In this period, some of the movie studios specializing in sound recording and re-recording activities, like Magnatech Omni and PM Studio at Sampaguita, were set up to provide postproduction services to movie producers.

 

Sound mixer Rolly Ruta, an electronics engineer who managed Magnatech since its establishment, is a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Hall of Fame awardee for Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984; Paradise Inn, 1985; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; and Chinatown, 1988. He is the only sound director who won the FAMAS for five consecutive years. Other outstanding practitioners are Sebastian Sayson, Ramon Reyes, and Luis Reyes for Mike de Leon’s Itim (The Rites of May), 1976; Gregorio Ella for Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974, and Bakya Mo Neneng (Your Wooden Slippers, Neneng), 1977; Gaudencio Barredo for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Hero Turns Black), 1978; Teddy Ramos and Vic Macamay, who worked with Rolly Ruta in the Ishmael Bernal episode of Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979; Cesar Lucas for Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 1980; Rudy Baldovino for Broken Marriage, 1983, and Scorpio Nights, 1985; Gabby Castellano for Sumuko Ka, Ronquillo (Surrender, Ronquillo), 1983; Rodel Capule for the “Banga” (Jar) episode in Halimaw (Monster), 1986; Joe Clemente for Tiyanak (Changeling), 1988; and Joe Climaco for Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990. As in other fields of filmmaking, many sound practitioners in Philippine movies are related to each other, as in the case of Reyes, de Santos, and Clemente. For purposes of upgrading their craft and profession, the sound engineers banded themselves together into the Sound Technicians Association for Motion Picture under the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1981.

 

The coming of digital video technology in the late 1990s altered the process of sound recording. In digital audio recording, the digital recorder processes and stores the sound that comes through the microphone. The recorder measures the level of electrical signal and records those measurements in binary codes. Digital recording offers high quality in its small, lightweight package. It provides longer, continuous recording with the sound stored in a small memory card. It is timecode-capable, index-ready, and easily accessible to mark and quickly locate the takes at any point of the recording.

 

In the new millennium, a new breed of sound engineers emerged who are remembered for specific movies. They are Ditoy Aguila for Baler, 2008, and Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, 2012; Emmanuel Nolet Clemente for Serbis (Service), 2008, and 10,000 Hours, 2013; Albert Michael Idioma for Feng Shui, 2004, Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, and El Presidente (The President), 2012; Mark Laccay for Tribu (Tribe), 2007, and Puti (White), 2013; Mark Locsin for Dinig Sana Kita (If I Knew What You Said), 2009, and Bwakaw, 2012; and Addiss Tabong for Emir, 2010, and Amok, 2012.  Written by Nick Cruz and Joel David, with notes from  Pio de Castro III , Bienvenido Lumbera , and Nicanor G. Tiongson, u pdated by Rica Arevalo

Sound mixer Rolly Ruta, an electronics engineer who managed Magnatech since its establishment, is a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Hall of Fame awardee for Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984; Paradise Inn, 1985; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; and Chinatown, 1988. He is the only sound director who won the FAMAS for five consecutive years. Other outstanding practitioners are Sebastian Sayson, Ramon Reyes, and Luis Reyes for Mike de Leon’s Itim (The Rites of May), 1976; Gregorio Ella for Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974, and Bakya Mo Neneng (Your Wooden Slippers, Neneng), 1977; Gaudencio Barredo for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Hero Turns Black), 1978; Teddy Ramos and Vic Macamay, who worked with Rolly Ruta in the Ishmael Bernal episode of Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979; Cesar Lucas for Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 1980; Rudy Baldovino for Broken Marriage, 1983, and Scorpio Nights, 1985; Gabby Castellano for Sumuko Ka, Ronquillo (Surrender, Ronquillo), 1983; Rodel Capule for the “Banga” (Jar) episode in Halimaw (Monster), 1986; Joe Clemente for Tiyanak (Changeling), 1988; and Joe Climaco for Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990. As in other fields of filmmaking, many sound practitioners in Philippine movies are related to each other, as in the case of Reyes, de Santos, and Clemente. For purposes of upgrading their craft and profession, the sound engineers banded themselves together into the Sound Technicians Association for Motion Picture under the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1981.

The coming of digital video technology in the late 1990s altered the process of sound recording. In digital audio recording, the digital recorder processes and stores the sound that comes through the microphone. The recorder measures the level of electrical signal and records those measurements in binary codes. Digital recording offers high quality in its small, lightweight package. It provides longer, continuous recording with the sound stored in a small memory card. It is timecode-capable, index-ready, and easily accessible to mark and quickly locate the takes at any point of the recording.

In the new millennium, a new breed of sound engineers emerged who are remembered for specific movies. They are Ditoy Aguila for Baler, 2008, and Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, 2012; Emmanuel Nolet Clemente for Serbis (Service), 2008, and 10,000 Hours, 2013; Albert Michael Idioma for Feng Shui, 2004, Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, and El Presidente (The President), 2012; Mark Laccay for Tribu (Tribe), 2007, and Puti (White), 2013; Mark Locsin for Dinig Sana Kita (If I Knew What You Said), 2009, and Bwakaw, 2012; and Addiss Tabong for Emir, 2010, and Amok, 2012.
